P R E F A C E
<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1727427415Screenshot2024-09-27142645.png"/>

Candidates intending to appear for the Inter Arts Examination of the University of Bombay in 1948, 49 and 50 have to ad the MudrƒÅrƒÅk·π£asa of Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta as one of the prescribed ts in Sanskrit. The present edition of the MudrƒÅrƒÅksasa is imarily intended for them. With a view to facilitating the understanding of the text, the translation of the same into English has been printed just below it. Students need not to be rightened by the brackets, semicircular and rectangular, appearing in the translation. The former contain Sanskrit words to the rendering of which it was found necessary to draw a pointed attention of the reader in which case the words have been printed in italics with the necessary diacritical marks. The latter are ended mostly when certain words had to be supplied in order to complete the sense yielded by the words in the text itself. Lines purprose following each verse are numbered so as to make a reference to them in the Notes easy The number of the act and act of the verse explained are indicated at the top of every page the Notes part of the edition. Thus on page 56 of the Notes [II 11] at the top in the right hand corner indicates that on that ge is to be found the explanation of the 11th verse from the second act of the play. 2, 10,7 on that very page down below indicates that the 7th line commencing from after the 10th verse from the second act is being explained. The first figure refers to the act, the second to the verse from after which lines in prose are counted and the third to the number of the line which is being explained.

In the preparation of this edition I have used all previous editions that became avilable to me and I take this opportunity of expressing my indebtedness to all p≈´rva s≈´ris in the field. In the pages that follow there is nothing original to which I lay claim. I have, however, made a slight departure from the practice obtaining heretofore in the writing of Notes. I have not only mentioned but also explained, briefly though, the figures of speech in the passages under consideration. I thought it better to refer to the metre of every verse, giving the scheme of

the same, on the occasion of its first occurance, in the Notes themselves, than relegating the same to one of the appendices, as few students refer to them. In making this departure, I was prompted by only one consideration viz., that an I. A. student is a student of language and literature, and that it is desirable that he is introduced to this aspect of the study of his text, even before he begins to read for his degree examination.

For the deficiency arising out of failure to secure the necessary diacritical marks for the names of the dramatis personae the translation, inspite of all efforts, there is nothing else I can do except hoping to be excused by the generous readers. To thestaffs of the Modern Printing Press and the Aryasamskriti Mudranalaya, Poona, I am thankful for the co-operation they gavein having this edition of more than 400 pages printed. To M N. K. Gandhi Proprietor, the Popular Book Store, Surat, I offer my sincere thanks. But for his help, I would not have ever thought of bringing out the edition in these difficult days.

All suggestions to make this edition more useful to those towhom it is intended will be gladly and thankfully accepted.

R. R. College, Bombay.
R. R. Deshpande

I N T R O D U C T I O N

1.VisƒÅkhadatta, the author of the MudrƒÅ·πõƒÅk·π£asa:
his date, scholarship and other works.

(a) Date

Those who seek information about the author of the MudrƒÅrƒÅk·π£asa as revealed by the play itself have to depend on two passages primarily. (1) The first of these is 1, 2, 1-3 and reads after the stage direction (‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á) as also the S≈´tradhƒÅra’s formal‡§Ö‡§≤‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§® as follows:‚Äî

‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§ü‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•ã‡§É ‡§ï‡§µ‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø There are variant readings ‚Äò‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡§¶‡§≠‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•Å‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•ã‡§É‚Äô for ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•ã‡§É and ‘‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø’ for ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø Of these the former is rejected on account of its not maintaining the symmetry which is otherwise found intheauthor’s own statementabout himself, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§ü‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ which brings out that his grandfather was ‡§µ‡§ü‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ having the rank of a‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ (the lowest rung of the ladder), that his father was‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§, who was, it is safe to infer, raised to the satue of a‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú (having thus risen higher than the officers called ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï, and ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ, who represent the intervening rungs of the ladder, beginning from‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ and ending with ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú and that he was himself ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ by name. This would make it clear that‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ was the distinctive nominal ending of the family of the dramatist. Regarding ‘‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø’ instead of‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø (see footnote 4, p. 2 of this edition), it has to be noted that only three manuscripts out of a total of ninecollated by Mr. K. as‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ who had the distinction of having raised his family from the ‚Äò‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‚Äô of the previous generation to ‚Äò‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‚Äô.

(2) The other passage directly useful for our purpose is the Bharata-vƒÅkya of the play, and even from it, the 4th line in particalar: ‡§∏ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ (or ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ or ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ or ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É It is customary for the dramatƒ±st to express through the bharata-vƒÅkya of his play what he wishes should happen to his contemporaries or to the succeeding generations. The play proper is over and in the bharata-vƒÅkya it is unlikely that any reference to any incident in the plot of the play itself, or to any of the dramatis personae or characters of the play is made. It is safe on this account to infer that whatever the name of the king mentioned in the bharata-vƒÅkya of the ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏, the king referred to is the one who ruled in the days of the poet, one who was the poet’s patron. This enables us to turn to the consideration of another important question viz, that of the date of the author of the play.

  • *Taking the reading‚Äò‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É‚Äô first, it is seen that Mr. Telang accepts this reading only to be in conformity with the name accepted by the commentator DhundirƒÅja, whose commentary he has printed along with the text of the play. In his learned Introduction, however, Mr. Telang shows a marked inclination to the other reading‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ(a). If the reading‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É isaccepted as genuine, the king referred to would be‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ II of the Gupta dynasty (about the fifth century A. D.) who is being glorified by‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ for the former’s signal services to BhƒÅratavar·π£a in having defeated the white Huns (‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ_(s)) who had become a great nuisance to the people of this land. This would bring us to the conclusion that flourished in the 5th century A D (b) If the other reading is genuine, however, the question as to who is ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç mentioned in the ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø becomes important ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ and ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ are rejected as errors made by copyists (though it may incidentally be pointed out that‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ has been taken to be a Pallava king of that name who is known to have been ruling about the beginning of the 9th century A.D. and that the play has been assigned by some to the 11th or 12th century A.D.) To turn to ‘‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ’, the history of Indra reveals that King‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æof Kanaujco-operated with‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®of Thanesar andwith him shared the glory of

having saved India from the attacks of the Huns who were given a crushing blow in the year 582 A.D. Prof. Dhruva concludes from this, that ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§, ‚Äòmay be safely put down in the second half of the sixth century [There is another ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ, king of Kashmere (about 850 A. D.) known to history. On the basis of this identification, Jacobi expresses the opinion that the ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ was enacted before this ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ of Kashmere on the 2nd of December, 860 A.D. As against this it has to be pointed out that in the play itself there is the mention of a king of Kashmere ‘‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É’ who was buried deep into the earth by‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å, Act V. This milhtates against the identification between ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ of the ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø of the play and ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ, king of Kashmere. ‘‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ Act I, ‡§ó‡•å‡§°‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡•Ç‡§≤‡§ø Act V. ‚Äò‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä…‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç Act VII contain references to paddy, ladies from Bengal and the VarƒÅha encarnation of Vi·π£iu. The cumulative effect of these is that there is a general agreement to take the poet to be hailing from Bengal, rather than from Kashmere‚Äîand the date assigned to him, therefore, is the 2nd half of the 6th century A.D, and not the 2nd halt of the 9th century A. D. The tolerance shown to the Jaina friar, Jivasiddhi (who is in fact Indu≈õarmƒÅ, a BrƒÅhamna disguised as a Jaina) confirms this earlier date of the author and even more so does the high eastern in which the life and carear of Gautama Buddha [or of Budhists generally] are held in VII, 5: ‚Äú‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ.’ For, it was afterSa·πÅkarƒÅcƒÅry (800 A.D.) dealt a death-blow to Budhism, that the followers of that system suffered heavily in popular esteem.

Having decided the age to which the author of the MudrƒÅrƒÅk·π£asa belonged, we may proceed to consider such bits of evidence as throw light on other aspects of the play.

(b) Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta’s Scholarship.

(1) That the auother was a close student of the SahityaSastra in general and of the nƒÅ·π≠ya≈õastra section of it in particular, is evident on even a cursory reading of the play. The many metres which the dramatist handles skilfully, the alaniekƒÅras in which the verses in the play obound, the patƒÅkƒÅsthƒÅnas or ga·πádas

of which the author seems to be so fond, the criticism he offers on the performance of an unskilled dramatist (‘‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•á ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§£‡•á‚Äô) the consciousness he has of the extreme care that a dramatist must exercise (‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ), the five ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø in a play he refers to‚Äîall prove one fact bevond all dipute that ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ was a very close student of the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ and even there particularly of the section of it. It need hardly be mentioned that the dramatist, as was only natural to expect of him, knew Sanskrit grammar as also the peculiarities of the PrƒÅk·πõts used in the play.

(2) The ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞’s ‘‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§É‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á’ the verse ‚Äò‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‚Äô Act IV and the verse ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§É‡•• Act I,6. leave no doubt in the mind of the readers that ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§himself was well versed in the Science of the Luminaries (‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞).

(3) A whole verse in act V (10). Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta devotes to the requirements of a sound syllogism and he also states how a wrong or defective kind of sƒÅdhana or middle term expose a debater to defeat (in an assembly, like the wrong kind of army exposing a king to defeat on the battle-ground). This coupled with the logical exposition that‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø makes of his policy for the benefit of‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ (Act III,) clearly indicates the mastery of the author of the play over the branch of knowledge known as Logic.

(4) The two systems of philosophy‚Äîheterodox from the orthodox Brahmanical view-point‚Äîviz. Jainiam and Buddhism were well known by‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ as is borne out by the use of the technical terms ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§§‡§É (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø) ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø) in regard to the former, and by the reference to the deeds of Bauddhas (‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É etc.VII, 5) in regard to the latter.

(5) It would be no unfair conclusion to draw, in view of II 4, (.. ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§) and V 3, (‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ…‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§É) that ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ had cultivated a more than casual acquaintance with the art of painting. I, 2; III, 15, 21, etc. would seem to corroborote the conclusion. For they give such vivid pen-pictures of the objects they deal with as to make the

Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta devotes to the requirements of a sound syllogism and he also states how a wrong or defective kind of sƒÅdhana or middle term expose a debater to defeat (in an assembly, like the wrong kind of army exposing a king to defeat on the battle-ground). The spies employed by CƒÅ·πáakya, as also those by RƒÅk·π£asa, the apparent malcontents like BhƒÅgurƒÅyana and others going over to Malayaketu and RƒÅk·π£asa, the various measures adopted by RƒÅksasa with a view to get rid of Candragupta and their being furstrated one and all by CƒÅnakya ‘who ever keeps awake’‚Äîall make a very interesting reading, which proves one thing more than anything else viz. In Act V‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ gets himself placed into the greatest difficulty.‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï is seen to have a letter on his person, in the handwriting of‡§∂‡§ï‡§ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏’s friend. The letter is said to have been intended to be delivered to ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ and sent by ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏. To make things worst, ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï has with him ornaments formerly given by ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å to ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏. These ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï says would be given away to ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ along with the letter. The letter bears the stamp of the signet-ring of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏. To make the situation even more complicated, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ hasonhis own person ornaments which formerly were used by‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å’s father, murdered for political purposes. The estrangement between ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å and‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ is complete just on the eve of their attack against ‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ (Act V). ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ returns to ‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ only with one hope now viz. saving the life of his dearest friend‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏, He comes to an old garden now no longer well maintained. There he comes across a person who tells him he is going to kill himself as his friend ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏ is going to put

an end to his life before he himself learns of the worst calamity that was to befall his dearest friend ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ decides to set out with his sword to rescue‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏ from the executioners but gives up the idea on learning from the friend of‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏ that the executioners have of late begun instantaneously killing the person in their charge when they see any one with a weapon in their vicinity (Act VI). Just when‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏ is about to be killed,‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ surrenders himself to the ex cutioners. The news isconveyed to ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø makes it quite plain to ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ that if the latter wants‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏to be allowed to live,‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ has to accept the ministership of ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§. And thus‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ is compelled to do, what he would have avoided by all means.‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏acceptsoffice for the sake of the friend who had suffered most on his account, who had given shelter to ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§Ω wife and son, thus exposing himself to death at the hands of Candragupta’s executioners. Manyaketu is taken prisoner by ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§£ –µct, but released on ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏’s request to do so-this being his first request in his capacity as the Prime Minister of Candragupta. CƒÅ·πáakya retires from active politics now satisfied that Candragupta’s empire is in safe hands and thus comes to a close Act VII as well as the drama itself.

The account of the plot of the play will make it clear that the play is political in nature. There are spies of CƒÅ·πáakya and spies of RƒÅk·π£asa; as also assassins, poisoners (a poison-maiden), secret agents in the guise of K·π£apanaka and others who are kept intensely active throughout the course of the play. Regarding the historicity of the events and the persons, it can be safely stated that CƒÅ·πáakya and Candragupta were historical person. that RƒÅk·π£asa too was a historical person. For, the dramatist, who is very particular about appropriately naming such subordinate characters as ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï, ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡§ï, ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï etc. would not have given such a monstrous name to the minister whose services CƒÅ·πáakya is shown to be so anxious to secure for Candragupta. Malayaketu also probably is a historical person. Other details‚Äîmost of them‚Äîare inventions of the poet, though it is not unlikely that in the lives of other persons and in days other than those of CƒÅ·πáakya and RƒÅk·π£asa, they took place. The highest skill is displayed by Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta in thus welding

together faet and fiction of a type and making MudrƒÅrƒÅksasa one of the most remarkable plays in Sanskrit language and literature.

Sources of the Play

The storyof Candragupta is told in the Pura·πáas‚ÄîVis≈Üu, VƒÅvu Matsya etc. from which it is learnt that Nanda called‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ or‡§µ‡§®‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ ruled for 88 years and his sons who were eight in number for 12 years, that CƒÅnakya exterminated the Nanda family, that Candragupta ruled for a period of 34 or 24 years. In Buddhist and Jain works, Candragupta’s mother MurƒÅ is said to have been a servant girl of ‡§ß‡§®‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶, ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ is said to have been SƒÅkya and his family name Maurya explained on the ground that their main city was planned like a peacock’s neck and therefore styled as Murianagara. From Greek sources is learnt the story of Sandracottus or Xandrames. Of late, the equation of Sandracottus with Candragupta Maurya has come to be challenged and the view is put forth that Sandracoottus’ account comes closer to that of Samudragupta or Candragupta of the Gupta dynasty. This Sandracottus was a low-born king, who attained his position as king, only after the departure of Alexander. Seleukus Nekator is said to have entered into an alliance with this Sandracottus at whose court Megasthenes was an ambassador. The Kathasaritsagara too gives an account of CƒÅ·πáakya’s abhicƒÅre rites as a result of which the death of Nanda took place within seven days. DhundirƒÅja in his commentary gives an account of the treatment given by the nine Nandas to Candragupta who was only eagerly waiting for an opportunity to avenge himself and of the irascible CƒÅ·πáakya whom Candragupta found trying to burn a cluster of darbhas that had pricked his foot With the aid of Paravataka, the mountain chief,‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø and‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ seized‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ and killed the Nandas. CƒÅ·πáakya then established Candragupta on the throne, himself becoming his minister. [Verses 23-84, pp. 40-44 of Mr. Telang’s edition eighth, 1935, will be read with profit in this connection, and particularly, verses 46-57 and 71-82]

III Time taken by the action in the Play

On a perusal of the MudrƒÅrƒÅk·π£asa, it should not be difficult to fix up the time taken by the entire action in the play

Perhaps the best way of attacking this uuestion is to concentrate attention on two facts (I) that in Act III there takes place the sham quarrel between CƒÅ·πáakya and Candragupta on the PaurnimƒÅ of the month of KƒÅritika and (2) that in Act IV Malayaketu observes ’to day is the tenth month since the departure of dear father to the yonder world. After the incidents in Act III, a month’s time must have been required for the preparation of the army with the purpose of launching an attack against Pataliputra. This brings us to the conclusion that ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å’s utterance ‚Äò‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‚Äô belongs to the month of ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑. Ten months previous to that, that is in month of‡§´‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£ in the earlier year, ‡§™‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ï was murdered. As ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ is said to have stayed in ‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ as long as he liked, even after the city was taken by Candragupta’s forces, it follows that the action of the drama, 1. e. of the first act must have begun in the month of Chaitra. Here the day also can be decided. It must have been ‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ as the eclipse of the moon ‘‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø’ is possible on that day. The ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ of ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§ï which ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ wanted to carry out must be the frst ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß of the departed mountain-chief. In Act II,‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ reports the happenings in‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞ having covered all the distance from there to the camp of Malayaketu, which, presumably must have been 200 miles or so. A month’s time between the events in Act I and those of the II must have elapsed. Thus the action of the II act took place in the month of Vai≈õƒÅkha. The sham quarrel took place on the Paur·πáimƒÅ of KƒÅrtika. The intervening months must have been used by both the parties to strengthen their respective postitions, as due to rains, no activity or movement of the army was possible. In act IV, Karabhaka brings news of the cleavage between CƒÅnakya and Candragupta which became a public property on the Paur·πáimƒÅ of KƒÅrtika. Karabhaka must have taken between a fortnight and a month to reach Malayketu’s camp. Thus by the moth of ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ RƒÅk·π£asa must have had his army ready for an attack on PƒÅ·π≠aliputra. Malayaketu’s army is ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§® i.e near ‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞. This must have been possible after a journey of a fortnight or month, thus bringing us to the conclusion that the action in Act V must probably have occured in the beginning of the month of ‡§™‡•å‡§∑. Act VI and VII show that Malayaketu’s forces have been given a crushing defeat, that ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏

has come back to Pataliputra to save the life of his friend ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏. This too would require a fortnight or a month in happen. The action of the play thus would appear to end by the month of MƒÅgha. This means that the entire action in the play takes about ten months’ time to be completed.

IV A Critical estimate of the Play

In many respects the MudrƒÅrƒÅk·π£asa of Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta is so different from other plays in Sanskrit as to be regarded a surgeneris or a class by itself in the realm of Sanskrit dramas. Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta did not undertake the delineation of the tenderest feeling in the human heart, since its inception to its almost divine perfection as is done by KalidƒÅsa in his SƒÅkuntalam. Nor did he, Bhavabh≈´ti-like, choose to hold before us the highest ideal of kings, who in order to ensure the gratification of his subjects is prepared to ignore even the most sacred duty he owed to his own beloved wife (‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§π‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡••). Vi≈õƒÅkhƒÅdatta felt not like depicting an unusual aspect of love viz. that of a beautiful young courtezan for a family-man to whom she feels drawn irresistibly on account of the inordinate generosity of his heart that reduced him to absolute penury. That was quite a good theme, fit to be made the subject of a play, according to the author of the M·πõcchaka·π≠ika. Nor did Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta dramatise the vengeance of a hero who is no lover of peace for the sake of peace’ for the grossest injustice that was inflicted on his wife by his enemies hailing from the same family as his own. That was Bha·π≠·π≠a Naraya·πáa’s choice of theme presented to us in the from of the Ve·πáƒ´sa·πÅhƒÅra. And yet Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta’s play ranks so high in the group of Sanskrit plays as easily to find a place for itself in the first few best. To Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta the absence of more female characters than one is no handicap. Even the lady who has succeeded in finding a place for herself in the dramatis persone of the MudrarƒÅk·π£asa, does not occupy the stage for more than a few minutes. There is only one way of describing the MudrƒÅrƒÅk·π£asa properly and it is to characterise it as a Political play

  • *There are spies of CƒÅ·πáakya and spies of RƒÅk·π£asa, murderers or assassins, poisoners, those who could arrange mechanical

arches to fall on the principal party on the accasion of the state entry into the palace of the king, incendiaries, there are men disguised as snake-charmers and as Jaina friars. There are forged letters and ornaments which though expected to be in possession of one party, are actually possessed by another. There are friendsready to face the gallows for friends. There are otherswho feign friendship with anulterior political purpose in view. There are executioners realand men who only appear in the guise of executioners. Thereis a well disciplined prince, and a prince who knows not what he is doing or saying. The MudrƒÅrƒÅk·π£asa atmosphere is so different form the atmosphere of the general run of Sanskrit plays.

It is, therefore, necessary to seek for the factors that made it possible for Vi≈õƒÅkhatta to come out triumphant in his admittedly difficult task. Those who read the play with a view to being able to answer the question, ‘what made Vi≈õƒÅkhatta’s success possible?’ do not fail to notice the following important features of the play.

(1) Unity of Action‚Äî It can be said, without the least exaggeration, that Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta has shown his thorough mastery over a principle so essential for the success of a literary artist viz., that of the unity of action. It is needless to give an outline of the plotof the‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ here (the resume of each one of the acts given in the Notes may be profitably read, at this stage). But it isevident to all readers of the play that all incidents, small or big, all measures, remedies or actions arm at only *one abject viz.*winning over RƒÅk·π£asa and making him accept the responsibility of the Prime Minister of Candragupta. The signet-ring, the forged letter, the ornaments given by Candragupta to Vi≈õvƒÅvasu and his two brothers, the receiving of an ornament from RƒÅk≈õasa by SiddhƒÅ·π≠haka, ≈öaka·π≠adƒÅsa’s being sent to the execution-ground, his miraculous rescue, the K·π£pa·πáaka’s work, BhƒÅgurƒÅyana’s contribution, CandanadƒÅsa’s being taken to the execution-ground, all these are made to focus themselves on just one thing-making ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ see the inevitability of the acceptance of the offer of the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§¶ of ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§Æ. In fact so

great is the success that Vi≈õakhadatta has achieved in the respect that even from the stand-point of western critics most particular about the three unities‚Äîthat of time, that of place and that of action, the performance of Vi≈õakhadattas admirable as nothing else in the entire range of Sanskit literature. Subordination of minor events, acts, faetors, to the main object has been quite thoroughly accomplished by Vi≈õakhadatta.

The other two unities viz. that of time and place, can be said to have equally well been achived by the dramatist, For the entire action of the play covers the period of a bareten months‚Äîcontrast Bhavabh≈´ti’s UttararƒÅmacraita in this respect‚Äîand the scene is laid either in PƒÅ·π≠aliputra or in Malayaketu’s capital at a distales of about 200 miles from PƒÅ·π≠aliputra or his camp somewhere midway between the two.

(2) Consummate skill in caracter-delineation‚ÄîAnother forte of Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta isthe consummate skill with which he has delineated the various characters in the play. Like all high ranking literary artists, Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta was thoroughly aware of the importance of the principle of contrast in this aspect of the art of composing a play (Cf. Venƒ´sa·πÉhƒÅra, SƒÅkuntala, where character. study in pairs, sometimes in threes, for instance ≈öƒÅkuntala, Anus≈´yƒÅ and PriyamvadƒÅ, is given). Thus there are two PrimeMinisters the astute, resolute, implusive, irascible, but ever vigilant, ever resourceful CƒÅ·πáakya who is to be contrasted with RƒÅk·π£asa, Prime Minister of the Nandas, given to anxious meditation, finding fault with fate, occasionally blundering, not careful enough in the choice of men, devoted to the master no doubt, but having an adravya like Malayaketu to depend on and therefore failing in his object of ousting Candragupa from the throne, There is Candragupta, well-discplined, full of reverence for his preceptor, regarding the order of the preceptor to act independently for a while to be nothing less than a sin. Contrasted with him is Malayaketu with no diplomacy and very little modesty to his credit, eavesdropping, suspecting the one whose sincerity of purpose was beyond dispute, vain and therefore defeated most

disastrously by CƒÅ·πáakya with the minimum amount of fighting. There are the two Chamberlains, the two ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ω; CƒÅ·πáakya’s friend Indu≈õaman in the guise of a Jaina friar is well contrasted with CandanadƒÅsa, the flame of whose love for his friend RƒÅksasa blazes forth despite the violent gales it has to face. Each character is made to stand out from the rest so well that it would not be difficult to assign without reading from the text of the play, the important utterance to the characters to whom they belong.

*(3) Fine sense of style‚Äî*There is one more reason besides those indicated above why Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta’s play has been able to win a high place for itself. It is that Vi·π£ƒÅkhadatta had a very fine sense of style. Whether it was prose, or in verse, Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta knew well which words would suit his purpose best, which combination would be most favourable to the effect intended to be achieved. On the whole, Vi≈õƒÅkhƒÅdatta’s prose is full of perspicuity‚Äîwith very few (Act II) involved sentences or long compounds. In Act I and Act III, in the dialogues between ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏ and between ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ respectively Vi≈õƒÅkhdatta’s prose isseen to be at its best (‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç or ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§∂‡•ç‡§õ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§ as also ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§É ‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡•§ ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•§ ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø). The raciness, the vigour, the sarcasm of VisƒÅƒ∑hdatta’s prose have contributed considerably to his success. Vi≈õƒÅkhsdatta handles a variety of meteres and he knows thoroughly well that certain metres and just those only are the most effective media of certain thoughts. ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§§, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ, ‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ and other metres are deftly handled by the dramatist. No careful reader of the play can forget the lyrical charm of some of the verses put into ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏’s mouth, when on returning to Pataliputra he hides himself in a dilapidated garden (Act VI). Well in contrast with these are verses such as

‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§¶‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ú‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§É‡§™‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡•§ etc. (III, 30 or III 27, 28) where long compounds

Not to be merely enthusiastic in the appreciation of the play, it has to be pointed out that Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta repeats certain ideas too often (his ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï of ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø, ‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§≤, ‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§≤ isan example easily suggesting itself), that he is inordinately fond of‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ (pointod out in the Notes) and that occasionally he overdoes the.**effect acheved by a‡§™‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§® or ‡§ó‡§£‡•ç‡§° (Act I) not minding that character is made to wait ridiculously long and that some of his verses are altogether prosaic.

But even after duly pointing out the blemishes, it has to be owned that the effect of the drama as a whole is to make the reader exclaim ‚Äúremarkably well-done:!-f not excellent indeed !‚Äî and this despite the handicaps inherent in the very nature of the species of drama, Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta set himself to write Consequetely the reader sees no reason to grudge the dramatist satisfaction he derives in ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡•§ though the satisfaction is of the nature of self-congratulating.

V Main Characters of The Play

(1) CƒÅnakya as he is drawn by V≈õƒÅkhadatta

The play proper begins with the appearance of CƒÅnakya on the stage. He is full of anger, and in no way conceals his displeasure at what he heard some one say ’this one desires to overpower Candra, though possessed of the circle in its entirety’. The implusiveness of the Prime Minister is brought out by the fact that though the seat was already kept therefore him’ he did not notice it and took the pupil to task for what was no fault of his. But the preceptor and Prime Minister of Candragupta is also kind at heart. There is no ‘inherent bad temper’ towards the pupils of which he at any rate can be accused. CƒÅ·πáakya’s self-confidence. resourcefulness, capacity of turning almost any

and every happening to his own best advantage are well brought out in Act I. The signet-ring brought by Nipu·πáaka suggests to him an elabroate plan which is worked out in full during the remaining acts of the play. CƒÅ·πáakya has a sense of apprectiation of merits wherever they are found and hence the unstinted praise which he bestows on RƒÅk·π£asa who is devotion, valour, intellignce, all in one, according to Canakya. In fact, RƒÅk·π£asa is characterized by him as ‚ÄúMantri-B·πõhaspati‚Äù. The second act shows, how very Vigilant how thorough a statesman was the preceptor of Candragupta. All the plans of RƒÅk·π£asa are either forestalled or frustrated by CƒÅ·πáakya. CƒÅ·πáakya being a politician first and politician last,‚Äîtill RƒÅksasa is won over to the side of Candragupta at least minds not the deaths or virtual murders of Vairocaka and, Varvaraka. DƒÅruvarman, Abhayadatta, Bƒ´bhatsaka all perish for the simple reason that they desired and strove to kill Candragupta. CƒÅ·πáakya has no compunction, no qualms of conscience as his principle was to maintain the efficiency of the administration by all means. Act III reveals CƒÅ·πáakya at his best. The sham quarrel, in its conception as well as execution, is a master stroke that keeps RƒÅk·π£asa on a wrong track. Act V shows how deep laid the plan of CƒÅ·πáakya was. Jƒ´vasiddhi, BhƒÅgurƒÅya·πáa are all CƒÅ·πáakya’s agents. The forged letter, stamped with the signet-ring of RƒÅk·π£asa, the ornaments CƒÅ·πáakya had arranged to be sold to RƒÅk·π£asa who wore them, the ornament given by RƒÅk·π£asa to SiddhƒÅrthaka as a *‘pƒÅristo·π£ika’*on ≈öaka·π≠adƒÅsa’s release by him, now made to accompany the letter sent by RƒÅk·π£asa to Candragupta’ destroy totally the friendly relations of Malayaketu and RƒÅk·π£asa. Again in Act VI, CƒÅ·πáakya’s intelligence and his plan it is that make RƒÅk·π£asa throw his weapon and in the VII, he succeeds in making RƒÅk·π£asa accept the ministership of Candragupta, it not for any thing else, at least to save the life of his dearest friend CandanadƒÅsa!CƒÅ·πáakya’s mastery over the springs of human action is finally proved. But even after this there is no tinge of boasting, no vanity shown by him. On the contrary he leaves everything to be decided by RƒÅk·π£asa. ‘When he is there to guide the state business, what use are we?,’ be observes, and the one who was seen in an earlier act to be staying in a cottage with dilapidated walls, with little more than cowdung cakes, darbhas, and a piece of stone….2

by way of property, retires never to bother himself with state administration again. He is pleased that RƒÅksasa has accepted the responsibility. This exit of CƒÅ·πáakya leaves as indelible an impression on the reader, as his first appearance, in fact as all’ he said and did, even the ‘vaunting’ as some would characterize it, on his having destroyed all the scions of the Nanda family and reader is filled with admiration (may be not unmixed with awe still lurking in his mind) for this politician who did notmix up philosophy withpolitics and did not allow a mess to be made of the state, but ever retained it strong and firm.

(2) RƒÅk·π£asa

Next to C√¢·πáakya and as his, rival, it is RƒÅk·π£asa who claims the attention of the reader. That his devotion to his master was the highest is evident as he continued to terve him, even after his departure to the other world. RƒÅk·π£asa is possessed of ‚ÄúprajnƒÅ‚Äù on CƒÅ·πáakya’s own confession. Act II is an eloquent testimony to this. Only a superior politician with CƒÅ·πáakya’s mettle could frustrate RƒÅk·π£asa. Fallen on evil days, this former minister of the Nandas has become, if he was not even earlier, sentimental and superstitious. He is full of tears to see the plight of VirƒÅdhagupta. He finds it difficult to recognize quickly his spies. He blunders, almost calls his secret agents by their names and then tries to check himself and to comouflage. One who was to be admitted for listening to subhƒÅ·π£itas from him us said to be admitted for showing serpents. Fidelity, unflinching devotion, however, are the strongest points of the minister of the Nandas. He is all full of joy on seeing ≈†aka»õadƒÅsa reported to have been impaled on the stake, safe again. After being dismissed by Malayaketu, RƒÅk·π£asa comes back to PƒÅ·π≠aliputra mainly to save the life of his ‚Äòdvitiyam h·πõadyam’, CandanadƒÅsa. This trant is the most apppealing to us. RƒÅk·π£asa, the *mantri-b·πõhaspati,*we feel is essentially a man of this world. He give up his opposition to Candra and is ready to work as his prime minister. But such is the impression left on our minds by the character of the new prime minister of Candragupta that we have not the least doubt, as Canakya had not, that RƒÅk·π£asa would carry out his duties with the same devotion, sincerity and whole-hearted.

ness, as he did, while, serving his former masters, the Nandas. So very kind is RƒÅk·π£asa that out of consideration that he once stayed with Malayaketu, does he order him to be freed when brought by BhƒÅgurƒÅya·πáa etc. to be duly punished. He has no illusions about his capacity as campared with that of CƒÅ·πáakya and when offered the badge of the Prime Minister’s Office, the ≈õastra, by CƒÅ·πáakya, he frankly admits his unfitnese to take the same, especially as it was wielded by Ca·πáakya till then. Nothing weighed more with RƒÅk·π£asa, it is evident, than love of his friend, causing him to accept anything for that matter. Thus is the brave, devoted and intelligent minister of the Nandas seen to be accepting Candragupta’s service. The reader feels drawn to minisister RƒÅk·π£asa and is in no mood to criticize him. After all there was a point in saving the life of the dearest friend who did not care for his own, when he gave shelter to RƒÅk·π£asa’s wife and son, in their hour of need. When aught else deemed precious in life was lost, despite the sincerest and most persistent efforts to regain and retain the same, was a false sense of prestige to be deemed so important as to be permitted to lead one to perpetrate the most heinous crime viz. ungratefulness to one’s best friend?

(3) Candragupta

As indicated in the previous section, Candragupta is the devoted, well disciplined pupil of CƒÅ·πáakya. He is not prepared to have an undue amount of freedom and his mind feels like hiding itself into the bowels of the earth for having distespcted the revered preceptor though that was at the bidding of the preceptor himself. Candragupta is thus entirely dependent on
CƒÅ≈Üakya as far the play is coscerned may practically be considered to have no existence apart from that of the prepceptor.

(4) Malayaketa

This is another “prince” delineated in the play. He has no diplomacy to his credit. He is full of suspicion and does not consider it below his dignity to stoop to eavesdropping while

RƒÅk·π£asa and Karabhaka, are speaking about the happenings Kusumapura. BhƒÅguraya·πáa, CƒÅ·πáakya’s secret agent, has thorough hold over him and it is only what the stern logic events demanded that happened to him in the end viz., his being taken prisoner by BhƒÅguraya·πáa himself and his forces being very easily defeated by CƒÅ·πáakya. If Candragupta was “dravyaMalayaketu is a typical “adravya” marring all the elaborat efforts of RƒÅk·π£asa to oust Candragupta from the position of the sovereign Canakya bad won for him. The only redeeming feature of this prince is his love of his father.

(5) CandanadƒÅsa

From among the other characters of the play CandanadƒÅsa easily claims the highest attention of the reader. He is prepared for the worst, when summoned by the *‚Äúpitiless‚Äù*CƒÅ·πáakya. He has taken all precautions to see that RƒÅk·π£asa’s wife and son would not be found by CƒÅ·πáakya at his place, even if the latter were searched by CƒÅ·πáakya’s men. In politeness and being honey. tongued, “the president of the Merchant Guild is not to be beaten by even CƒÅ·πáakya at least upto a point. All attempts at frightening him‚Äîthe tumult on account of the banishment from the city with disgrace of some one, and that on account of the execution of another, make him only firmer in his resolve, not to surrender RƒÅk·π£asa’s wife and son to CƒÅ·πáakya. It is no wonder that CandanadƒÅsa’s wife and son too are equally resolute. He was meeting that kind of death fortunately for the sake of a friend and not because he had committed any crime. His last words to the wife are ‚ÄòYou must live and train this dear son of ours.‚Äô To the son he says Stay in a country, which would be free from CƒÅ·πáakya’s (unwelcome) presence.‚Äù And when RƒÅk·π£asa reveals his identity to the executioners and asks them to kill him (not CandanadƒÅsa), CandanadƒÅsa asks him noble one what have you done?‚Äù RƒÅk·π£asa’s reply to this is the best tribute paid to and the one most deserved by CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî‚Äúemulation of a bit of your excellent action. ‚ÄúNo reader of the Mudr√¢rƒÅk·π£sa would forget this merchant friend of RƒÅk·π£asa who outdid Sibi of the epic fame and surpassed by his noble deeds even the course of conduct of the Buddha saints.

doings of CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äîthe hero of the play. CƒÅ·πáakya, the critics would add, cannot boast of any the least adherence to lofty, edifying moral principles. And precisely here is it necessary to sound a note of caution to the critics. It is that CƒÅ·πáakya by virtue of the peculiar position of the society of which he was a member, could not have done anything better, from any view point, than what he did.

At this stage the readers would have to leave the MudrƒÅrƒÅk·π£asa of Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta aside for a while, and ascertain from the history of ancient India (3rd and 4th centuries B. C.) as to what was the state of affairs at that distant date. History reveals to us that but for the strong policy CƒÅ·πáakya adopted, there would have been politically speaking all chaos everywhere. In the absence of a firm State and a powerful Emperor well established on the throne, life would have been not only insecure, but also impossible for the vast bulk of the populace. It stands eternally to the credit of CƒÅ·πáakya that he developed the technique of the policy of ’thoroughness’ and suppressed with an iron hand all the mischievous elements eating into the very life, of the people. CƒÅ·πáakya was not led away by the mirage of spiritualising politics. He was too shrewd an observer of the kaleidoscope that is human life, too great a master of human nature with all its wonderful variety and too great a realist to have been led away from his main object viz., the establishment of a very strong and thoroughly equipped state. CƒÅ·πáakya did not love killing for the sake of killing. He himself pities SarvƒÅrthsiddhi (’tapasvi’ as the is called). His and Paravtaka’s murder w√©re a political necessity. The executions of Saka»õadƒÅsa and CandanadƒÅsa are but mimicries intended to serve the one purpose CƒÅ·πáakya had in view viz., of winning over RƒÅk·π£asa and making him accept the ministership of Candragupta. And Ca·πáakya’s choice fell on RƒÅk·π£asa for the important post for only one reason viz. that he was most worthy of it. Once his ‚ÄúprajnƒÅ‚Äô,‚Äòvikrama‚Äô and above all ‚Äòbhaktƒ±‚Äô were secured for Candragupta, there was not the remotest possibility of the State ever becoming weak or infirm on any account. CƒÅ·πáakya had no axe of his own to grind. There were no personal enemies whom he wanted to get rid of. The

object achieved, he quietly retires, never to interfere with statbnsiness again. CƒÅ·πáakya was thus the saviour of the people He never said anything or did anything for purposes of selsaggrandisement.

A glance at some of the most far reaching developments acontemporaoy world politics and an unbiassed study of the same would convince all that so far as morals are concerned there is no superiority over CƒÅ·πáakya to which twentieth century States men can lay claim. With an unparalleled record of brokes promises, dishonoured treaties, use of a hundred thousand times more destructive weapons, war time camouflage and peace time camouflage, subtle proraganda, penetration tactics of ‘democracies’ that would put ‘imperialism’ to shame, concentration camps, mass trials and what not, the present day politicians cutill afford to find fault with CƒÅ·πáakya. The hollowness of the stock-in-trade phrases and slogans that fit the very air we breathe is patent to us all. The cry for ’the amelioration of the masses ’the materialisation of the dream of universal brotherhood’ ’the appreciation of higher values’, and the ‘common heritage’ of man in effect, has amounted to nothing. The second world war brought into existence and helped flourish a species of markets, the black market, to so great an extent, that life to-day is permeated by it in all its branches and the most vigorous and most determined efforts on the part of every intelligent human being would be necessary to eradicate the evil that has affected human civilization and culture. What more strange than that those who have allowed, if not encouraged, this monster to thrive, should find’ fault with CƒÅ·πáakya’s morals and with the ethics of the MudrƒÅrƒÅk·π£asa?

**‡§®‡§ü‡•Ä‚Äî**‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡•Å ‡§£‡§Ö‡§π‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§£‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ [ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§]

** ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§ó‡•á12 ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡•§‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§ï‡§É‡•§ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡•§ ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡•ß‡•´

** ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‚Äî‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§É‡••‡•¨‡••**

**‡§®‡§ü‡•Ä‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§â‡§£ ‡§è‡§∏‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ö‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡•ã‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ã ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ [‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•á‡§∑ ‡§ß‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡§∞‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø‡•§]

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**(‡§Ü‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø ) ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

of crooked intellect, he is this one, by whom the Nanda dynasty was burnt down by force in the fire of [his] anger On account of [his] hearing ‚ÄòCandrasya graha·πáam’, he understands an onslaught by the enemy against the Maurya moon (Candragupta) with the same name (as that of Candra‚Äî ‘moon’).

with Malayaketu, son of Parvataka, enraged by the murder of his father [further] encouraged by the stipulation (parapatana) of the entire kingdom of the Nandas [and] surrounded by [i.e. accompanied by a great force of the Mleccha kings, is girding up his loins (ud-yukta) to attack Vrsala [Candragupta]? Fire of wrath gets cooled down, like the fire in forest, on account of the absence of the object to be burnt and not out of exhaustion, after having rendered dark the moon-faces of the quarters in the form of the young ladies on the enemy’s side by the continued grief-columns-of-smoke, after having scattered (prakƒ´rya) profusely (hƒÅmam) (or at will) the stupefaction ashes carried away by the statesmanship-wind over the minister-trees (and) burnt the bambooshoots (vam≈õrapraroha) in the form of the scions of the Nanda race, [now] divested of the flocks (jana) of birds in the form of the altogether frightened (sambhrƒÅnta) citizens.

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

Those people who with faces down-cast, with the word (s) ‘Fie (upon you)‚Äô suppressed (garbharh) within, through the fear of the king, grieving (in their heart) saw me, in thepast, helplessly dragged down from the main seat-they see, at present, Nanda with his [entire] family thrown down by me, in that very manner, from the throne (lit lion-seat), like a lordly elephant hurled down by a lion, from the peak of a mountain.

That I am at present wielding weapon, though I have carried out my weighty vow out of consideration for V·πõ·π£ala (i.e. Candragupta) (and not for myself). That I by whom

have been dug out the nine Nandas like [as many] darts from the heart of the Earth, [by whom] has been made to have a firm stand (lit. footing) Sovereignty in the son of MurƒÅ (i.e. Candragupta), like a lotus-creeper in a lake, [by whom] has been divided, with a mind closely applied [to the task], the two-fold fruit, best and even (equal tulyam), of anger and affection, respectively, between the two (viz.,) the hating (enemy) and the one with a fine heart (i.e. the friend).

(Reflecting) O the unsurpassed (nir-ati≈õaya) quality of RƒÅk·π£asa of devotion to the race of the Nandas To be sure (khalu), so long as some member of the Nanda family is alive, he cannot be made to accept the [principal] ministership of V·πõ·π£ala. What advantage (lit. merit) would there be with (a servant) not wise and nervous, possessed [though he may be] of dovotion? ‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

The best of elephants and the best of men, though strong by nature, generally undergo decay (sƒ´danti), afflicted [as they are when] maintaining themselves after having brought [the means of livelihood] themselves.

  • (Then enter a spy with a pictorial representation of Yama on, a piece of cloth)*

** Spy‚Äî** Prostrate [yourselves] and salute (pra-namata) the feet of Yama. What is to be done with (i. e. what use are) other divinities? Indeed, this one takes away the life, (which is) throbbing, of the devotees of others (i.e.other divinities).

Moreover,

A man’s sustenance becomes possible through one who is far from even (vi-·π£ama) (but) won over by devotion. The one who destroys all people,‚Äîby that Yama‚Äîdo we live.

I shall just enter this house and showing (i.e.spreading out for view) the Yama-chart, sing (some) songs.

‡§ú‡§æ‡§µ ‡§è‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•á‡§π ‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ö ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§™‡§°‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§á‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ [‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ ] (‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø)

** ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**(‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§π‡§Ç‡§π‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£, ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§è‡§¶ ‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡§Ç‡•§ [ ‡§π‡§π‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£, ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§]

** ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§® ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**(‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§π‡§π‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£, ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•á‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§ú‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§π ‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§£‡•ã‡§ò‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§π‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§™‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§µ ‡§¶‡•á ‡§â‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§æ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§™‡§°‡§Ç‡§™‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ö ‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§â‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ [‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£, ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•É‡§π ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ü ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§]

** ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§É‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§π‡§Ç‡§π‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£,‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§™36‡•§ ‡§® ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§£‡§¶‡§ø‡•§‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§â‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§æ‡§ì ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ [‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£, ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§ ‡§® ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§ ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§]

** ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∏‡§ø‡•§

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

(So saying, he walks round)

** Pupil‚Äî** (Observing), Good [Man], you should not enter.

**Spy‚Äî**Oh BrƒÅhmana! whose house is this?

** Pupil‚Äî**Of our preceptor Revered CƒÅnakya with a well invoked name.

Spy‚Äî (Laughing) This is a house as though of some one closely related to me (ƒÅtmiya), of a spiritual brother [so to say.] So grant me admittance so that having spread out the Yama-chart I shall instruct your preceptor in duty (dharma).

** Pupil‚Äî**(With anger) Fie (upon you) Oh fool! Are you a greater knower of duty than even our preceptor?

Spy‚Äî O BrƒÅhmana, do not be angry. For, not does everyone know everything. Therefore your preceptor knows something (while) people like us know some (other) thing.

** Pupil‚Äî** O fool, you desire to take away (lit steal) the omniscience of our preceptor.

** ‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§π‡§Ç‡§π‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£, ‡§ú‡§á ‡§§‡•Å‡§π ‡§â‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§æ‡§ì ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§£‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•á‡§¶‡•ã ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ [‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£, ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§§‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§]

** ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî** ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§®37 ‡§µ‡§æ‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî** ‡§§‡•Å‡§π ‡§â‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§æ‡§ì ‡§è‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ú ‡§á‡§Æ‡§ø‡§£‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§π‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ ‡§è‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡•á‡§¶‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•§ [‡§§‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•§]

‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§£‡§π‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§à ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§≤‡§Ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§á‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§á‡§Ç‡••‡•ß‡•Ø‡••

[ ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§π‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡••‡•ß‡•Ø‡••]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**( ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç)‡§Ö‡§Ø‡•á‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡§®‡•§

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** Spy‚Äî**O BrƒÅhmana, if your preceptor knows everything, let him know [and tell] then, to whom is Candra (moon, punningly Candragupta) not agreeable?

** Pupil‚Äî** Fool ! what [use or harm is there] by this being known or not known?

**Spy‚Äî**Your preceptor alone will know what (use) there would be with this being known. As for yourself (tvam tƒÅvat), you know [only this much] that Candra is not agreeable to the [day‚Äî] lotuses. I say, (just) see‚Äî

The character (silam) of lotuses which are attractive is entirely out of tune (vi-samvadati) with their [handsome] form [‚Äìof lotuses‚Äì] which are opposed to the moon when possessed of a full orb [punningly opposed to Candragupta, even when with the regal circle full or well equipped].

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî** (Listening, to himself) Oh! I know persons who are dissatisfied towards Candragupta‚Äî’this is what is hinted by this [man].

** ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

**‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§π‡§Ç‡§π‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§ú‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ ‡§è‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡•§ [‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ]

** ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§

**‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§ú‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§£‡§ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§£‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§π‡•á‡•§ [‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§≠‡•á‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•§ ‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•§

**‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§∏‡•ã ‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö) ‡§ú‡•á‡§¶‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ã‡•§ [ ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø (………………) ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**(‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç38 ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡§ï‡§É‡•§ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§) ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§â‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•§

**‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ [ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§] (‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É)

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§≤‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§É‡•§

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

**Pupil‚Äî**Fool ! what is this irrelevant (matter) being spoken (by you)?

** Spy‚Äî** Oh BrƒÅhmana, it would be nothing but (eva) relevant‚Äì

Pupil‚Äî In case what (happens)?

** Spy‚Äî** In case I get one who knows [how] to listen.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**Good man, come in (litenter) without any apprehension (visrabdham, lit. confidently).You will get a list ener as also a knower.

** Spy‚Äî**Here I enter. (Having entered and approachet) May the Revered one be victorious.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî** (Observing, to humself) How ! this is Nipunaka appointed for knowing in all details (or fully, prƒÅn-prƒÅne) the minds of the subjects. (Aloud) Good man! Welcome [to youj sit down.

** Spy‚Äî** As the Revered one commands. (Sits down on the ban floor)

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî** Good man! Now give (lit. describe) the accounts of the duty you were entrusted with (sva-niyoga). Are the subjects entertaining affection for V·πõ·π£ala?

** ‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§π ‡§á‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á‡§£ ‡§ñ‡•Å ‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•Å ‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§∏‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∏‡•Å ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ó‡§π‡•Ä‡§¶‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§è ‡§¶‡•á‡§¨‡•á ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¢‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§ì ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§ì‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Å ‡§â‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§è‡§§‡•ç‡§• ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∏‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§π ‡§™‡§¢‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡§ø‡§£‡•á‡§π‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§§‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§£ ‡§∏‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ [‡§Ö‡§• ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•É‡§¢‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡•á‡§Ω‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§π ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§π‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∏‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡•§]

‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî (‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç)39… ‡§® ‡§∏‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•§”) ‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∏‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡§É‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§ï‡§π‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§£‡§ø‡§Ö‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§Ü ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§£‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ [ ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡•§]

‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§∏‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã‡•§ ‡§™‡§¢‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•á ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã ‡§ñ‡§µ‡§£‡§ì‡•§ [‡§∂‡•É‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§£‡§ï‡§É‡•§]

‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî(‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§£‡§ï‡§É‡•§

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** Spy‚Äî** What (else)? On the various causes of disaffection having been removed by the Revered one, the subjects are firmly attached indeed, to His Majesty Candragupta, with a well‚Äîinvoked name. But, there are in this city three persons, with affection and veneration for Minister RƒÅk·π£asa produced (in their minds) from even earlier days (lit from the first or beginning), who cannot bear the prosperity of His Majesty, with the lustre of the moon.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî** (in anger) It should be said, indeed, that they cannot bear their own life. Good man! are (they ) known (to you) by their names?

** Spy‚Äî** How can they be reported to the Revered one, if [they be] not known by their names?

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî** In that case, I wish to hear (the same).

** Spy‚Äî** May the Revered one listen To Begin with, there is the K·π£apa·πáaka (Jaina friar) with partiality engendered (in his mind) for the side of the enemy of the Revered one.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**(To himself) K·π£apa·πáaka with partiality engendered [in his mind] for the side of our enemy?

** ‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ40 ‡§ú‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∏‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡•§ [‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ) ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§É‡•§ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡§É‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ö‡§µ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•ã ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡•ã ‡§∏‡§Ö‡§°.‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•§ [‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§µ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§∂‡§ï‡§ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**(‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ41 ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ì ‡§µ‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ö‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ö‡§Ö‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§â‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§Ü‡§∞‡§∏‡•á‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡•Ä ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§£‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•§ ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡•á ‡§ï‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ï‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ö ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ã ‡§£‡§Ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡•§ [‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•ã ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡•á ‡§ï‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ã ‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§]

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** Spy‚Äî**Named Jƒ´vasiddhi, by whom that poison-maiden appointed by minister RƒÅk·π£asa, was directed against His Majesty Parvate≈õvara.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**(To himself) Jƒ´vasiddhi. This one is just our spy. (Aloud) Good [man], now (atha) who is the other (one)?

** Spy‚Äî**Revered one, the other one is, indeed, a dear friend of Minister RƒÅk·π£asa, a KƒÅyastha, SakatadƒÅsa by name.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**(Laughing, to himself) A KƒÅyastha, that (iti) (is really) a (very) small matter [lit, measure, mƒÅtrƒÅ)]. Even so, it is not proper to ignore even an ordinary enemy. By me, SiddhƒÅrthaka has (already) been specially (vi) appointed (nak·π£ipta), in regard to him, in the guise of a friend. (Aloud) Good man ! I wish to hear(the name of) the third.

** Spy‚Äî**The third too, the alter ego (lit, the second heart) of Minister RƒÅk·π£asa (is) a resident of Pu·π£papura, President of the Guild of Jewellers, CandanadƒÅsa by name. [It is] in his house (lit., in whose house), that Minister RƒÅksasa has left his wife for sefety [lit., having left as deposit, nyƒÅsƒ´k·πõtya ]and escaped from the city.

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**(‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§®‡•Ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§® ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•á42 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•á‡§®43‡§ï‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, ‡§á‡§Ö‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ó‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§¶‡§ø44 ‡§Ö‡§°‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§¶‡§ø (‡•®) ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§á‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ “)‡•§ [‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§] ( ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø)45”)

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**(‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∏‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§°‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§∏‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡§ú‡§£‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ö‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡•á‡§∏‡§£‡•á‡§£‡§ø‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§™‡§∞‡§ß‡§∞‡§™‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§Ö‡§£‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á‡§£ ‡§á‡§Æ‡§ø‡§£‡§æ ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§™‡§°‡•á‡§£ ‡§π‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§Ü‡§∞‡§∏‡•á‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§£‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡§Ç‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡•ã‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§™‡§°‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ö ‡§™‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§¶‡§æ‡§á‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§á‡§¶‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ [‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•É‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡§ú‡§®‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ü‡•á‡§® ‡§π‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞-

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**(To himself) To be sure [CandanadƒÅsa must be] the best friend [of Minister RƒÅk·π£asa]. Minister RƒÅk·π£asa will not leave his wife for sefety with those who are not as worthy (sad·πõa≈õa) as himself. (Aloud) Good [man], how (is it) known (by you) ’that by Minister RƒÅksasa (his) wife has been left for safety in the house of CandanadƒÅsa?

** Spy‚Äî**Revered one, this signet-ring will enable the Revered one to ascertain the whole matter.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî** (Observing the signet-ring, taking the same, reads thevname of RƒÅk≈üasa. With foy, to humself) Indeed, it must be said that RƒÅksasa himself has been enamoured (prarayƒ´ samv·πõitta·∏•) of the fingers of our hand (i.e. has fallen into our clutches). (Aloud) Good [man], I wish to hear (the account) of (your securing the ring at length (in full).

** Spy‚Äî**May the Revered one listen. To start with, (tƒÅvat) appointed by the Revered one to find out the behaviour of the citizen-folk, I, wandering about with this Yama-chart, not likely to be looked at with suspicion by others, while entering

**CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**What (happened) then?

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§® ‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ [‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§] ( ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É )

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§µ, ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§µ‡•§

(‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø) **‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø, ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

excitement of restraining the boy, fell down at the door-side and having bounced again (and) without being known by her at all (eva) having come close to my feet became still (lit., motionless) like the bride from (i.e. born and brought up in) a noble family [who remains steady after having bowed before elderly persons]. By me too, as (iti) it has the name of Minister RƒÅk·π£asa inscribed [on it], it has been brought into the vicinity (m≈´lam) of the Revered one’s feet. This then is the [account of my] securing this (signet-ring).

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**Good [man], (the account) has been heard (by me). (Now) retire. Before long (nacirƒÅt) you will get a reward (lit.fruit) worthy of this labour (parn-srama) [of yours].
