** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡•§ (‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡•§)50 ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡§® ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•§”)

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**(‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡•á‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ã ‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•§

(‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø) **‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‚Äî**‡§ú‡•á‡§¶‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã‡§Ç51‡•§ [ ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã52 ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§É‡•§(‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§∂‡•ã‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

** ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã, ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•Å‡§°‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§Æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§£‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ö ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§á‡§Ö‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ö ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§á‡§Ç‡§Ü‡§á‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§£ ‡§™‡§°‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ [‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§≠‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§]

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**Dear boy, bring an ink-stand and a piece of paper.

(The pupil does accordingly)

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**(Taking the piece of paper, to himself) What should I write here? With this letter (lit writing) indeed, is victory over RƒÅksasa to be secured.

(Entering) Pratƒ´harƒ´ (Female door-keeper)‚ÄîMay the Revered one be victorious !

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî** (With joy, to humself) Accepted is the word of victory. (Aloud) ≈öonottarƒÅ, what [is] the purpose of [your] arrival?

**Pratƒ´harƒ´‚Äî**Revered one, His Majesty with a moon-like lustre having placed on [his] folded bands with the shape of a lotus-bud, requests the Revered one; Permitted by the Revered one, I wish to perform the obsequies (lit., rite pertaining to the yonder world) of His Majesty Parvate≈õvara. And I would [like to] give as a gift to the BrƒÅhma·πáas the ornaments worn by him before’.

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§≤, ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§π ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§ø‡•§ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§∂‡•ã‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á, ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§≤‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§

**‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É‚Äî**‡§ú ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ [‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§] (‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡•§)

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§µ,‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡§É ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø53 ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§54 (‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§)

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî** ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡•§ (‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§Ü‡§É ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§â‡§™‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‚Äî

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**(Withjoy, to himself) Fine ! ‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

be read out by some one personally to some one else, wait on me. And to him (≈öaka»õadƒÅsa) it should not be made known that CƒÅ·πáakya is causing (the letter) to be written out,‚Äù

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ã‡§∑‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§ö‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§∑‡•Å60 ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∂‡§ï‡§ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø61‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç62 ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ (‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•á) ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡•§

** ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡§É‚Äî**‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ [‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§µ, ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§µ‡•§

(‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø) **‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî** ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§≤‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§£‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§ï‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§è‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§63

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**To begin with, going to the place of execution, the executioners should be made to understand the sign in the form of the contraction of the right eye in anger. Then after they have understood the sign and run in this direction and that, on the pretext (apadesa) of fear, ≈öakatadƒÅsa is to be taken away from the place of execution and helped (lit caused) to reach RƒÅk·π£asa. And from him [RƒÅk·π£asa, quite pleased at the preservation of (his) friend’s life, is to be accepted a reward. For some time, RƒÅk·π£asa himself should be served. Then while the enemies will be quite near at hand (prattyƒÅsanna), this mission is to be carried out. (In the ear), thus thus.

** ≈öiddhƒÅrthaka‚Äî**As the Revered one commands.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**≈öƒÅr·πágarava ! ≈öƒÅr·πágarava!

(Entering) **Pupil‚Äî**Preceptor, command (me).

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî** Let KƒÅlapƒÅ≈õika and Da·πádapƒÅ≈õika be instructed in our name that V·πõsala (i.e. Candragupta) commands‚Äî‚ÄòThis K·π£apa·πáaka named Jivasiddhi, who appointed by RƒÅk·π£asa caused Parvataka to be murdered through a poison-maiden, should, having proclaimed this very crime [of his], be exiled with disgrace (≈õa-nikƒÅram) from the city.’

** ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî** ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§ (‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡•§)

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏, ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§† ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§∂‡§ï‡§ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§∏ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø64 ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ó‡•É‡§ú‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§65

‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§66 (‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É)

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî** (‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ã ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•§

** ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, ‡§ó‡§π‡•Ä‡§¶‡•ã‡•§ [‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§É‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî** (‡§∏‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‡•§ ( ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§É‡•§

** ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡§É‚Äî** ‡§ó‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§¶‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∏‡•ã‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä‡§è‡•§ [‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á‡•§]

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** Pupil‚Äî**Accordingly [shall I do]. (Exit.)

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**Dear boy wait, wait [lit, stand, stand]. This other one viz. the KƒÅyastha, ≈öakatadƒÅsa by name, who appointed by RƒÅk·π£asa ever (nityam) tries hard (pra-yatate) to injure, ou personr (i.e. is plotting against our life)-he too, having proclaimed this crime, should be impaled on the stake. And the people at his house (i. e. members of his family) should beput into prison.

** Pupil‚Äî**So [shall I do].(Exit.)

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**(Gesticulaing anxiety, to himself) How I hope(apa-nƒÅma) that the evil-souled RƒÅk≈üasa could be taken(i.e. captured).

** ≈öiddƒÅrthaka‚Äî**Revered one, has been taken.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**(With Joy, to himself) Oh joy! RƒÅksasa has (already) been taken. (Aloud) Good [man], who [do you say] has been taken here?

** ≈öiddƒÅrthaka‚Äî** (Here) has been taken the message of the Revered one. I shall therefore set out for the accomplishment of the mission [entrusted to me].

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ) ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É‡•§

** ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡§É‚Äî**‡§§‡§π‡•§ [‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§] (‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§)

(‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø) **‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§ (‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§π ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§á‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî** (‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç)

‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§≠‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•á ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§ø ‡§ú‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏67‡•§
‡§£‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§∏‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§â‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§π68‡§ú‡§æ‡§¶‡§¶‡•ã‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡••‡•®‡•ß‡••

[‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡••‡•®‡•ß‡••]

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**(Having handed over the letter along with the signe-tring) (May you) go. May there be success in your mission,

** SiddhƒÅrthaka‚Äî** So (shall I do). (Exit)

(Entering) **Pupil‚Äî**Preceptor, KƒÅlapƒÅ≈õƒ´ka and Da·πádapƒÅ≈õika request the Revered one here the command of His Majesty Candragupta is (i.e. will soon be) carried out.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî** Good ! Dear boy, I now wish to see CandanadƒÅsa President of the Guild of Jewellers.

** Pupil‚Äî**So [shall I arrange]. (Exit. Entering with CanadanadƒÅsa) This way, this way, President of the Guild.

CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî(To himself)‚ÄîOn the part of even an innocent person] called suddenly by CƒÅ·πáakya, (there arises) apprehension (sa·πÖkƒÅ), what (greater reason is there) then (of fear arising) on the part of me, in whose case there has been a crime [committed]?

‡§∏‡§æ ‡§≠‡§£‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§è ‡§ß‡§£‡§∏‡•á‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§£‡§ø‡§Ö‡§£‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡§∏‡•á‡§†‡§ø‡§Ü ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§π‡§¶‡§ì ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§π‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§£‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡•á‡§Ö ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§£‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§ß‡§∞‡§Ö‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§π ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§π‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§π‡•ã‡§¶‡•Å ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ [‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ß‡§®‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§§‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§§ ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§]

** ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§á‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§É‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§Ö‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø [‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§] (‡§â‡§≠‡•å ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§É)

** ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**(‡§â‡§™‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø, ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Ä ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§ú‡•á‡§¶‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã‡•§ [‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**(‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®69 ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§£ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø70 ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã ‡§ú‡§π ‡§Ö‡§£‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ã ‡§â‡§µ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ö‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ ‡§á‡§π ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á‡§µ ‡§â‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§è ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§è ‡§â‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ [‚Äî‡§ï‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§â‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ò‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§π‡•à‡§µ‡•ã‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§]

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

Dhanasena and others, staying at my place of residence were, therefore, told by me, The accursed (hataka) CƒÅ·πáakya would [have a] search [in the] house, any time [ he wants]. Being careful, therefore, [safely] take cut members of the family of [my] master RƒÅk·π£asa. As for myself, let what [ever] happens, happen!

** Pupil‚Äî**O President of the Guild, this way, this way.

CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî Here I come.

(Both walk round.)

** Pupil‚Äî**(Approaching) Preceptor, here is CandanadƒÅsa, the President (of the Guild).

CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî May the Revered one be victorious.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**(Gesticulating seeing) President [of the Guild], welcome to you. May this seat be accepted [by you].

CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî(Bowing) Does not the Revered one knowthat unmerited courtesy causes pain to the heart [greater even]than an insult? I shall, therefore, sit here only on the ground [as is] proper [for me].

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§71 ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•à‡§É ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§è‡§µ‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî** (‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§â‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§£‡•á‡§£ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡•á‡§£‡§ï‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡•§ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ [ ‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø‡•§ ‚Äî‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§] ( ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§â‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É)

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî** ‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§É‡•§72

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ã ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§£‡•Ä‡§ì‡•§ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§Ö‡§π ‡§á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡§æ‡§è‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡•§ [……‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§É ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§É‡•§…‡§Ö‡§• ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§® ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§É‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî** (‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•å ‡§™‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø ) ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç‡•§ [‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§≠‡•Ç‡•§]

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**O President [of the Merchant-Guild] do not do not [say] so. This is only (eva) in keeping with ordinary courtesy (sambhƒÅvita) [ and such as ought to be shown ] by per sons like us to your honour. Let, therefore, the seat itself be occupied [by you].

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî**(to himself) Something has been [lit, throwa in i.e.] insinuated by this wicked one. (Aloud) As the Revered one commands. (Sits down.)

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**O President [of the Merchant-Guild] CandanadƒÅsa, do the interest and profits of [your] excellent (mercantile) dealings, get themselves well (pra) accumulated ?

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî** (to himself) Excessive regard is what ought to be dreaded. (Aloud) Yes (lit, what else?). Uninterrupted (is) my trade, (proceeding) by the favour of the Revered one.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî** Do indeed the faults of Candragupta not cause the subjects to remember with regret the excellences of the former lords of earth?

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî**(Closing Tus ears) Let evil be averted.

[‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§∂‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£
‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§É‡••‡•®‡•®‡••]

‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî ‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡•ç, ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§É‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî** \‡§Ü‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã [‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç74 ‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ö‡§Ç ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã ‡§ú‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Ä‡§Ö‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ [‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§]

**‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡•ç, ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶ ‡§® ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•á‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ß‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂ ‡§è‡§µ‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî** (‡§∏‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, ‡§Ö‡§£‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§π‡•Ä‡§¶‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡•§ [‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§]

**‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡•ç, ‡§∏ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É?44 ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ö‡§•‡§µ‡§æ (‡•®)… ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡•§”)

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

The subjects are really all the more delighted by the king with the lustre of the moon, as by the full moon risen up on an autumnal full-moon night.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**O President of the Merchant-Guild, if (it be) so kings wish [to have]from subjects whe have been gratified, a gratification in return.

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî**May the Revered one command-what and how much is expected from this person (i. e. myself).

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**O President [of the Merchant-Guild]this is Candragupta’s rule (or kingdom), not (that) of NandaFor, of Nanda fond of wealth, did acquisition of (lit., connection with) Wealth cause gratification Of Candragupta. however, Just the absence of affliction of you is, the cause of gratification ].

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî** (with joy) Revered one, I have been favoured.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**O President \of the Merchant-Guild and how does that absence of affliction manifest (itself)?‚Äî thus. I say (nanu), we deserve to be asked by your honour.

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§Ü‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã‡•§) ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™‡§§‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ø[‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§75

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§â‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡•ã ‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Ä‡§Ö‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ [‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§ï‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§µ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•å ‡§™‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø) ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç76 ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§76 ‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡•ã ‡§§‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§£‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•ã‡•§ [‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§É‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§É‡•§‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ö‡§Ç ‡§è‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§£‡§Æ‡§ø‡§£‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§£77 ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ [‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§® ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§]

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî** May the Revered one command.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**To be brief (saviksepatah), by attitudes not opposed to the king.

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî** Revered one, who again is the unfortunate one, known by the Revered one to be opposed to the king?

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**Just (eva) your honour, to start with (prathamam).

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî**May the evil be averted, may the evil be averted. What kind of opposition (could there) be on the part of blades of grass with fire?

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**Here is the opposition of this kind. That you are protecting even now the family-members of minister RƒÅk·π£asa, having taken them to (and given them shelter in) your house.

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî** Revered one, this false (report) has been given to the Revered one, by some one who does not know things well (anabhijna).

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§É ‡§ö‡•å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§É ‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§78‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§¶‡§® ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§è‡§µ ‡§£‡•á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§è ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§ò‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§ò‡§∞‡§Ö‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡•§ [‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•á ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§ú‡§® ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡•á‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§è‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ö‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ü‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ [ ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§õ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§∂‡•ç‡§õ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§≤ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**O President [of the Merchant-Guild], enough of apprehension (ƒÅ-sumakƒÅ). Officers of former kings, full of fear, [do] flee to another country, having kept members of their families in the houses of citizens, even when the latter are unwilling (to give them shelter). After that, a concealment of those [persons], becomes the cause of a crime.

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî** It is just thus. At that time, there were the family members of minister RƒÅksasa in our house.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**First [what I said was]false, now [you own the members of the family of minister RƒÅk·π£asa] were [there in your house]‚Äîthese two statements (are) mutually contradictory.

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî**Just to this extent, there is a trickery of words (or dishonest statement) on my part.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**O President [of the Merchant-Guild], while Candragupta is [the ruling] king, there would be no indulgence [shown] at all (a-parigrah) to trickeries. (Do you), there. fore, hand over the family members of minister RƒÅk·π£asa. Let there be no trickery on the part of your honour,

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§•‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ó‡§§‡§É‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî** ‡§£ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ [‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî** (‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ) ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•§ ‡§≠‡•ã ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡•ç, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡•á79 ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É (‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•ã‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§≤‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** CandandƒÅsa‚Äî**Revered one, I am indeed requestfully state (yi-jnƒÅpayƒÅmi) ‘at that time there were the family-member minister RƒÅk·π£asa in my house.’

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**Then, where are they gone now

** CandandƒÅsa‚Äî**I dont’ know.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî** (Smiling) How indeed is (that) not known O President [of the Merchant-Guild], [there is] danger of (your) head, (while) very far off (is its) remedy.

** CandandƒÅsa‚Äî**(to himself)

Over [the head ] (there is) a deep rumbling of the clouds (while) the beloved is far away. What has here (lit, chis) befallen? On the Himalayas [there are ] wonderful (lit., celestial, heavenly or divine) medicinal herbs [while right over] the head is the serpent well established (samƒÅvr·π£·π≠a·∏•)

** ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§54 (‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø, ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§£‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§£‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§π‡§π‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§•‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

The Sovereignty, which, moving now and anon, was not then‚Äìwhile yet Nanda was alive, caused to be steady by competent ministers, VakranƒÅsa and others (at once) valorous and adept in polity‚Äîthat (sovereignty) which has now got itself concentrated in one (place), gladdening the (whole) world,‚Äîwho would be busy separating from king Candragupta, like the lustre (of the moon) that has gathered in one place and is giving excessive delight to the (whole) world, from the moon? Moreover, (recites 1, 8 ‘ada adita… ’ uttered previously)

(A trumult behind the screen.)

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**SƒÅr·πágarava, let (what) this (is) be ascertained.

** Pupil‚Äî**As the Revered one commands(Going out and entering again) Preceptor, here is Ksapa·πáaka Jivasiddhi, act in a way harmful to the king, being exiled with disgrace (nikƒÅram) from the city, at the command of His Maje Candragupta.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**A Ksapa·πáaka alas Or, let him sutter consequence of an attitude of harmfulness to the King. President [of the Merchant-Guild], thus is this king dea

** ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§83 (‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø, ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§∂‡§ï‡§ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Å‡•§ ‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ö‡•§

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

severe punishment to those who have an attitude full of harm [towards him]. Let the counsel (lachah) of a friend (su-h·πõd), therefore, be carried out. Let the family members of RƒÅk·π£asa be handed over. Let the favour of the King (which is indeed) variegated (i.e. diverse in nature) (ncitra) be enjoyed, for long

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî**Members of minister RƒÅk·π£asa’s family are not there in my house.

(A tumult, again, behind the screen)

** CƒÅnakya‚Äî**≈öƒÅrngarava, let (it) be ascertained (as to) what this (is).

** Pupil‚Äî**Accordingly [shall I do]. (Saying so, goung out, (and) entering again) Preceptor, here too, just one causing harm to the King, the scribe ≈†ika»õadƒÅsa, is being led for being impaled on the stake.

** CƒÅnakya‚Äî**Let (him) experience the consequence of his action. President, this king who thus meets out severe punishment to those given to what is injurious to the king, will not tolerate the concealment of RƒÅk·π£asa’s wife on the part of your honour. [Do you j, therefore, protect with another’s wife, your wife as also life.

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø ‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡•á ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§ò‡§∞‡§Ö‡§£ ‡§£ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ã ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§â‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•§ [‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§≠‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡•á‡§Ω‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî** ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¢‡•§ ‡§è‡§∏‡•ã ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§£‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ì‡•§ [‡§¨‡§æ‡§¢‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å, ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡•§

‡§∏‡•Å‡§≤‡§≠‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡•á‡§∑‡•Å84 ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡§É‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî** ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¢‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ [‡§¨‡§æ‡§¢‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî** (‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç, ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§®‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§É‡•§86

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî** ‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§£‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§¶‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§£‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ø‡§Ü‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡•§ [‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§]

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî**Revered one, do you [seek to] frighten (bhayam darsrayasi) me? I would not hand over the family members of minister RƒÅk·π£asa [to you] even if they were in the house, how far (less posible is it) again (that I would hand them over) when they are not there?

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**CandanadƒÅsa, is this your resolve?

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî**Yes, this is my firm resolve.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî**(to himself) Well, CandanadƒÅsa, well done.

When the acquisitions of the desired objects (or wealth, artha) are easy to secure, on surrendering another, who would do this, difficult to carry out, excepting ≈öibi, now.

(Aloud) CandanadƒÅsa, is this your resolve?

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî**Yes.

** CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî(**With anger) Evil-souled one, wretch of a merchant, wait (lit., stand). Let the wrath of the king be experienced.

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî**I am prepared. May the Revered one carry out (what is) in keeping with his authority.

** ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§®‡•ç, ‡§á‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§É‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, ‡§Ö‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ (‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§Ü ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á‡§£ ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§£ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§¶‡•ã‡§∏‡•á‡§£‡•§ [‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ã ‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡•á‡§£‡•§] (‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§π ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É)

‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî(‡§∏‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß ‡§á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‡•§ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡•§

** CƒÅnakya‚Äî**≈öƒÅr·πágarava, let KƒÅlapƒÅ≈õƒ±ka and Da·πádapƒÅ≈õika be told in our name‚Äî ’let this wretch of a merchant be quickly taken into custody.’ Or, let (that) wait Let VijayapƒÅla, the (one appointed as) protector of the fort be told ‘having well bound this one, with property confiscated (and) accompanied by (his) son and wife, guard this one till the moment that [the matter] is reported to V·πõ·π£ala. Vrsala himself will issue an order regarding the punishment of this one that will deprive him of his life.

** Pupil‚Äî**As the Preceptor commands. This way, this way, President [of the Merchant-Guild]

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî**Revered one, here (do) I come. (To himself) Fortunately, my total destruction (is taking place) on account of the work [in the interests of or], entrusted by a friend and not on account of a personal crime [on my part].

(This over, walking about exit with the pupil.)

** CƒÅnakya‚Äî**(with joy) O joy, secured now is RƒÅksasa. Why?

Just as this one (CandanadƒÅsa) is giving up his life, like something disagreeable, in his (i.e. RƒÅksasa’s) calamity, so in that manner surely, life [would] not [be]dear to him (RƒÅksasa) either (api), in the calamity of this one(CandanadƒÅsa).

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï, ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§É‡•§ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç); ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§ (‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏, ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡•§

ACT II

(Then enter a snake-charmer)

** Snake-charmer‚Äî**Those who know the use of antidotes (tantra-yukti) [also punningly, the application of the science (of administration)], those who draw the (magic) circle in the proper manner [also punningly, draw i.e. keep in its proper position the Ma·πádala (of kings)] (and) those who are intent on the preservation of spells, [also punningly, are intent on guarding (secret) counsels], move the vicinity of [also punningly, wait upon] serpents and overlords of men (respectively).

[Directing his eyes up] (in space) Noble one (or Sir ), what do you say‚Äî‚Äòwho are you?‚Äô Noble one, I (am) indeed a snake-charmer, Jƒ´r·πáavisa by name. What do you say ‘I too wish to play with the serpent’? Now, what profession again do you have for your means of livelihood? What do you say‚Äî I am a servant at the king’s house (hood) ? Well (in that case), the noble one is playing with a serpent already (eva) How possibly? snake-catcher not skilled in magic-spells and medicinal herbs, one who mounts an intoxicated elephant

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

and a king’s servant who has secured (a position of) authority and is priding on his success, all these three without exception (api) certainly experience utter (vi) destruction (nƒÅsa). How, no sooner was this one seen than did he go away? (Again) (directing his eyes in space) Noble one, what do yoa say what [is there] in these baskets and caskets?’ Noble one, (there are in them) serpents who help (me) earn (my) livelihood. What do you say‚Äì ‚ÄòI wish to see (them)‚Äô? May the noble one be pleased. This indeed is no (proper place (for showing the serpents). In that case, may the noble one go. As for me again there as entrance on account of the favour (thanks to the good offices) of (my) means of livelihood. How?‚Äìthis one also has gone away? (To himself‚Äìresorting to Sanskrit) Oh wonder! Beholding Candragupta well (pari)

supported (grhƒ´ta) by CƒÅnakya’s intellect, I consider the effort of RƒÅk·π£asa (to be) void of fruit, as though. Looking at Malayaketu, well backed up by RƒÅk·π£asa’s intellect, I regard Candragupta (to be) dislodged from his position of suzerainty, as it were. Why (do I say so)?

I consider the Sovereignty of the Maurya king to have her.form (m≈´rti) tied down by the intellect of Kau·π≠ilya At the same time (api), I see her being dragged away as though by RƒÅk·π£asa with (his) hands in the form of (political) expedients (upƒÅyar·∏•).

Thus then in the conflict of these two competent (su) ministers possessed of (great) intellect, the Sovereignty of the Nanda family, is as it were in doubt.

Between these two eminent (mukhya) ministers, extremely (bh·πõ≈õam) opposed to each other, by the (Goddess of) Sovereignty, terrified (bhƒ´tayƒÅ), is being experienced [a con·π£iderable amount of ] worry (khidyate), to be sure on account of goings and comings (to and fro), through indecision as (eva) is experienced (a considerable amount of) worry, by a female elephant, terrified, in a big forest, on account of comings and goings (to and fro) through indecision, between two forest-elephants, excessively opposed to each other.

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

With the vast (vipula) family of the Nandas, like that of the Vrsnis, with (their) enemies laid low (sƒÅnta) by the operation (vyƒÅpƒÅra) of the qualities of policy (nƒ´ti) and bravery, having been led to destruction by pitiless fate (niyati), that same devising (racanƒÅ) of various measures (acts), on the part of me (keeping) awake by night and by day, with (my) mind all too perturbed (samƒÅkula) on account of entrance (into it) of anxiety, (now) remains, without (any) bacground (bhatti) like the activity of drawing a painting without (the requisite) wall (or canvass).

Or,

‡§® ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç
‡§∏‡•Å‡§ó‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç125 ‡§®‡•É‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§§‡§µ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡••‡•ß‡•¶‡••

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** Priyamvadaka‚Äî**Here [is] the seat. May your honour sit down. (Exit)

** Chamberlain‚Äî**(Sitting) Prince Malayaketu requestfully conveys to the Minister. ‘My heart is pained as (iti) the Noble one has since long given up the customary (or proper) decoration of his body. Though the (excellent) qualities of the master cannot at once (sahasƒÅ) be forgotten, it behoves the Noble one to grant (lit, honour) my request. (With these words, showingthe ornaments) It behoves the Noble one to put on these ornaments sent, having been taken off from his person, by the Prince.

** RƒÅksasa‚Äî**Noble JƒÅjali, may the Prince be requested at our instance. Due to the extreme attraction of (lit, partiality for) your honour’s merits, the excellent qualities of the Master have been forgotten altogether (or already,‚Äì ‘eva’). But

I shall not wear even the slightest decorative arrangement on these limbs [of mine] devoid of valour, [and] miserable (krpana) on account of being subjected (ƒÅkrƒÅnti) to humiliation [at the hands] of the enemy, till the time (tƒÅvat) that (yƒÅvat) O best of men, this throne of you, fashioned out of gold, with the entire (nui≈õ≈õe·π£a) circle of the enemies destroyed, is not set up in the SugƒÅ·πága palace.

** ‡§ï‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•Å‡§ï‡•Ä‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§∞‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§≤‡§≠‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Ø‡§É‡•§

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á126 ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡•§

** ‡§ï‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•Å‡§ï‡•Ä‚Äî**(‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø)‚Äî‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á‡•§

(‡§ï‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•Å‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É)

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§ï, ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É‚Äî** ‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ [‡§Ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§] ( ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ) ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ [‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§]

** ‡§Ü‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§É‚Äî** ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶, ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ì ‡§ú‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ã‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§¶‡•ã ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡•á‡§≤‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ [‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ã‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•§ ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§É ‡§ñ‡•á‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§]

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** Chamberlain‚Äî**With the Minister as the leader, all this is easy for the Prince to get. Let, therefore, the first request of the Prince be granted.

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî**Noble one, like the Prince, your honour too is one whose words should not be transgressed. Let, therefore, the command of the Prince be carried out,

** Chamberlain‚Äî**(Gesticulating putton on of ornaments) Prosperity to your honour I shall go [now].

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî**Noble one, I salute [you].

(Exit Chamberlain.)

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî**Priyamvadaka, let it be ascertained as to (iti) who waits at the door with the desire of seeing us.

** Puru·π£a‚Äî**As the minister commands. (With these words, walking round (and) seeing the snake-charmer) Noble one, [are] you?

** Snake-charmer‚Äî**Good [man ], I am indeed a snake-charmer, Jir·πáavisa by name. I wish to play with serpents in the presence of the minister.

** ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É‚Äî**‡§ö‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§ú‡§æ‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§£‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ (‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö, ‡§è‡§∏‡•ã ‡§ñ‡•Å ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∏‡•á‡§¶‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ [ ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§† ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•á ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§]

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§µ‡§¶‡§ï, ‡§® ‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡•å‡§§‡•Ç‡§π‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•á127‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡•à‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

** ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§ï‡§É‚Äî**‡§§‡§π‡•§ [‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§] (‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ) ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú ‡§è‡§∏‡•ã ‡§ñ‡•Å ‡§¶‡•á ‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∏‡§£‡§ï‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã ‡§™‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ ‡§£ ‡§â‡§£ ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∏‡§£‡•á‡§£‡•§ [ ……‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•á‡§®‡•§]

** ‡§Ü‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§É‚Äî**‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶128‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§π‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§£‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡•ã‡§™‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§™‡§æ‡§â‡§°‡§ï‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ú‡§á ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∏‡§£‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã ‡§™‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§£ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§¶‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ ‡§è‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ö‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡•Å ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ [‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•Ä, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§É ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§]

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** Puru·π£a‚Äî**Wait till I inform the minister.(Approaching RƒÅk·π£asa) minister, here indeed (is) a snake-charmer (lit.,one living by serpents) (who) wishes to show a serpent.

RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî(Indicating throbbing of the left eye, to himself) how, the sight of a serpent just at the beginning ! (Aloud) Priyamvadaka, we have no curiosity for seeing a serpent. Having well gratified (the man) therefore, send him away.

** Priyamvadaka‚Äî**Accordingly (shall I do). (With thus, having approached the snake-charmer) Noble one, here indeed does the minister show favour to you with the result [sought by you] of seeing, not, however (lit, again), with seeing [the serpents].

** Snake-charmer‚Äî**Good [man], request the minister‚Äî ‘I am not only one who earns his livelihood with [ the display] of serpents [but I am also] a composer of poems in PrƒÅk·πõta, indeed. If the minister does not favour me with seeing [my exhibits], therefore, then, let him [kindly] read this leaflet (patraka).

** ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É‚Äî**(‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, ‡§è‡§∏‡•ã‡§ñ‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ó‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§â‡§°‡§ï‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ú‡§á ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∏‡§£‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§£ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§¶‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ã ‡§è‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ö‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡•Å ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ […‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§É ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§ ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§]

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø)

‡§™‡§æ‡§ä‡§£ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§∏‡•á‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§£‡•ã ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡§≤‡§¶‡§æ‡§è‡•§
‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§â‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§á‡§≠‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡§á ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡••‡•ß‡•ß‡••

[ ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡••‡•ß‡•ß‡••]

(‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç) (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§ï, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§Ø‡•à‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§É‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§129

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** Purusa‚Äî**(taking the leaf, approachug RƒÅk·π£asa) Noble (one), this one indeed requests the minister ‚ÄòI am not only one who earns his livelihood with [the display of] serpents. I am a composer of poems] in Prakrta indeed. If the minister does not favour me with seeing [my exhibits], then let him (kindly) read this leaflet.‚Äô

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî**(Taking the leaflet, reads.)

Having drunk with its skill juice in flowers so as to leave nothing as the remnant, that which the bee emits, serves the purpose of others.

(Reflecting, to hemself) Oh the purport of the verse is [I am] your spy, conversant with the happenings in [ie in possession of news from] Kusumapura. On account of [my] mind being engrossed in [the diverse] affairs [of state], and the very large number of spies, [this] was forgotten [by me] Now has been gained recollection [of the same]. Obviously (tyaktam) this’ one must be VirƒÅdhagupta in the guise of a snake-charmer. (Aloud) (Priyavamdaka, usher him [in]. This one is a good poet. From him nice words deserve to be heard.

** ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É‚Äî** ‡§§‡§π‡•§130 ‡§Ü‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ “) [‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§] ( ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ) ‡§â‡§™‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•§ [‡§â‡§™‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•§]

** ‡§Ü‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§É‚Äî**(‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ) ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§∑‡§É

‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§•‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç131 ‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§æ
‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§ó‡§æ‡§¢‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç132 ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä
‡§Æ‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡••‡•ß‡•®‡••

(‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§ú‡•á‡§¶‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡•§ [‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•§]

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§Ö‡§•‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß (‚Äì‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§) ‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§µ‡§¶‡§ï, ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§®‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡•§

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** Purusa‚Äî**Accordingly (shall I do). (With thes, approaching the snake-charmer) May the noble one draw near.

** Snake-charmer‚Äî**(Gesticulating going near, seeing, to himself) This is minister RƒÅksasa Here (is) he,

apprehensive of whose activities the Goddess of Sover- eignty, having thrown her left creeper-like arm loosely round the neck, with her face turned away, the right [creeper-like arm], though per force placed on the shoulder, falling down on the lap, now and again, does not even now place her other than the left breast, on the bosom of Maurya, in such a manner that the nipple would get itself pressed (pidita) in the (act of) a close embrace.

(Aloud) May the minister be victorious.

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî**(Seeing) O VirƒÅdha (-when the word is thus halfuttered) I say (nanu) with the beard grown [far too much is this one]. Priyamvadaha, now is recreation to be had with serpents. So let the retinue retire from here [and] rest [itself]. Do you too render your office not-vacant [i. e. do you go about your work].

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§™‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ (‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø)

** ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É‚Äî** ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø137 ‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§É ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§∏‡§ñ‡•á, ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§∞‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É‚Äî**‡§è‡§∑ ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ï‡§Ø‡§µ‡§®‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§ú‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä-

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** Puru·π£a‚Äî** Accordingly [shall I do] (Wiith thes, exit along with the retinue.)

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî**Friend VirƒÅdhagupta, here [is] the seat. May it be accupied [by you]\

(VirƒÅdhagupta gesticulates and sits down.)

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî**(Observing closely) O, this [is] the plight to which is reduced (lit., of) the one earning his livelihood by [the grace of] the lotus-like feet of His Majesty. (With these words, he weeps.)

** VirƒÅdhagupta‚Äî** Away with grief Minister ! Before long the Minister will be restoring to us our former position.

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî** Friend, describe the happenings in Kusumapura.

** VirƒÅdhagupta‚Äî**Minister, extensive [is] indeed the report of what happened in the city] of Kusumapura. Beginning from where, then, shall I describe?

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî** I wish to learn from the beginning as to what was done by assassins and givers of poison employed by us, since just the entry of Candragupta himself into the city.

** VirƒÅdhagupta‚Äî**Here I narrate. Kusumapura was, to start with (tƒÅvat), besieged on all sides by the armies of Candra-

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§ï‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ (‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§π‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

gupta and Parvte≈õvara, ≈öakas, Yavanas, KirƒÅtas, Kambojas, PƒÅrasikas, BƒÅlhƒ´kas and others, very well (pari) supported (g·πõhƒ´tƒÅ·∏•) by the intellect of CƒÅ·πáakya, as though with oceans (lit., reservoirs of water) with waters tossed on high at (the hour of the universal) destruction (pralaya).

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî**(drawing his sword, in great excitement) Oh while I am standing (i.e.alive), who would besiege Kusumapura? Pravƒ´raka Pravƒ´raka, quickly now

let rounds be quickly had round the city-wall by the bow-wielders; let a stand be taken at the gates by the elephants capable of breaking through the groups (gha·π≠ƒÅ,) of the enemy’s elephants. Let those to whom fame is highly (abhi) desirable (i·π£·π≠a), who are of one mind with me, step out with me having abandoned [all] fear of death, with the purpose of striking at the weak army of the enemy.

** VirƒÅdhagupta‚Äî**Minister, away with excitement. [it is] a past event [that] is here being described.

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî**Alas! this is a past event. By me, however, was thought (lit., known) that this is that very time. (Throwing the weapon) Alas! Your Majesty Nanda! I remember your extreme kindness (lit., favour) towards Rak≈üasa.

** ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É‚Äî**‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§∞‡§ø ‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡§π‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§ø‡§•‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡•Å‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ò‡•ã‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡§ó‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§∏‡§ñ‡•á ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

There where a (vast) collection of elephants, dark like clouds, is moving, let RƒÅk·π£asa go. Let this cavalry [part of the] army, bounding up like rolling waters, be warded off by RƒÅk·π£asa. Let the force of the foot-soldiers be put an end to by RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äìthus sending [your] commands to me, you understood on account of your affection [for me] thousand RƒÅk·π£asas to be staying in the city.

What then?

**VirƒÅdhagupta‚Äî**Then having seen Kusumapura to be besieged on all sides, when His Majesty SarvƒÅrthasiddhi, not being able to bear the very great hardship, started since long (lit, many days back), overpowering the citizens, repaired to the penancegrove having gone to the subterranean passage, out of regard even in that condition for the citizens, when your armies that had their efforts made all too slack on account of (their) separation from (their) lord, could be inferred to be dwelling in the city from (their) daring acts such as disturbances at victory proclamations etc, when you had gone out by an underground passage for once again bringing back the sovereignty (lit, kingdom, reign of Nanda, when poor Paravate≈õvara was killed by the poisonmaiden employed by you for the annihilation of Candragupta.

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî**Friend, behold the wonder !

** ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É‚Äî** ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§µ‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§ï‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï‡•á146‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•á147 ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§§‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§Ü‡§π‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É148 ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞-

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

That potent poison-maiden, capable of killing one man who was preserved by me to kill Candragupta, like the formrdable missile (sukti), capable of destroying one person that was preserved by Kar·πáa to kill Arjuna,‚Äîthat killed the Parvata-king for the extreme benefit of the wretched Visnugupta [Parvata-king who was] to be killed by Just [CƒÅnakya] himself, like [the missile that killed] the son of Hidimba, having gone to him, who was to be killed by him (Visnu), for Visnu’s extreme benefit

** VirƒÅdhagupta‚Äî**Minister, here there is a behaviour just as it pleases [on the part] of Fate. What should be done?

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî**What happened then?

**VirƒÅdhagupta‚Äî**Then when Prince Malayaketu had gone away out of fear (trƒÅsa) at the murder of his father, when Vairocaka, the brother of Parvataka was taken into confidence, and when the entry of Candragupta [to take place at.a¬∏ specifie hour] into the palace of the Nandas was publicly announced, by the accursed Canakya were addressed all the carpenters (s≈´tradhƒÅrƒÅ·∏•) staying in Kusumapura, having (first) been invited (by him); at the instruction of the astrologere, Candragupta’s [state] entry into the palace of Nandas would take place at the midnight hour. Let the palace, therefore, be decorated

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§∏‡§ñ‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§´‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡§•‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø151‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ü‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡§ø ‡§¨‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§É‡•§152 ‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§É‡•§

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

from the eastern gate. ** ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§• ‡§ú‡§ò‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§ó‡§ú‡§µ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡§µ‡§®‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§ò‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§§‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§µ162 ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï ‡§π‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡§£‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ163‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§≤‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ò‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§®‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú ‡§≤‡•ã‡§π‡§ï‡•å‡§≤‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§ó‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§π‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï‡§É‡•§

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§ï‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç164, ‡§Ö‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§® ‡§π‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡§§‡•å ‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï‡•å ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§ï‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§æ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•á165 ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§™‡§ú‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§Ø‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É166‡•§

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî** (‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä167 ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ö‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•å‡§∑‡§ß‡§Ç168 ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§§‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§®‡§ï‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§≤, ‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡•å‡§∑‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî** ‡§∂‡§†‡§É ‡§ñ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•å ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§ü‡•Å‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§∏ ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** VirƒÅdhagupta‚Äî**He [lit, this one] was pelted to death by the infantry-folk marching in front of Vairocaka.

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî**(With tears) Alas ! we have been separated for all time (iti) from our affectionate, frined DƒÅruvarman Now, what was done by that physician Abhayadatta?

‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî(‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

** ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É‚Äî** ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç169‡•§

‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî(‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡•§

** ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É‚Äî**‡§∏ ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§≠‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¨‡§π‡•Ç‡§®‡§ó‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§§‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ß‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§

‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî(‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§π‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** VirƒÅdhagupta‚Äî**[He] was made to drink that very medicine and [as a result of that] died.

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî**(With dejection) Oh ! a great store of knowledge passed away. Now, what [is the] news of Pramodaka, appointed to [look after] the bed [room arrangement] of that [king Candragupta]?

** VirƒÅdhagupta‚Äî** The same [is the news about him] as that of others.

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî**(With excitement) How possibly?

** VirƒÅdhagupta‚Äî** That fool, indeed, having got the big store of wealth given by you, began to enjoy with a great extravagance. Then being questioned, Whence this profuse acquisition of money?’ when he made [lit. went to] many conflicting statements (vƒÅkyabhedƒÅn), by the accursed CƒÅ·πáakya was he put to death by a curious (vicitra) [way of] killing.

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî** How, evenhere we were struck adversely by Fate: Now what [ is the news about Bƒ´bhatsaka and others, appointed by us to strike against the person of Candragupta, [when] asleep, who were already dwelling within the walls of the royal residence, having come by [lit. to] the underground passage?

** ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•ã ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•ã ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§® ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§§‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡•§

** ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ó‡•É‡§π ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§µ170‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡§Æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§§‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§™‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§É‡•§

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§ï‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§ï‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ñ‡•á, ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§π‡§§‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡•§

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

** VirƒÅdhagupta‚Äî**Minister, terrible [is the ] news [about them]

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî**(With agrtation) How [do you say a terrible news? Surely [khalu] they were not known by the accursed CƒÅ·πáakya as dwelling there.

VirƒÅdhagupta‚Äî Minister, yes [ lit, what else? ]

By the evil-souled accursed CƒÅnakya who, as soon as he entered the bed-chamber, prior to Candragupta, observing minutely, came to the conclusion this place [lit, house] is having persons [staying] in it,’ as he saw [lit., on seeing ] a row of ants, gettings out from some hole, having taken [along] particles of cooked rice, was that bed-chamber caused to be burnt down. And while it was being burnt down, all [those] Bibhatsaka and others, having failed to reach the door, the way to go out [from where] was already closed, their eyes blinded [lit.,sobstructed] by smoke, being caught up in the Fire [that raged there] were destroyed on the spot [ lit, just there].

** RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî**(With tears) Alas ! Oh alas! Friend, behold the [extremely] favourable fortune [lit., wealth of fortune] of the accursed Candragupta. Why [do I say so]?

‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì

The poisonous maiden who was secretly employed by me for his destruction,‚Äìby luck was that Parvataka killed by her [Parvataka] who was to share half the kingdom with him. Those who were employed with definite purposes (parinitƒÅh) in the matter [of the use] of weapons and [deadly] medicines [lit, juices ], by just those [means] were they killed. Behold, my policies bring diverse desirable things as fruits just to the Maurya [himself].

** VirƒÅdhagupta‚Äî**Minister, even then, what has been undertaken [lit., well begun] does not deserve to be given up by any means [or, at all, ‘eva’]. Behold.

Through fear of obstacles, indeed, is [even] a beginning not made by the low [people]. Having begun, the midding ores, stop, having been struck hard by obstacles. Those with excellent qualities, being struck adversely (pratihanyamƒÅnƒÅh) by obstacles, repeatedly [lit, again and again], do not give up what has been well (pra) begun. Moreover,

Is there no pain of burden on the person of [ the serpent ] Sesa in so far as he does not throw [away] the earth [on his head]? Or is there no great fatigue [caused] to
