** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**[‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§£‡§ø566 ‡§£‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§£ ‡§ú‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•Å‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ã‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§£‡•Å‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ [‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡§ø, ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ]

** ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‚Äî**(‡§∏‡§¨‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§™‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ö‡§Ç ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§¶‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã ‡§£ ‡§¶‡•á‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç‡•§ [‡§™‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§® ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§]

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á567, ‡§Ö‡§Ö‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á‡§£ ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§£ ‡§â‡§£ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§¶‡•ã‡§∏‡•á‡§£‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§£‡•§ [‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ã ‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡•á‡§£‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•§ ]

** ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, ‡§ú‡§á ‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ú‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏568 ‡§£‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ [‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç, ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ]

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§π ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§°‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡§è569‡•§ [ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§

** ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‚Äî**‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§£‡•ã ‡§ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§£‡•á ‡§Ö‡§£‡•Å‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§è ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§π‡•ã ‡§π‡•ã‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ [ ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ]

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

**Bilvapatra‚Äî**Noble CandanadƒÅsa, you have [now] to the execution-ground. So, send away [your] family members,

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî**Dear wife, [lit. mistress of the family], now go back with the son. It is indeed not proper to follow [me], further than this.

** Wife‚Äî**(With tears) For the yonder world has my lord started, not for another country.

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî**Lady, this my destruction [i. e. death is] due to [my] duty towards [my] friend, not again due to a personal mis-conduct (dosa). Then, away with dejection.

** Wife‚Äî**My lord, if [it is] so, this is no time for the family members to return.

** CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî**Now what has been resolved [or begun] by my lady?

** Wife‚Äî**That there should be favour done to myself, by following [in death] the feet of my lord.

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á ‡§¶‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§è‡§¶‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§§‡•Å‡§è ‡§Ö‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ì570 ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•Å‡§£‡§ø‡§¶‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§£‡•Å‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§£‡§¶‡§µ‡•Ä‡•§ [ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•§]

** ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§£‡•Å‡§ó‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∏‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§ì‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§¶‡•á‡§µ571‡§¶‡§æ‡§ì‡•§ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§™‡§§ ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§∏‡•Å572 ‡§™‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§£‡•ã ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∏‡•Å‡•§[ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï, ‡§™‡§§ ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§ ]

** ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**(‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ) ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§è ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§£‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§¶‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ [‡§§‡§æ‡§§, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ]

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§, ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§¶‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ [ ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ]

** ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§£‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§£‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§≤‡•á ‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡•§ [‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§®‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡§É‡§∂‡•Ç‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•§ ]

** ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ, ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•§ [ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É, ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ]

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

CandanadƒÅsa‚ÄîLady, this [is] a bad resolve. By you is this darling little son, a boy who has not heard [anything ] about the ways [lit.dealings] of the world, to be favoured [with training ].

Wife‚ÄîLet the family-divinities, gratified, favour him. ‚ÄòDear one, [my] little son, fall at the feet of your father, [that are available to you for this ] the last (pascrma ) [ occasion].

Son‚Äî (Prostrating lmself at the feet ) [ Dear ] father, what should be done by me, now bereft of my [father] ?

CandanadƒÅsa‚ÄîSon, you should stay in a country devoid of CƒÅ·πáakya.

Bilvapatra‚ÄîNoble CandanadƒÅsa, the stake is [ready ] planted. So, be ready.

Wife‚ÄîNoble sirs [or gentlemen], protect, protect.

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á, ‡§Ö‡§¶ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§è‡§§‡•ç‡§• ‡§Ü‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡§ø‡•§‡§∏‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç573 ‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§ø‡§Ö‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ö‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§Ç574 ‡§Ö ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á‡§£ ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á‡§£‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø ‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ö‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ [ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£‡•§ ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ]

** ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§≤‡•á ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§575, ‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡•ç‡§£ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§£‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ö‡§Ç ‡§è‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ò‡§≤‡§Ö‡§£‡•ã ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ [ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•á ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§æ‡§£ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§ú‡§®‡•ã ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ]

** ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§≤‡•á ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ, ‡§è‡§∏‡•á ‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ [‡§Ö‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ‡§®, ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§ó‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ ]

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶, ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§† ‡§ú‡§æ‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ö‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ü‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§576 ( ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡•§) ‡§ú‡§æ‡§¶, ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§£‡•Å‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§577 [ ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†, ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•á…… ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§, ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•á ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ ]

** ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§§‡§æ‡§¶, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§è‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø ‡§≠‡§£‡§ø‡§¶‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•Å ‡§è‡§∏‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç‡•§ \‡§§‡§æ‡§§, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ω[‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç578‡•§ “( ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§§‡§§‡§ø )‡•§")‡•§ ]

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

CandanadƒÅsa‚ÄîLady, now why do you cry ? On the distressed relatives [lit. retinue] of those gone to the heavenly world, just gods take compassion. And [as] another [important] matter,‚Äìmy death [is ] due to [my] duty to [my] friend, not due to [any] unworthy deed. Why then do you indulge in crying on an occasion [lit., in a place] of joy ?

Vajraloman‚ÄîO Bilvapatra, take hold of CandanadƒÅsa; of their own accord, would the family-members go [back].

Bilvapatara‚ÄîO Vajraloman, here I take hold [of him].

CandanadƒÅsa‚ÄîGood [friand], wait for a moment till I emachrace my little son. (Embracing the son, smelling hem on the head) Dear son, while death is sure to take place [in the case of every one born], I am meeting [lit. experiencing my] death, while carrying out [my] duty towards [my] friend.

Son‚Äî[Dear] father, need even this be told [i.e said in so many words]? This [is] indeed our family ‚Äì[code of]‚Äìduty.

**‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§≤‡•á ‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡§£ ‡§è‡§£‡§Ç‡•§ [ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•á, ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§æ‡§£‡•à‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ] ( ‡§ö‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§≤‡•å ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç )

‡§ï‡•Å‡§¶‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‚Äî(‡§∏‡•ã‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç ) ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ, ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ö‡§ß ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•§ [‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É, ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ]

(‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§ü‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™‡•á‡§£ ) **‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§≠‡•á‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç579‡•§ ‡§≠‡•ã ‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§É, ‡§® ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‡•§

‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡§¨‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ) ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç, ‡§è‡§¶‡§Ç‡•§ [ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§]

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø581‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡•à‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•§

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Vajraloman‚ÄîOh, take hold of him.

(Both the CandalƒÅs take hold of CandanadƒÅsa)

Wife‚Äî( Beating her bosom ) Noble sir, protect, protect.
(Entering with the tossing of the curtain)

RƒÅk·π£asa‚ÄîLady no need to be afaid. Oh, oh stakemen, not indeed should CandsnadƒÅsa be killed.

He by whom was seen formerly, the family of his master, perishing as though it were the family of [his] enemy, who remained indifferent [svasthena keeping just to his own place] on the occasion of the calamity of his friends, as though were a great festive occasion, to whom his own body (ƒÅtmƒÅ), even though made the target [lit. field, ground] of insults, is dear, dear as it is to you for slaying,‚Äìround the neck of me of this description (tasya mama), let this garland of the one condemned to death, the [very] path to the world of Death, be thrown [lit. bound].

CandanadƒÅsa‚Äî(Seeing with tears) Minister, what [is] this [that you are doing]?

RƒÅksasa‚ÄîThis is indeed an imitation of a part (ekadesa) [only] of your excellent [course of] action.

** ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö, ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø ‡§á‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§Ü‡§∏ ‡§£‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡•Å‡§è ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§£‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç‡•§ [‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ]

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§∏‡§ñ‡•á, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•582%20‡§π‡§ø%20‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§É‡•§ “‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§è‡§µ ( ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ) ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§É‡•§”) ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•á‡§®‡•§ ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•§

**‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‚Äî**‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ [ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ]

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**

‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ
‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ò‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•å‡§∂‡•Ä‡§®‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É‡•§
‡§µ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ
‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§µ ‡§ó‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§É‡••‡•´‡••

** ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§≤‡•á ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§£‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§£‡§Ö ‡§á‡§π ‡§è‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§£‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ü‡§è ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§† ‡§ú‡§æ‡§µ ‡§π‡§ó‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§£‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ó‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§¶‡•ã

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

CandanadƒÅsa‚ÄîWhat has been achieved [lit done] by you rendering fruitless the whole of this great effort (pra-yoga)?

RƒÅksasa‚Äî[Dear] friend, only [my] self-interest [has been achieved]. Away with rebuking [me]. Good [friend], let [ this ] be communicated to the evil-souled CƒÅnakya.

Vijraloman‚ÄîWhat [ is the message] ?

RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî

Here am I, that one (sa), for whose sake, he [CandanadƒÅsa], though worthy of being worshipped, attained the state of being a victim of yours, condemned to death, [‚ÄìCandanadƒÅsa‚Äì] by whom, possessed of glory, has been reduced to the state of being a paltry something (atrlagkuvƒÅm nƒ´tam ) the glory of Sibi [by] protecting (rak·π£atƒÅ) at the cost of [lit. by] his own life, another, even in this Kali [age], an evil age, with the tastes of people vitiated (asat ) [and by whom ] with a pure soul has been surpassed, by good deeds, the course [ of acts ] of even the Buddha [ saints ].

Vajraloman‚ÄîO Bilvapatra, do you just taking hold of this CandanadƒÅsa, wait for a while in the shadow of this tree

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ [ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•á ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§† ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§π‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ]

** ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§≤‡•á ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ, ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§π‡•ã‡§¶‡•Å‡•§ [ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Å‡•§ ]

( ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§π ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É )

** ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‚Äî**‡§è‡§¶‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡•§ (‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§π ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø) ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ø583 ‡§è‡§§‡•ç‡§• ‡§ï‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§π ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ ‡§£‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§£‡§ó‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ö‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§™‡§°‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•§ [ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§®‡§ó‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•§ ]

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ) ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

** ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‚Äî**‡§è‡§∏‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§ú‡§ó‡•Ä‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶584‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ü‡§≤‡•á ‡§ó‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§¶‡•á‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ [‡§è‡§∑ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ]

( ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É )

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

in the cemetery till I report to revered CƒÅ·πáakya, ‚ÄòMinister RƒÅk·π£asa has been captured.‚Äô

Bilvapatra‚ÄîO Vajraloman, let [it] be so.

(With this, he goes with CandanadƒÅsa accompanied by (his) wife and son.)

Vajraloman‚ÄîMay the minister come. (Walking round with Raksasa) Is there any one [on duty] here? Just report to revered CƒÅnakya, the thundrebolt (kulasia) to the mighty mountains (kulaparvata) in the form of the Nanda family, the founder of the stability (prati·π£thƒÅpaka) of the Maurya family.

RƒÅk·π£asa‚ÄîThis too, indeed, has to be beard [ quietly ].

Vajraloman‚ÄîThat there is minister RƒÅk·π£asa captured, with his intellect and bravery brought under effective control (sariyamita), by the policy of the Revered one [CƒÅ·πáakya].

(Then enter Canakya his body covered with a mantle, with the face only visible.)

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø

‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ‡§™‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á585 ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡•Ä

** ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‚Äî**‡§£‡§Ç ‡§£‡•Ä‡§¶‡§ø‡§£‡§ø‡§â‡§£‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§£‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á‡§£‡•§ [ ‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£‡•§ ]

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç \‡•§ ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§π‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ) ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§•‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•å‡§ü‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•§

‡§Ü‡§ï‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•ã ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡••‡•≠‡••

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

CƒÅ·πáakya‚ÄîGood [man], tell, tell‚Äî

By whom has fire (snkh√Ø-lit. the one possessed flames ), tawny ( kapila ) with the mass (kalƒÅpa) of flames, (sikhƒÅ) [rising ] high (uttu·πÖga ) been bound up inthe skirt of his garments? By whom has the state of not moving [ at all ] of the ever-moving [wind] been accomplished in the twinkling of an eye [sadyah-lit-instantaneously] ? By whom has the lion, his mane, (sa·π≠ƒÅ) made fragrant (vƒÅsita ) by the ichor (dƒÅna) of elephants (an-eka-padvipa), been put into a cage? And by whom is the frightful (bhima) ocean (ar·πáava), with a number of (naika) crocodiles and sharks [or fish] been crossed with [just his ] two arms?

Vajraloman‚ÄîI say [this has been done] by the Revered one, with [his] intellect proficient in policy.

CƒÅ·πáakya‚ÄîNo, [say] not so. Say ‚ÄòBy Fate, full of hatred against the Nanda family [was this wrought].‚Äô

RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî(To himself) Here [is] KƒÅu·π≠ilya [ I wonder whether he is] evil-souled or noble-souled‚Äî

The mine of all sciences, like the ocean [that ] of gems, with whose merits, we [that are] under the influence of jealousy, are not fully satisfied.

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî** ( ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ) ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•§

‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•á‡••‡•Æ‡••

(‡§ú‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ) ‡§≠‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å587‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§π‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á‡•§

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§, ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§≤588‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§¶‡•Ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡§à‡§∏‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏, ‡§®‡•á‡§Æ‡•å589‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§≤‡•å‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•å590 ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑ ‡§è‡§µ‡•§ ‡§∂‡§ï‡§ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂ ‡§ï‡§™‡§ü‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**( ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ) ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡§ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§É‡•§
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

CƒÅ·πáakya‚Äî( Beholding, with Joy to hemself ) Ah ! Here is that minister RƒÅk≈üasa,‚Äìby whom, the high-souled one‚Äî

was subjected to worry, for long, the army of V·πõ·π£ala, as well as my mind [lit. intellect, ], with the arduous (guru) troubles of conceiving ( kalpana ) [ and carrying out plans], the cause of prolonged wakefulness.

(Removrng the screen ( of the mantle) and approaching ) O minister RƒÅk≈üasa, I, Vi·π£·πáugupta, salute [you].

RƒÅk·π£asa‚Äî(To himself) ‚ÄòMinister,‚Äô this now is an epithet bringing shame [to me ]. ( Alond) Visnugupta, [it behoves you not i. e.] please do not touch me, polluted [that I am ] with the touch of Ca·πádƒÅlas.

CƒÅ·πáakya‚ÄîMinister RƒÅk·π£asa, these [two] are not CandƒÅlas. This one indeed is an officer of the king, even seen formerly by your worthy presence, [and] SiddhƒÅrathaka by name. And this one too, the other,‚Äìhe also is just an officer of the king, SamiddhƒÅrthaka by name. And poor ≈öaka·π≠adƒÅsa too was caused by me to write that false letter of that sort, without himself knowing [it] at all.

RƒÅksasa‚Äî(To himself) By good fortune is the suspicion about ≈öaka·πõadƒÅsa removed !

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**(‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ) ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡•á,‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ

‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•á‡••‡•Æ‡••

( ‡§ú‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ) ‡§≠‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å587‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§π‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á‡•§

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**( ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ) ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§, ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§≤588‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§∏‡§ø‡•§

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**(‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ) ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡§ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§É‡•§

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**[‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø604‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏, ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§≤ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø605 ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç606%20‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É-%20‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç%20‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø%20‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø%20‡§Æ‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á%20‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç%20‡§ö‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á%20‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø%20‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç%20%7C%20‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø%20‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•á%20‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§§%20‡§∏‡•Å‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•å%20‡§≠‡•Å‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Å%20‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞%20‡§á‡§µ‡•à‡§∑%20‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É%20‡•• “( ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ) ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É- ‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§§ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•å ‡§≠‡•Å‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§µ‡•à‡§∑ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡••")‡•§

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É‚Äî**‡§≠‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§, ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§≠‡•à‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡•á‡•§

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏, ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§π‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•§

nate, niyate] of even a dull-witted counsellor [netƒÅ.‚Äìguide, adviser]. Coming to[ have] an unworthy [young king, however, a minister, even with a spotless [perfect ] policy falls, in the manner (v·πõttyƒÅ) of a tree growing on the bank [of a river ], with the resort [itself] shattered.

ACT I

The MudrƒÅrƒÅk·π£asa, like other plays in Sanskrit, opens with a nƒÅndi, as required by the rules of Sanskrit dramaturgy. As brought out by ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ, a nƒÅnd√è is called nƒÅnd√è as the divinities (who are praised) take delight in it. The relevant part of the dictum of the ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ regarding this nƒÅndƒ´ is ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§†‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ç… In the ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏, it may also be noted that the ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä is of the ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡§¶‡§æ type, where ‡§™‡§¶ is to be understood as meaning a line. The two stanzas between themselves make eight lines. Thus the‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Äin the ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ is ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡§¶‡§æ.

(1) Construe‚Äî‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§á‡§Ø ‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ? ‡§∂‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ? ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§è‡§µ, ‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç? [‡§Ö‡§π] ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§™‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§® ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç; ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§® [‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø], ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø‡§§‡•Å ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ã‡§É‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§†‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§É ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§

The stanza contains a dialogue as it once took place, according to the poet, between Lord ≈öankara and PƒÅrvatƒ´. Seeing a woman on the head of Lord ≈öankara, PƒÅrvati was astonished and therefore asked Lord ≈öankara ‚Äòwho is this blessed one on your head?‚Äô (blessed indeed she was, as she was occupying the most covetable place in the world viz., Lord ≈öiva‚Äôs head which even PƒÅrvati, though constituting half of the Lord’s ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§ü‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ form, never could, occupy; in fact PƒÅrvati‚Äôshighest claim never extended beyond the Lord‚Äôs lap). ≈öiva wanted to conceal that it was GangƒÅ [the river Ganges personified] who occupied his head and therefore, deliberately misunderstanding the point of PƒÅrvati‚Äôs question replied, ‘S’asikalƒÅ‚Äô‚Äî the moon’s digit‚Äîis on my head‚Äô. P√§rvati, still having GangƒÅ in her mind, though she knew her not by the name, proceeded to ask, ‚ÄòIs this her name?‚Äô S’iva replied ‚Äòthat is even her appellation

(‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ= appellation, the way one is called); in fact, it is well. known to you. How have you forgotten it? PƒÅrvati wated to remove S’iva’s misunderstanding regarding her question and with that in view she said, ‚ÄòI am asking [you] about the woman [there on your head]‚Äînot about the moon.‚Äô ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø=‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§™‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø, ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø and similarly ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å ‡§® ‡§™‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø=‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ï‡§Ç or ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§™‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø. Sankara who, however, was in a mood to tease PƒÅrvati, whose Jealousy was obviously roused by Ganga, continues in the vein he had on purpose started in and takes ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§™‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø to be the same thing as ‘I shall ask or inquire of a woman and ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å ‡§® ‡§™‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§øto be the same thing as I shall not ask or inquire of the (moon or) Candra’ [who, after all, is a male as untrustworthy as S’ankara himself] and, therefore, coolly says ’let ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§æ[your trusted female companion or attendant, according to another account] tell‚Äîif Candra, is not an authority i. e is not reliable [in your opinion]. S’iva thus succeeded in not allowing PƒÅrvatƒ´ to extract from hun the name of the woman on his head. The cleverness or ingenuity not unaccompanied by a desire to tease Parvati, isappreciated by the poet Visakhadatta and so he expresses the pious wish ‘may this cleverness of the Lord protect (‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç to protect) you [i.e. the audience before whom the play was being staged].

‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äîi. e., most reliable mean of knowledge. According to Indian Logic there are four principal means of knowledge: ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑, ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®, ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶, ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®. The term ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ primarily applied to these reliable means of knowledge, it is later extended to anything or any one reliable. It is in this sense that the moon is said to be no pramƒÅnu, in the eyes of PƒÅrvatƒ´.

Students of Hindu mythology are well aware how the sacred river Ganges in the course of her descent from heaven earthwards, first fell on S’iva’s head, lest the earth be pierced through by the mighty fall. The story of Bhagiratha, who practised austerities with the purpose of making the heavenly river come down and raise his ancestors who were in the nether regions, is what the poet has in view so far as ‡§ï‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç

‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§øis concerned. But the whole of it need not be recounted. The stanza contains a fine equivocation which is based on two senses of the tern ‡§∂‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‚Äî (a) ‡§∂‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡§∂‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‚Äòthe moon’s digit‚Äô‚Äîas stated by ≈öankara in reply to the question ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§á‡§Ø? The stanza describes the tƒÅndava dance which ≈öankara performed with an amount of discomfort (‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ) out of consideration (‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß) for the ƒÅdhƒÅra lit, the very ground where he danced viz the ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡§≤. Flushed with the victory that the

But the Lord knew full well that if he were to let himself go and indulge freely in the dance, the whole earth would undergo a depression (‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡§§‡§ø) under the vigorous stampings of his feet [ ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç=‡§Ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç, the term being used proleptically]. He, therefore, spared (‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§É) the earth and was content with only gentle (‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•à) treadings of his feet (‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø = ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É). So far as gesticulation, expression of feelings, was concerned, the Lord remained content with whatever (in fact) inadequate space he could get for stretching out his arms. ≈öiva, as the NatarƒÅja, has a thousand arms.‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç genitive plural of ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ·πÉ, an arm thus is quite proper. That the Lord should have shown so much consideration after having demolished the tall then formidable, if not unassailable three cities [made of gold, silver and iron] of the demons from where they had for long been harassing the people, as also the demon ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞ dwelling there, shows that the Lord, though ‚ÄòRudra‚Äô when necessary, is essentially ≈öiva or ≈öankara (‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É),‚Äîis, in other words, ‚Äòfull of the milk of human kindness‚Äô.

‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§ and ‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Øare often used, though loosely as synonyms.Technically, however, ‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç is dancing characterised

  1. 2, i ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É literally would mean that after the ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä has been recited the SutradhƒÅra or the stage-manager says ‚Äò‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø etc.‚ÄôThe question naturally arises ‚Äòwho recited the‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä ?‚Äô It has to be noted here that in fact the ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä is a remnant of an elaborate P≈´rvaranga [like that of a ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®which used to be gone through, in ancient days, before the beginning of the play proper. That was managed by a separate personnel led by the ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ of the ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó After this, entered the SutradhƒÅra of the play proper, In course of time, however, the religious ceremony of the P≈´rvaranga was curtailed and only the ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä part out of the many (‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø) that constituted the ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó was retained. This then came to be recited by the ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ and then either he or the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ï, another actor enjoying a similar status, carried on the prologue (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ) to the play. Though the ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ thus was responsible for the recitation of the pƒÅndƒ´, there is no stage direction thrown right at the beginning of the play, because (a) the ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä is, as shown above, only a part of the ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó andnot that of the play, (b) the play proper commences only after it is recited, [and perhaps even more important than (a) and (b) is the circumstance which weighed with the Sanskrit play-wrights viz.,] (c) the ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Äis a ‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ïwhich must receive the very first place in the ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø (‡§Ü‡§¶‡•å ) to be literally understood‚Äîa stage direction, ‚Äò‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§†‡§§‡§ø‚Äô for instance would disturb this, As relevant to the topio under consideration, the following may be noted: ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡•á‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ò‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡••[vide ‡§Ö‡§¨‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç and ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•Å in verses 1 and 2] and ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§†‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡••

The term ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ is thus explained:‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‚Äô and ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞defined in ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ The

stage-manager, so to say, holds the threads of the play in his hands. The name ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ takes us back to very ancient times, when a ‚Äòshow‚Äô consisted of dolls that were controlled with (the not easily visible) srrings that the person who exhibited such shows held in his hands. The term then came to be shifted and applied metaphorically of course to the stage-manager who was responsible for every thing connected with the successful staging of the play.

‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó or ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ refers to the elaborate ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó. The term thus contains a memory of prolixity that used to be. It is curious, that even after the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ was dispensed with, the term should have remained in use ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡•ç an assembly where people sit round, with the purpose of witnessing and pronouncing their opinion on a play which is being staged. In the assembly there would be the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ω duly qualified for the expert job of judging the play. The three terms ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§µ‡§§‡§ø etc. are used paranomastically (‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü) ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä as adjective qualifying ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä would mean possessed of excellent qualities such as chastity, modesty etc. But when understood as qualifying ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ science of polity, the term means possessed of the six ‚Äògunas‚Äô viz. ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π, ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®, ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§®, ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§ß‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ and ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø i. e, peace or alliance, war, (military) expedition, keeping to one’s position prepared to attack, creating differences among the enemies and resorting to a fortified place for safety, respectively. As an able ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä the

Sutradhara’s wife must have shown herself to be quite equal to the task of devising ways and means or expedients as required by the occasion (‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ). But as going with the ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ means one in which one or the other of or all the four ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ω have to be used viz, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ, ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ, ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§° and ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ i.e. (1) negotiations or persuasive efforts (2) money or bribery (3) punishment which is a severe measure and (4) breaking the camp of the enemy so as to have persons favourable to oneself in the enemy’s camp itself. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ means that the ‡§®‡§ü‡•Ä helped the ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ as his ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä to accomplish three goals of the ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ viz, ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§• and ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ. When related to ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó = ( 1 ) ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Édecay (2) ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§® neither decrease nor increase and (3) increase of what is technically known as the ‚Äò‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‚Äô for which read ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§™‡§•‡•ã‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§‚ÄòAccomplishes these three i.e, sees to it that the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Å is able to maintain the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§® or further to bring about the ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø or augmentation of these eight, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Ç or decay of the ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó being avoided.

Because of the use of ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ø‡•á and ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§É‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•á there is ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ or paranomasia in theverse, As the ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä isindentified with ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ (of ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á) there is a r≈´paka or metaphor contained in the verse. ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É qualifying ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§É shows the high esteemin which they were held in those days. 1,5.10 ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‚Äî the report goes, ‡§â‡§™ √ó ‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç passive third person singular, ‡§â‡§™‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á (present used to refer to what is going to happen in the immediate future) ‚Äòwill be eclipsed‚Äô, The dramatist is using a very clever device to introduce the main scene. 1.7. ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø on hearing ‚Äò‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‚Äô understands (‡§Ö‡§µ + ‡§á to understand) that there is an attack (going to take place), against the Maurya moon i. e. against ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§, the ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ explains. II Sources of the Play.

The verse contains an instance of the ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ as ‘anger’ is identified with ‘fire’ ( ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß ‡§è‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§É). Read ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂ X 7‚ÄîThere is also a suggestion that the Nandas were so many bamboos (‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ω) that could easily be reduced to ashes by the fire. The metre of the verse is ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‚Äî‡§Æ, ‡§®, ‡§ú, ‡§∞, ‡§ó being the scheme of the same.

[On the ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞and the retiring, having made zoom for ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø to enter, ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø whom the audience is expecting toappear on the scene, the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ or ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ of the play comes to an end (‡§á‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ ). Read ‡§®‡§ü‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∑‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡§É ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡•§ That where either the Nati as in the ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏, or ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∑‡§ï Or ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï, holds conversation with the ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ and where by means of passages relevant to their duty, they introduce the matter in hand i. e. the plot of the play, is rightly called ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ or ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ (opening). For the five different types of ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ and their definitions ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£ VI, 132-18 may be referred to. So far as the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ in the ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ is concerned, it can be regarded to be of the (1) ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï type as ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç is explained by ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç, ( 2 ) or of the ‡§ï‡§•‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§§ type,

because the ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‚Äôs wordare taken up, ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø and with the help of them, is the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂i.e. appearance on thescene of‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø achieved. 1, 7, 3, ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§∂‡§®‡•ç‚Äî‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø had vowed that he would not tie up thistuft of hair onhis head till he had destroyed the Nandas who had insulted him by driving him away from the principal seat at the dinner. The Nandas have been killed before the events of the main scene begin For the purposes of this drama, therefore, we have to understand that the destruction of the Nandas would be inadequate, till Candragupta whom ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø had installed on the throne thus rendered vacant, was safely established there. For this, the services of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏, the able minister of the Nandas, were, according to‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø. absolutely necessary. Till these were secured, there was no satisfaction possible for‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø that he had avenged himself on his enemies. 1. 8. To ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø,the one thought that was more unbearable than any other, was that while he was alive, closely watching the interests of Candragupta and personally looking after the administration of his kingdom, any one should imagine he could attack Candragupta. Entertaining a desire to attack Candragupta was inviting death, as 1, 8 shows.

(8) Construe‚Äî‡§ï‡§É ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§¶‡§∂‡•ã‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡•ã‡§£‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ ‡§∂‡§∂‡§≤‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§µ ‡§ú‡•É‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø [‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§É] ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç [‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§É] ‡§¶‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ [‡§§‡§Ç] ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø‡•§

Who desires, ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø asks to take out [per force] from the mouth of a lion (‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§É a lion) his jaw (‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ), shining as it is (‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä), while the lion has opened his mouth widely in the act of yawning (‡§ú‡•É‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ)? Who has the courage to do this? The jaw of the lion is said to have a complexion (‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ) which is red ‡§∂‡•ã‡§£ because of the blood (‡§∂‡•ã‡§£‡§ø‡§§) of an elephant (‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§¶), tasted (‡§Ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§) by the lion only a little while ago. The [white] gleaming and curved jaw of the lion is only in the fitness of things compared to the digit (‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ) of the moon (‡§∂‡§∂‡§É hare ‡§≤‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§õ‡§® ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø, with hare us his mark,‚Äîthe dark spots on the moon being fancifully conceived as a hare, among others) which too isbright and curved. Corresponding to the red hue (‡§∂‡•ã‡§£‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ) of the jaw [the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø] is the red tinge (‡§Ö‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ) of the moon’s digit at the twilight hour (‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ) [the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®],

The figure of speech in the verse is ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ for the ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§ lion mentioned here conveys the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø himself. Attacking ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§is tantamount to putting one’s own hand into the mouth of this lion. There is ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£too as the bright jaw takes on the red colour of the blood of the elephant.

(10) Construe‚Äî‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§§‡§É ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§â‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§É ‡§ï‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§≠‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø identifies himself with fire (‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§É ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É) of the forest in the form of the Nanda family ( ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ò‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É). Who dares transgress the heat of the wrath of him that is burning bright ( ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§®‡•ç ) ? Such a person obviously must be altogether deluded ( ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§É ) regarding the measure of other peoples’ and his own strength

‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§É‡•§ There is only one thing in store for him viz to meet his destruction instantaneously (‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É), like a moth (‡§∂‡§≤‡§≠) [ throwing himself into the flame of a burning lamp or fire ]. The ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø or ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Øor the maxim of the moth and the flame of a lamp, or one of the moth and fire, is quite common in Sanskrit literature. Anyone going in for an indiscreet act sure to result in his own destruction is compared to the proverbialmoth (‡§™‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó or ‡§∂‡§≤‡§≠).

The figure of speech in the verse is ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï whether we understand (1) an identification between ‡§ï‡•ã‡§™ of ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å or ( 2 ) between ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø himself and ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å, for, in either case, this identification is besed on another viz. between ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤ and the ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§® ( ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ).

1, 10 1. Repetition of the pupil‚Äôs name brings out the impulsive nature of CƒÅ·πáakya. If ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§µ does not present himself as soon as he is addressed, without giving him a moment’s time, ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø calls him again The pupil humbly submits ( ‡§®‡§®‡•Å ) that there was a cane-seat already kept ready in the hall adjoining the door. Ca·πáakya, who was all tooengrossed in state business [ and also upset at some one’s having said ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø as seen before ] failed to notice the seat provided for him and therefore had to proceed to explain the same to the pupil. He should not understand that ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø’s ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§π‡§Æ‡•Ç(inherent ) ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤‡§§‡§æ was responsible for the display of his anger a little while ago.That in the days of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ quite a large majority of ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ω must have been in the habit of venting their badtemper on their pupils is evident from the phrase ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡§π‡§≠‡•Ç‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•á ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤‡§§‡§æ. Much water has flown under the bridge since ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‚Äôs times and an ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø can ill afford to-day to have ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤‡§§‡§æ of this type towards his pupils, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§â‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø does not seento be necessary, for, some seat could certainly be provided for ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø on the stage.

The matter which has become a public property (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§É) is briefly this ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏(line 3 after verse 10) has entered into an alliance with ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å (line 4) and is ready to attack

  1. 11 CƒÅnakya compares the fire of his wrath (‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß ‡§è‡§µ-(‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§É) with a forest fire (‡§µ‡§®‡•á ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§® ‡§á‡§µ). This is not very happy ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡•ã ‡§µ‡§®‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ or ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§≤ ‡§á‡§µ or alternatively ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§≤‡§É [‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§≤] would have been better. The trouble is that now there is nothing [more] that could be burnt (‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§® ‡§ñ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç) ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø’s wrath-fire, like a forestconflagration has done the following: The face-moons of the quarters in the form of the enemy-ladies have been rendered dark by the ever continuing (‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡§§) columns of smoke in the form of grief. [Does forest-fire not emit columns of smoke and thereby render dark the moon in the quarter she has resorted to ? ] It has profusely scattered the ashes in the form of defusion, on the trees in the form of the ministers‚Äî ashes carried to the trees by the wind in the form of statesmanship (‡§®‡§Ø). [Now does forest-fire too not scatter about ashes on the trees with the co-operation of wind?] Finally, ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø’s ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø has burnt down the bamboo-shoots in the form of the scions of the Nanda-family excepting (‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç) the flocks of birds in the form of the citizens altogether confused‚Äîand bewildered (‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§). [Precisely this is done by a forest-fire in so far as it burns down bamboo-shoots, sparing the flocks of birds who fly away from

there]‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‚Äî ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ is a ‡§ö‡•ç‡§µ‡§øform. The metre of the verse is ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ (Vide 1, 1 & 2 ). The ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ in the verse is ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï in view of the identification ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß ‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Égiving rise to several others viz. ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§§‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§É, ‡§Ü‡§®‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§É, ‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É, ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§£ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É, ‡§®‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡§µ‡§®‡§É, ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§∏‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ó‡§£‡§æ‡§É‡•§

(12) Construe:‚Äî‡§Ø‡•á [‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É] ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•à‡§É ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•à‡§É ‡§∂‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É, ‡§§‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡•á‡§® ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§ú‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§µ, ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ,‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§

CƒÅnaky a means that he indulges in no idle boast. There was an occasion when people saw him dragged down from the seat of honour (‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§®)‚Äì him who was powerless or helpless (‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∂). And not only Nanda‚Äîbut the whole of his family (‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø)‚Äîhas been hurled down. The figure of speech in the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ. The following resemblances may be noted. ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‚Äî‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§É ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‚Äî‡§ó‡§ú‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞; ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‚Äî‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∞ The metre of the verse is ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§§ with the scheme‚Äî ‡§Æ, ‡§∏, ‡§ú, ‡§∏, ‡§§, ‡§§, ‡§ó (‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø, ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§ó‡§æ‡§É‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ).

(13) Construe:‚Äî ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§É ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§∂‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§á‡§µ ‡§®‡§µ ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§É, ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø ‡§®‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡§á‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ, ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø continues in the same vet to mention why he has already achieved, The nine Nandas like so many darts rankling in [the heart of the] Earth were dug out Sovereignty was made to have a firm stand in ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§, like a lotusplant in a lake. The fruit is both ‚Äòchoice‚Äô (‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç) and even (‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø) no partiality having been shown in the division.

The ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ in the verse is ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø because the order ‡§ï‡•ã‡§™-‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø is maintained in what is stated immediately afterwards ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ö. The metre of the verse is ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä with the scheme ‡§Ø, ‡§Æ, ‡§®, ‡§∏, ‡§≠, ‡§≤, ‡§ó ‡§∞‡§∏‡•à‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§≠‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä).

1,11,1 ‚Äò‡§Ö‡§•‡§µ‡§æ‚Äô is quite significant. It shows that‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø changes the line of his thought. Instead of indulging in a mood of self congratulation, he now states, ‚Äòtill RƒÅk·π£asa is secured, nothing like the uprooting of the Nanda family or the establishment of the sovereignty of ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ can be claimed to have been achieved.‚Äô From ‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Øafter (‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø), ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø proceeds to the appreciation of the merits‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏. The latter’s devotion to the family of his master is

unparalleled. Hence had poor ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø [‚Äìof the Nandafamily-] to be killed. That was a political exigency.

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•á ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‚Äìthe stage-direction indicates that ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø imagines that RƒÅksasa is standing in flesh and blood before him in space and therefore proceeds to address him with the words ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å …etc. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø isa Brahmana who has secured mastery over the Vedas. ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‚Äì Brihaspati among the ministers, wisest among the ministers, is the highest tribute that ever could have been paid to a minister Brihaspati, the preceptor of gods, is a standard of comparison in point of intellectual eminence.

(14) Construe:‚Äî‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§É ‡§ê‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡§™‡•á‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡§É‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡•á, ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§æ [ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ], ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§æ‡§É [‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ]‡•§

The majority of men in this world (‡§Ö‡§Ø ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§É) serve a master, yet in possession of prosperity ( ‡§ê‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§® ‡§Ö‡§™‡•á‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ). Such of the people as follow their master in his calamity do so out of the by no means unselfish hope‚Äîthat he would be restored to his prosperity (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§æ ). Very few (lit difficult to come across) are men like ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ who without any such hope or calculation, and on account of their attachment to the good things done by the master previously carry on the master’s work with unstinted devotion, even after his departure to the yonder world (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø lit. utter destruction). They are blessed (‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§É) indeed. The metre of this verse is ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§§.

A foolish (‡§Ö‚Äì‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û) servant who is also very nervous or apprehensive, may be full of devotion to his master. But he would serve no useful purpose. His folly and apprehensive nature mar altogether the advantage, that otherwise, his master could have had of his devotion. A servant who is distinguished for his intelligence (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ) and valour, but lacks in devotion would be of no use to the master. Those who have all the three qualities ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ, ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø risen high for prosperity, they are servants worth the name of the king. (19) Construe:‚Äî ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø [ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ] ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§π‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡§ø‡•§

1. 19. The day-lotuses (‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø) are very attractive. But their character is in no harmony with their beautiful

appearance, They are opposed to, on enemical terms with the moon, though the latter is possessed of a full orb (‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤). The pupil accompanies ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏ to the fort where he was to be given in charge of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤, the ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§™‡§æ‡§≤ i. e the protector of the fort. (1)Construe:‚Äî‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§É[ ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á] ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§™‡§ö‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§

The verse contains several terms which are paranomastic. Thus ‡§â‡§™‡§ö‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø =(1) move near [the serpents]; (2) wait upon, serve [lords of men].

‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‚Äî(1) application i. e. use of antidote [against the poison of a serpent-bite] (2) application of the science √≠. e. the principles of the science (of administration). For ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞= science, see 1, 26, 13 (‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç) and the note on the same. ‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äì(1) the circle. Those who want to be able to move in the vicinity of serpents must know well to draw the circle (within which the serpent would be entirely under control, thanks to the efficacy of the mantra or spel they know), (2) techinically this means the group of kings with their relation to each other and their relative strength or weakess well ascertained. The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Å or ambitious youngruler who aspires to be the sovereign ruler (‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç) and his minister ought to have a correct idea of this ‚Äòcircle of kings.‚Äô Thus there will be ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ and ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ on one side of the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Å while on the other there will be the ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π, the ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞, the ‡§Ü‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ and the ‡§Ü‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞, with two others viz. the ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ and the ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§®. All these with the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Åconstitute the from the point of view of the ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ or ‚Äò‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞,‚Äô Manusmrti VII, and Kau»õilya‚Äôs ArthƒÅ≈õastra‚ÄîMandaladhikara·πáa will be referred to with advantage, in this connection ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‚Äî(1) having full possession of (lit. protecting) the spells or magic formulae, a mastery over which enables one to control serpents; (2) protecting i. e. maintaining or guarding [the secrecy of] counsels (‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ from ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞to give counsel; Of ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä a counsellor minister.) Dealing with kings is both a science and an art and only those well-equipped can do so with safety. Dealing with serpents too isno easy matter and not all can do it without being injured, oftentimes fatally. The figure of speech in the verse is ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑, and its metre is ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ.

(2) Construe:‚Äî‡§ï‡•å‡§ü‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç [‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç] ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø [‡§§‡§æ] ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§

‡§ï‡•å‡§ü‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ß‡•ã‡§É (intellect) ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§É (rope) ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É (form,body) ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§§‡•à‡§É‡•§ The [royal] splendour i. e. sovereignty of ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ is having her person tied down by the rope of ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‚Äôs intellect, so that the sovereignty cannot leave ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§.But this is only one side of the matter. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ says he sees the sovereigntv being dragged by ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏by his hands in the form of political expedients (etc.), As indicated in the dissolution of the compounds above ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§É is a metaphor (‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï) giving rise to another in line 3 of the verse viz ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§ÉThe figure of speech here, therefore, is ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï.As though-‡§á‡§µ-shows that there is ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ also. (3) Construe: ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§µ‡§®‡§ó‡§ú‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§ú‡§µ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§á‡§µ [‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§É] ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á‡§É[ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ] ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§á‡§π ‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•É‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

The two eminent ministers ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ opposed to each other are likened to two elaphants from a big forest and Sovereignty is likened to a female elephant who cannot decide (‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç) to whom to resort, as both are equally strong, as she is all full of apprehension on account of either being offended if she goes over and sticks to the other]. Many are the comings and goings ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö the female elephant‚Äîand like her [the goddess of] severei-gnty has between the strong rivals and very greatly is she‚Äîalso Sovereignty‚Äîwearied‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á is an impersonal construction‚Äî ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É‡§ñ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§≠‡•É‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äòextremely‚Äô can be taken as an adverb [goiny with or] modifying ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Éas in the translation (p.46). word so far as its denotation is concerned. The dgure of speech in the verse is ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ and its metre is ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ (or ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ) with the scheme ‡§ú, ‡§≠, ‡§ú, ‡§ó (‡§ú‡§≠‡•å ‡§∏‡§ú‡•å ‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§π‡•à‡§É).

[Page-47] 2,3,1 ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É. The snake charmer (VirƒÅdhagupta) describes in the verse how due to the activities of minister ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ of course against ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ Sovereignty does not embrace Candragupta whole-heartedly even now. The verse gives a graphic description of the partial embrace The Goddess of sovereignty has placed her left creeper like arm round the neck of Candragupta (but only) loosely (‡§∂‡§ø‡§•‡§ø‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç). She has turned her face away from him. Her right creeper like arm placed on the shoulder of Maurya, per force, falle ‚àôagain and again (‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§É) on his lap. Afraid of the (political) activities ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏, Sovereignty does not place ( ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ) her right breast, with the nipple (‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç) pressed on account of ¬∑the contact ( ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó ) in a close (‡§ó‡§æ‡§¢) embrace, on ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§’s bosom.

The details of the embrace are given soas to enable the reader visualise vividly the picture The left arm placed found the neck of, the face turned away, the right arm placed on the shoulder per force dropping down again and again on Candraguta’s lap, the right breast not coming into close contact with Candraguta’s bosom so as to have its nipple pressed hard-all are clear indications of the ner. vousness of the Goddess of Sovereignty-who but for ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏’s activities would have long ago completed the act of giving a waris and close embrace to Candragupta, ‡§Ü‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§æ‡§¢‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§§‡•á‡§® or ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§É ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç - if this be taken to be the adjective qualifying.     1. 1 ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ had said ‘‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§§‡§ï‡§É‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç….. ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç (‡§Ü‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ is, therefore, mentally prepared to hear about the calamity of one more friend of his, at least (‡§Ü‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç is‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡§ö‡§®). ‚Äî3 The removal of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏’s family by CandanadƒÅsa (‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ rightly says was improper as it was opposed to ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø’s wishes‚Äî4 ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ loses no time to point out that not removingKing ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏’s wife and son, thus leaving them at the mercy of the wicked ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø would have been even more improper as it would have been nothing short of a friend’s betrayal (‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§π) 4 ‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‚Äî I would like to submit ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§É isa fine instance of ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æfor, what ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§really wanted to say was ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§É; instead he states a general proposition.‚Äî6‚Äì7 ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡§ü‡•Å‡§®‡§æ leads ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ to the only conclusion possible under the circumstances, and therefore, eagerly, excitedly asks ‘was not killed, indeed ?’ [Page 71] Though relieved to learn that ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏ was not killed, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏is not in the least ’s being thrown into the Batisfied. The rule is that no character should enter the stage unless the entrance is duly_tndioated beforehand ‚Äî‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‚Äî in the earlier dialogue between the characters on the stage. All sudden or unexpected entrances, therefore, are made with the tossing of the curtain. The tossing of the curtain is to be done by the character entering on the stage. Thus the attention of the audience is drawn to the new entrant.

Here ‡§™‡§ü‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™is absolutely necessary. 12‚Äî15 The man giv√©s ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏news that ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ never expected to have‚Äînot even in the wildest of his dreams. To turn next to a resume of this act: As the curtain goes up, there appears on the stage a snake‚Äîcharmer who speaks very highly of his means of livelihood, as it makes it possible for him to enter any place‚Äîeven such as that where minister ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ stayed. From what the snake-charmer says, the audience gathers that the goddess of Sovereignty has not been yet able to decide to whom she should stick. Like a female elephant having many goings to and fro beween two equally strong wild elephants. Sovereignty expriences many goings to and comings back from the two competent ministers ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏. At the other end of the stage, presumably, is seen minister ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏, anxious and waited upon by a man-servant, The minister is all grief, as the family of his master, even like that of the ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡§Ω has become extinct, thus rendering his political activities as meaningless or purposeless, or

better baseless, as the painting of an artist who has no canvas-board (verse 4). The only motive prompted by which the minister is busy putting various plans into prac- tice is serving the dead-master, by killing his enemies The minister is pained to see that sovereignty has of late behaved like a wanton woman, thus showing an absolute lack of the sense of appreciation. Were it not for the proverbial fickle- ness of the mind of women, explaining Sovereignity’s choice of the low-born son of MurƒÅ as her husband, would have been very difficult, he says. But the minister is bent on nipping the mischief in the bud. He has resolved to destroy the very resort of Sovereignty-viz., Candragupta.

With that very end in view did he keep his wife and son at Candanadasa’s in Pataliputra, and leave the city, so that the inhabitants of the city should have no doubt regar- ding his keenness on attacking ‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ Those in ‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ and siding with him would thus be assured of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏’s coming back soon and they would not be slack in their own efforts, ‡§∂‡§ï‡§ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏ with a huge treasury at his command has been appointed to collect assasins and poisoners who would help them kill Candragupta. Friends like ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø have been capt busy getting news from the enemy circle and effecting a breach between persons on the enemy-side thus breaking their unity. Only the invisible Fate should not wantonly interfere and shield Candragupta. With this negative co- operation from fate, the minister is confident, he would break the very vitals of the ungrateful son of his Majesty Nanda, with the shaft of his intelligence.

(3) Construe‚Äî‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•à‡§É ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•à‡§É‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡§•‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§ö‡§≤‡§§‡§æ ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§É ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§ß‡•Å‡§É ‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ä‡§¢‡§æ, ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç [‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ] ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä) [ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É]‡§®‡§µ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§É ‡§µ‡•ã‡§¢‡•Å ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§É[‡§Ö‡§Ø] ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ö ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ ‡§® ‡§µ‡§π‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§

The comparison between an experienced king and a bull used to be at the yoke (‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø) as also that between a young inexperienced king [or prince] and & raw bull. yet requiring training (‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø) is quite common In Sanskrit. Evidently, the verse is a glowing tribute to the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø and ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø of the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ who refuses to be discouraged by any number and kind of difficulties, who is bent on going straight along

the path leading to success. ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä lit. possessed of a mind i. ea very strong or spirited mind. (4) Construe.‚Äî‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡•á [ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•á ] ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§π‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø, ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É [ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ] ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É, ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§§‡§∞‡§É [ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ] ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§ [‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ] ‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç [ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ], ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§É ‡§∞‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§µ ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§

If the king is bent on carrying out other people’s work, serving other people’s interests, accomplishing his own object would naturally leave him i. e. he would not be able to achieve his own ends. If he gives up self-interest ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É, his name lord of the earth’ (‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É) would certainly be emptied of its meaning (‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‘Lord of the earth’, with ’no self-interest to speak of’ are a contradiction in terms If the king sets a higher value on the interest of others, then Oalas! (‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§), the poor person gets himself reduced to the far from enviable position of being under the influence of others (‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç= ‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡§∂‡§É). How could anyone depending on others ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ) ever know the sweet taste or relish (‡§∞‡§∏) of joy or delight ( ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø= Joy) ? The last line contains an instance of the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§® ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ And as ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ really wants to convey his owndifficult position, but instead of speaking of himself, states general propositions true of kings as a class, there is.

‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ also in the verse. This verse too is in the ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä metre.

3, 4, 1 ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‚ÄîBy those who have control over them- selves, or are possessed of‚Äò‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‚Äô a technical term of the ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ conveying one who is possessed of ‘‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ω’ and ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ω’ [ this latter explanation is based on ‡§ï‡•å‡§ü‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ itself].

(5) Construe:‚Äî[‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É] ‡§§‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç [ ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç] ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§§‡•á, ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡•å ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•á, ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø [ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•Å] ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø, ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§∞‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É [‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø] ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§§‡§ø, ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç [ ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç ] ‡§â‡§™‡§π‡§∏‡§§‡§ø, [‡§á‡§§‡§ø] ‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É ‡§≠‡•É‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡•ã‡§™‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ[‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§§]‡•§

Sovereignty (i. e. the goddess of sovereignty) and a courtezan, are according to Candragupta, very difficult to wait upon, once Sovereignty (also the courtezan has secured scope for herself, i e, has got the king or any ordinary person under her clutches, The king cannot afford to be severe or sharp, for Sovereignty is disgusted with such people. ‘Mildness’ would be no remedy against this, for, with the ‘mild’ Sovereignty (‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‚Äìlike ) stays not for long, for fear (‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏) of being insulted (‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ) by others whom the mild cannot control. She hates fools. At the same time there is no love lost between the extremely learned persons and Sovereignty. Bravery may be very commendable, nay, covetable. But (courtezan-like) Sovereignty stands in extreme awe of the brave [No one should understand ‘‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§∏‡•á or ‡§∂‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø’ as a proposition, the truth of which stands unchallenged]. Knowing the mind of either a courtezan or Sovereignty and pleasing her is one of the most difficult jobs that can be set to a man. The ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ in the verse is ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ, its metre is ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§§

(6) Construe:‚Äî‡§á‡§π ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É [‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ] ‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á, ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å [‡§Ö‡§∏‡•å] ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§É ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§É [ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ]; ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§É [ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ]; ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§É [‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É]‡•§

The preceptor (‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å) does not ward off his pupil, so long as or while the latter is building up e. carrying out a good (‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç) action. The preceptor becomes a curb [lit. the goad, used to control elephants], when through infatuation or delusion (‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‚Äìto be infatuated, to be deluded, is the root from which is derived ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π ), the pupil leaves the [right] path. This being so (‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç) good people, naturally having a liking [as well as appreciation] for good training (‡§µ‡§ø+‡§®‡•Ä to lead or train well) or discipline ( ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ø) ever are without any [artificial] curbs. No ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‚Äînocurb need be exercised against them nor would they ever complain that any is used against them. This is the maximum independ ence one can legitimately ask for A wise teacher never grudges it to his pupil. But, we [this is of course the royal type] are averse to any freedom or liberty(‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø) further than or going beyond this limit. ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ lit. with one’s face turned away from i. e metaphorically, not favourable to, averse to. ‘‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø is an abstract noun and there cannot be ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§ø’ is an objection which attaches greater importance to the science of grammar (‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞) than to the popular usage (‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡§ø). We are living in an age where ‘four freedoms’ does not any longer sound as a wrong phrase. The reading ‘‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§É’ need not be considered to be superior to those where the form ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Énot entering into a compound with another word occurs

3, 6, 1. Not that Candragupta did not know the way to the SugƒÅnga palace ‘‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§Ø’ is absolutely formal The king must have some one going before him, his harbinger. The Chamberlain is to do that here‚Äî4 ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®, ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‚Äìhere ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® is quite proper, as it is more than likely, that in’ the days of Vi≈õƒÅkhadatta, the stage was not as advanced as to have a regular staircase on it.
