The actor playing the role of Candragupta is there. fore to convey by gesticulation that he has gone up such a staircase as would obtain in a palace. The king is agreeably surprised (‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã) to see the extreme beauty of the quarters, beauty that is accumulated [as it were], thanks to the autumnal season (‡§∂‡§∞‡§§‡•ç autum, ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø season)3,7 explains the king’s remark about the beauty of the quarters.

(7) Construe:‚Äî‡§∂‡§®‡•à‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É, ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ú‡§≤‡§ß‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§É, ‡§ï‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§É, ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§ö‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•à‡§É ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§É ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§É [ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§É ] ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§®‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡•§

‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ has a penchant for ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑. In this verse primarily intended to describe the beauty of the quarters during the autumnal season, he has, therefore, used paranomastic expressions such as apply to the quarters and also rwers. (1) Thus the ten quarters are extensive (‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§É) and flow from thesky above (‡§®‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§É) i. e. appear to stretch out into space from there Rivers are long ( ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§É) and they flow ( ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ) from the month of S’rava·πáa (‡§®‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç=‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£+‡§§‡§Éa termination in the sense of the ablative ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç). (2) The quartersgradually become separate (‡§∂‡§®‡•à‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É) as they proceed further and further. Rivers have gradually become narrow in their beds (‡§∂‡§®‡•à‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É). The quarters are having sandybanks (river-like) in the form of white (‡§∏‡§ø‡§§) strips of clouds(‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§ú‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ ‡§è‡§µor ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§≤‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§É). That the autumnal clouds are white as distinguished from those that pervade the sky during the ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§ã‡§§‡•Åor the rainy season

(17) Construe:‚Äî‡§Ø‡§É ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•å‡§¶‡§Ø‡•å ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ [‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ] ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§

‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø has overcome (‡§™‡§∞‡§ø+‡§≠‡•Ç) the world and is showing (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§®‡•ç) sƒ±mƒ±ultaneously ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§É‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø ( ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ; the disappearance setting, ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ) and rise (‡§â‡§¶‡§Ø) of the Nandas and the Maurya king respectively. By his lustre (‡§ß‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§æ) he thus surpasses the ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ of the thousand lustred (or rayed) one i, e. the sun, as the latter’s lustre causes cold and warrƒ±th to fall by turns (‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•á ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®) and as it is not all-reaching ‡§Ö-‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ-‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø) While the sun cannot display both setting and rising at one and the same time, ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø has done so‚Äîshownthe disappearance i. e. brought about the destruction of the Nandas and the prosperity (‡§â‡§¶‡§Ø) of the Maurya king, at the same time. Thus is ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ωuperior to the sun. As proofs of ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø’s superiority may be noted (1) that his lustre i. e. power, or influence is all-reaching while the sun’s lustre cannot enter the caves and mountain-recesses and (2) that while ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø can cause cold (destruction) and warmth (prosperity) to be brought about the same moment [ of two parties], the sun’s lustre causes cold and heat or warmth to appear only by turns. The ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø being thus superior to the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®, ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ to that of the sun, there is the ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ in the verse‚Äî

(19) Construe‚Äî‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡•à‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ü ‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§É ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ü ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§§‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§∂‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§§‡§µ ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡•Ä‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ö‡•Ç‡§°‡§æ ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

Let the kings, prostrating themselves (or lit. bending themselves far too low ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞+‡§®‡§§) in their hundreds repeatedly come ( ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ) and render the (cavity-like portions ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§É i.e. the) interstices between the toes (‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡•Ä) of the pair of your feet (‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó) full of (‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§É) or impregnated with the rays (‡§Ö‡§∂‡•Å) of crest jewels(‡§ö‡•Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø). low in your presence as an indication of their acceptance of your sovereign position. Let them do this even always, or now and again ( ‡§∂‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§è‡§µ ). From (‡§Ü) the Lord of the Mountains i. e. the Himalayas, cool (‡§∂‡•Ä‡§§) on account of the shower of the spray (‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞) of the river of gods i.e. GangƒÅ which has stumbled into the rocks (‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§) [in the north], to (‡§Ü) the shore of the southern ocean, having the lustre (‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç) of gems of diverse colours blazing forth (‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§)‚Äîfrom this vast area with the Himalayan range as one extremity and the shore of the southern ocean i. e. the Indian Ocean as the other should kings come in large numbers and own ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§’s suzerainty. 3, 19, 1 ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ says that the wish is already accomplished, thanks to the Revered one’s favour.‚Äì 2 ‡§â‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ie. due regard being shown to the fact that ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§is the sovereign emperor as also to the other viz. that ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø is ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§’s preceptor.‚Äî3 ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø does not want to waste a minute. He prefers being businesslike. Hence the question, as direct as it could have been ‘‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É? -4’ ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ answers more in the nature of politeness, than in that of straightaway making everything quite clear ‚Äî5 ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø,therefore, points out, with a smile (quite significant evidently), that there need not be too much of such modesty (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø). After all he is the occupant of the throne and has every right to ask any minister of his‚Äîeven the Prime Minister‚Äîto answer any question, he may deem it proper to put to the latter ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ office, or a post of authority + ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç one holding a post of authority. This is evidently an ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‚ÄîI your ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä certainly have not been summoned by you for nothing, is what ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø wants to convey. ‚Äî7 ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ too grows equally business-like and asks for a plain answer to a plain question: what advantage (‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç) does, the Revered one see in the prohibition of the moon-light festival?‚Äî ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø with a smile indicating that he is amused, that first there was an attempt at desplaying modesty on the part of the king, who now has put the question which reallywas suppressed by him so far, says ’then, for being reprimandedhave we been invited, ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§•‡•Å‡§Ç lit, for reprimanding.‚Äî 9

Nothing could be further from the mind of the King, the king replies It was ouly a request he had to make to the (minister) preceptor. 10 ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ωeizes his opprotunity and says ’then such as are worthy of being requested should be allowed to have things the way they like, and their sweet will (‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§∞‡•Ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É) should never be interfered with by the pupil (this too is an ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡§æ). ‚Äî12.13 ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ does not give up the battle. Though not on that ground, on another I can justifiably put a question to the Revered one. Not a single act on the part of the noble one is without a purpose. ‡§ï‡•å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ß certainly can be no exception to this rule. 14.15 ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø accepts the compliment putting it even more clearly‚Äînot even in a dream doth ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø act withouta perpose‚Äî16‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§æ desire to her (that ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®) makes me speak (‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø) 17-19 ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø begins in quite a dignified style ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§á‡§π ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å‡§É etc. But Immediately after this, he puts it quite bluntly to ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ that ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ belongs to the class of kings whose success or victory ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø) is dependant on the minister. (22) Construe‚Äî(‡§π‡•á) ‡§®‡•É‡§µ‡§∞, ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ø ‡§á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ò‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§•‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•á‡§™‡§æ‡§É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§æ‡§É ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§µ ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó ‡§® ‡§∏‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡•§

Obest of men (‡§®‡•É‡§µ‡§∞), lords of men like you, created by the lord of creatures(‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§æ lit. creator) for some reason difficult to be understood, indescribably great (‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø)‚Äìconqueror’s by their own lustre (i. e bravery, ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®=lustre) of lords or mastere of herds of elephants [i, e. kings having herds of elephants in their possession], stores (‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ø‡§É) as though of the excellence of strength, with their self-esteem as well as pride (‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® and ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§≤‡•á‡§™ quite patent, brook not an infringement of their command (‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç). (23) Construe‚Äî‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§É ‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø; ‡§™‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§É ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

It is not by wearing ornaments (as also the royal insignia such as the crown) etc that a master [i, e. a king] becomes a master [king]. A person like you, whose order is not violated with contempt (‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ i.e. ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ or ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ó‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É] is called a master. He is master worth the name.

2, 23, 1-4 CƒÅ·πáakya at first unable to grasp the signficance of 3, 22, & 23 soon makes out that this is a device employed by ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ [to bring about a split between ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ and himself]. The tawny (‡§™‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ) lustre of the eyes (‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§É) has as though flashed forth [even like lightning flashing forth] ‚Äîthough the lustre was made [considerably] mild (‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ) on account of being washed (‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≤‡§®) by limpid (‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§≤) water (i.e. tears trickling from the eye-iashes throbbing up (‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø‡§ö ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø) in excitement (‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠) ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø’s anger made his eyes tawny, though their red appearance was made considerably mild because there were drops of tears that appeared in his eyes and flowed down the eye-lashes throbbing because of excitement. Anger and tears, some may think, go ill together. But any emotion at its highest causes tears to appear in the eyes. There was smoke presented (lit.[which] sprouted, in the form of the kuitting (‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó) of the eye‚Äîbrow (‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å) (darkness being the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ of both). ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ proceeds to describe the stamping of the foot (lit. stroke with the foot) of ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø on the earth. Of the ‡§∞‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§∏, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ß is the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ, violent movements (‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§® here) of the limbs the ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ, It has ‡§Ü‡§µ‡•á‡§ó excitement etc. as its

accessory feelings (‡§∏‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ω) and tears rolling down the cheeks as the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ. ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø displayed all these Naturally does ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ fancy (‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ) [‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á] that ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø was as though Lord Rudra himself‚Äîso did he appear to Earth, who could put up with the mighty stroke, as she had done so previous occasions. ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ=‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç (accusative) ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ. To turn to a resume of the third act As the curtain goes up, there appears on the stage the Chamberlain (Vaihinari) of Candragupta. He addresses the officers appointed in the SugƒÅnga palace and announces the command of His Majesty Candragupta to be obeyed by them. ‘I wish to see Kusumapura, even lovelier because of the moon-light festival with its celebration duly started. Let the terraces of the palace be decorated and made worthy of being seen by us’ The officers inquire of the Chamberlain whether the king is not aware of the prohibition of the moon-light festival. The Chamberlain asks them not even to introduce this talk of the prohibition of the festival, as it

would surely bring about their instantaneous death. The officers should see that spotlessly white chowries are waved round the pillars with garlands suspended from the latter, and that the earth is favoured with a sprinkling with water with sandal mixed with it. The officers who readily accept the counsel of the Chamberlain are asked by him to hurry up as ‘His Majesty Candragupta is even [already] come here in this direction’.

Then enters king Candragupta accompanied by the female door-keeper. He states how kingdom far from being a source of delight to a king who follows the code of king’s duties, is a cause of great displeasure Dependent that he is on others he cannot know the taste of pleasure. Again, Sovereignty, like a courtezan who has got scope for her activities is so very difficult to be propitiated even by those possessed of self-control. For him personally, there is one more anxiety or worry. He has been ordered by preceptor CƒÅ·πáakya to have a sham quarrel with him (CƒÅ·πáakya) and deal independently so far as administrative duties are concerned for a while. Candragupta has accepted to act accordingly though to him the acceptance is little better than a sin. Candragupta would not like to have any more freedom than the one he was already enjoying He orders the Chamberlain to lead him to the SugƒÅnga palace.

Going up the palace, the king casts a glance at the quarters and appreciates their beauty hightened by the autumnal season. Even like rivers do the ten quarters flow from the sky. The autumnal season,the king observes, is instructing the people and helping them understand the importance of modesty (or discipline). S’arad has also brought about a happy (re-)union between the estranged couple‚Äîthe ‘offended’ Ganga and the ‘indifferent’ Ocean. The king is surprised to see that the capital city (Kusumapura) has not yet begun celebrating the moon-light festival. The Chamberlain finds it very difficult to answer the king’s question‚Äìif our command has been made known to all, how is there no indication of the festival having beenoommenced?’ Your Majesty, it is so’ does not satisfy the king

who orders the Chamberlain to state the matter clearly, Now comes the answer: ‘Your Majesty, the moon-light festival has been prohibited. ‘The king is all anger and asks ‘by whom?’ The Chamberlain pleads his inability to say anything more. The king conjectures that it must be revered CƒÅ·πáakya himself who has prohibited the celebration of the festival. Vaihƒ±nari’s answer ‘who else wishing to survive would transgress Your Majesty’s command?’ confirms the conjecture. The King takes his seat and sends Vaihinari with the message that he (Candragupta) wishes to see Fevered CƒÅnakya.

The scene shifts to the residence of CƒÅnakyaHe is full of anger as RƒÅksasa still continues to oppose himnay strives to surpass him. CƒÅ·πáakya apostrophizes RƒÅksasa and warns him not to pursue his activity any further. Between Candragupta and the Nandas as between CƒÅnakya and RƒÅksasa, there is a world of difference. Canakya concludes by observing that his spie, Siddharthaka and others, have already surrounded Malayaketu and entered his very heart and he (CƒÅnakya) need not therefore worry about the matter far too much. There is only one measure that must be adopted in the immediate future viz –∞ shamquarrel with the moon-like Maurya (Candragupta) which will bring about a rupture between the principal parties on the side of the enemy himself.

The Chamberlain has reached the minister’s house, the extreme simplicity of which impresses him most. That the prime minister of the supreme king of kings should have such a ‘prosperity’ is what surprises him.At the same time it also explains how ‘His Majesty’ Candragupta is to the prime minister only ‘V·πõ·π£ala’. One who has no desire, no longing, can afford to regard [even] the ruling sovereign to be as comtemptible or insignificant as a blade of grass Seeing the prime minister, surpassing in lustre even the thousand-rayed sun, the Chamberlain bends on his knees before him and conveys to him the message of the king. The prime minister takes no time to understand that the king must have learnt about the prohibition of the

moon-light festival ordered by him (CƒÅ·πáakya) and angrily asks ‘who informed (Candragupta about it)? The Chamberlain’s answer ‘His Majesty saw it, having gone up the SugƒÅnga palace, personally’ only leads the prime minister to another conjecture of which he makes no secret-’then by your people must the king have been seen in the meanwhile and incited against me; oh the attitude of extreme hatred that the king’s retinue has developed towards CƒÅ·πáakya !’ On being told to show the way to the SungƒÅnga palace, where His Majesty has gone, the Chamberlain meekly does so, saying ’this way, this way [may] ‘Your Reverence [come]” The prime minister of Candragupta goes up the SungƒÅnga palace and is mightily pleased to see Vrsala occupying the throne. Candragupta gets up from the throne and prostrates himself at the preceptor’s feet. The preceptor helps him rise, taking him by his hands and pronounces the blessing that he be saluted by hundreds of kings, repeatedly, coming from the vast area with the Himalayas as one extremity and the shore of the southern ocean as the other The pupil requests the preceptor to be seated and both get themselves seated in keeping with propriety.

The preceptor inquires of the king why he (CƒÅ·πáakya) was sent for. “To have myself favoured by your sight’ does not satisfy CƒÅnakya, who observes that men appointed to carry out duties are not invited by the rulers for nothing. Candragupta then asks ‘what advantage does the Revered one see in prohibiting the moon-light festival?’ “So for being reprimanded, were we sent for” says CƒÅ·πáakya and the king hurries to explain ’no no evil be deprecated; to requestyou, were you sent for’. CƒÅ·πáakya takes full advantage of this attitude of request and says‚Äîthen a pupil ought on no account to hinder the sweet will of the preceptor worthy of being requested.’ Candragupta submits‚Äî‘it is so; but never does the Revered one go in for any activity without any purpose; there is thus scope for a question regarding the purpose being put.’ ‘Not even in my dreams do I do anything that is without a purpose-you have well grasped, O Vƒ´·π£ala’ answers CƒÅ·πáakya Chandragupta says his keen desire to

hear (what the purpose is) made him speak [may be, perhaps far too much ].

CƒÅ≈Üakya explains to the pupil‚Äî’there are three kinds of achievement (in administrative matters) as expounded by those who have written treatises on the science of polity. He (Candragupta) is not a svƒÅyattasiddhi nor again, ubhayƒÅyatta siddhi. As such, being that is to say, sacivƒÅyattasiddhi, he had no business to make any inquiry regarding the purpose. That is entirely left to the minister and he would manage it. Naturally does the king turn hie face away in anger.

Just at this juncture, behind the curtain, two bards recite verses describing (i) the autumnal season. (ii) Lord Vi·π£·πáu getting up from the bed in the form of S’esa, (iii) the attitude of intolerance with regard to any violation of their crders shown by the sovereign rulers and (iv) the fact that a ’lord’ becomes ’lord’ worth the name not so much on account of the ornaments worn but because of his orders never being violated. A moment’s deliberation enables CƒÅnakya to understand that this is an attempt on the part of RƒÅksasa to bring about a split between Candragupta and himself i.e. CƒÅ·πáakya. Candragupta asks the Chamberlain to have a thousand gold coins given to the bard. CƒÅ·πáakya, however, peremptorily asks the Chamberlain to stop and blames Candragupta for thus wasting a huge amount for nothing. Candragupta becomes angry and says with this sort of restriction of the preceptor every where, the kingdom is only a prison and no kidgdom to us.’ CƒÅ·πáakya coolly replies ‘such defects are possible in the case of kings who do not apply themselves to the task of administration.‘There was only one thing he could do. It was to shoulder the responsibility of administration himself. ‘Here would he shoulder it‚Äî‘we would apply ourselves to our duty,’ says Candragupta CƒÅ·πáakya replies he is only too glad and that he too would apply himself to his own duty. The king takes the thread up and says he would then like to know the cause of the prohibition of the kaumudi mahotsava. CƒÅ·πáakya rejoins with the words, ‘I too would like to know the cause (or pur-

pose) of celebrating the *kaumudi mahotsava.’*That my command be not violated’ is Candragupta’s answer. CƒÅ·πáakya says ‘precisely, with a view to having your command violated was the prohibition of the festival ordered. I wanted to prove just this that your command implicitly obeyed by the kings as far away as the shores of the four oceans,stumbles on coming into contact with me And there is another cause also which I would tell if you are minded to hear it.”

CƒÅ·πáakya causes to be brought by the pratihƒÅri a list, of malcontents who had left Candragupta and joined Malayaketu, left with the scribe Acala. He reads the names on the list beginning with Bhadrabhata and ending with VijayavarmƒÅ. The king wants to know the causes of the disaffection of all these CƒÅnakya explains that Bhadrabha·π≠a and Purusadatta, in charge of the elephants and horses respectively, were seen to be addicted to women, wine and hunting, neglecting their duties and were therefore relieved of their duties, being permitted to have subsistence allowance only. Being given their posts by Malayaketu, the two joined him. DingarƒÅta and Balagupta were full of greed and considering their remuneration inadequate and hoping to get more, joined the enemy. RƒÅjasena, your attendant in your boyhood, having suddenly attained prosperity, thanks to your favour, went away to Malayaketu, fearing he would be deprived os the prosperity conterred on him BhagurƒÅyana with affection for Parvataka in his mind having arisen when the latter was our ally, having secretly frightened Malayaketu with the statement ‘by Canakya was your father killed,’ caused Malayaketu to go away from hither and Malayaketu full of gratitude at the thought that BhagurƒÅyans saved his life, gave to BhƒÅgurayana the position of his minister. RohitƒÅksa and Vijayavarman were too proud and too jealous of your relatives to stay on and therefore joined Malayaketu. The king asks if the causes of disaffection were known, why was nothing done to counteract the whole trouble?’ ‘It was not possible’ replies the minister. The king ask was it because of lack of skill, or was it on account of some purpose in view ?’ “Of coure the latter; there

could not be any lack of skill,” the minister answers. And the king wants to know the purpose at full length.

Listen and also understand carefully’ the prime minister begins the explanation of the purpose in view: Either one favours or one punishes those members of the body politic who are full of disaffection. In the case of Bhadrabha·π≠a and Purusadatta, addicted to evil habits, restoration to their respective offices would have led only to the destruction of the elephant force and the cavalry. DingarƒÅta and Balagupta would not be satisfied, greedy that they are, even if the entire kingdom be made over to them. RƒÅjasena and BhƒÅgurƒÅya·πáa were apprehensive of the loss of their property There was no scope left for doing a favo ur to them. RohitƒÅk·π£a and VijayavarmƒÅ had no patience with your relatives. No favour would have given them any delight. ‘yFavour’ was thus ruled out Nor was ‘punishment’ the proper course to adopt. If we were to have punishedour own helpers against Nandas, the subjects devoted to Nandas would have continued deeming us unworthy of any trust. Strengthened by our own people who have joined him, guided by RƒÅk·π£asa’, with a great Mleccha force at his command, Malayaketu is prepared, only too well prepared, to attack . This, therefore, is an hour of exercise, not of festivity What use is the moon-light festival? With this thought was it prohibited by me.

Candragupta is not satisfied with this explanation and says that there is a good deal he has to ask in the matter. ‘Ask unhesitatingly, I too have a good deal to tel. In the matter rejoins CƒÅnakya. The king wants to know why was Malayaketu, the root cause of the whole trouble *ignored,*while leaving the capital (Kusumapura)? CƒÅnakya explains. If not ignored he would either have been taken prisoner as a necessity or given half the promised kingdom. The first would have only confirmed the charge of ungratefulness levelled against us taking the shape ‘by these very people was Parvataka caused to be killed,” The latter course would have had the fruit of undoing what had been previously achieved. Getting rid of Parvataka would

have borne no fruit, if half the kingdom were given away to Malayaketu.

Supposing this was the right course to adopt in regard to Malayaketu, what answer would the Revered one make to the question ‘how was RƒÅksasa, going away from here, ignored by you?” “Allowing him to stop in the city would have led to a great internal disturbance, a revolt, as he enjoyed the confidence of the citizens, was rich in possession of wealth and lieutenants. Allowed to go away, he could be controlled by some means,"‚Äîthe answer thus given by the preceptor does not satisfy the pupil The latter asks ‘why was RƒÅksasa not seized per force?’ ‘Here too we were facing a dilemma,’ answers Ca·πáakya,‚Äî‘if attacked per force (1) he would have fought till the end, till he fell on the battlefield, which would have resulted in your losing such an eminent man as RƒÅksasa, or (2) would have killed your leading army officers. The pupil owns his incapacity to carry on a wordy warfare with the preceptor but states as the sum and substance of all he wanted to say: ‘minister Raksasa himself is on all counts highly praiseworthy in this entire episode.’ ‘And not I, you should have completed the sentence’ so saying, CƒÅ·πáakya asks ‘what was it that Raksasa had achieved to enable him to win this superiority ?’ The king explains‚Äîif you don’t know, then listen : he stayed in the city conquered by us as long as he wanted, caused obstruction to the proclamation of victory by ourarmy, per force, and now I am so bewildered by the greatness of RƒÅksasa’s policy that my mind does not believe even our own [so far] trustworthy men. CƒÅnakya observes derisively‚Äîthis is what be did; I thought he established Malayaketu on the throne having displaced you, as I established you on the throne, having extirpated the Nandas.’

All this was done by just another. What credit could the Revered one claim here this question of the pupil makes the teacher ask the pupil ‘who killed even like the beasts employed victims at a sacrifice, oneafter another, the Nandas, while [your] RƒÅksasa was helplessly looking on?’ Not long ago the cemetary fires were raging

to the great delight of the animals feasting on the corpses of the Nandas. Had Candragupta forgotten that? ‘Candragupta refuses to be impressed by this and repeats, his previous answer: ’this was done by just another’ ‘By whom?’ asks the teacher. By fate, ever so hateful towards the Nanda family’, answers the pupil. ‘Fools respect Fate’ rejoins the teacher. The pupil’s answer is ‘wise ones too are not given to boasting.’ The teacher is enraged and prepares to declare another vow, the fire of his anger having been enkindled by by the pupil. The hand of the teacher hurrying to untie the knot of hairthat was bound, and the foot ready again to mount on a vow, as also his knitting of the eyebrow and the lightning-like lustre of his eyes frighten Candragupta who says to himself ‘O, how the preceptor is really angry !’ CƒÅnakya withdraws his feigned anger, throws away the badge of his office saying let this (sword) be given to RƒÅksasa. as he is in your opinion superior to me.’ He is in his own mind quite confident, however, that RƒÅksasa who wanted to brings about a split between CƒÅnakya and Candragupta, would as a result of this sham quarrel, have to face a split between Malayaketu and himself (RƒÅksasa).

On Ca·πáakya’s departure Candragupta commands the Chamberlain to proclaim to the subjects that from that moment onwards, having disregarded CƒÅ·πáakya, Candragupta was going to look after the administration. As the Chamberlain is wondering how the king has referred to as CƒÅnakya without the honorific epithet ‘ƒÅrya’ the king asks him what he is thinking about. The Chamberlain hurries to explain ‘fortunately has your majesty become your majesty (in the fuil sense of the term)’. Candragupta welcomes the impression of the Chamberlain and hopes that all would feel so and that noble CƒÅnakya would thus be able to achieve his objective. The king then asks the famale door-keeper S’onottarƒÅ to show him the way to the bed-chamber, as he has got, as a result of the useless quarrel, a headache. In the last verse where Candragupta speaks to himself, he states how his mind feels like entering into the bowels of the earth, all full of shame as it is for

his having transgressed the due limit in the form of respect to be shown to the preceptor, at the latter’s own command, He for one, fails to understand how shame breaks not the heart of those who (wilfully) and as a matter of down right reality disrespect their preceptor.

(1) Construe:‚Äî‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§É ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§É ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø [‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø] ‡§ï‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§π ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡•§

(4) Construe:‚Äî‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§∞‡§ó‡§£‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§µ [‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ] ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡•á [‡§Ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç] !

The ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ due to the two meanings of ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç is evident As there is a comparison between ‚Äòhuman gods‚Äô and gods (‡§á‡§µ shows that there is one between them), the main ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ in the verse is ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ The metre of the verse is ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ.

4, 3, 7 Malayaketu, RƒÅksasa’s ally, is appearing on the stage (for the first time in the play). He is accompanied by BhagurƒÅyana who has been appointed as minister (see 3, 4, 27, P. 102 text) by him and by his Chamberlain JƒÅjali, 19 This passage has an importance of its own in being helpful to decide the time taken by the action in the play (Read pp 11-12 Introduction). ‡§® ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡§ø‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‘Not even a cavityful of water has been poured or offered’ ‚Äîshows how much the prince feels for not having done anything, to avenge the murder of his revered father. Love of and regard for his father is the only redeeming feature of Malayaketu’s character, which otherwise has very little to recommend in it (Read pp 20-21 Introduction) ‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§â‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ß‡§∂‡§Æ‡§É ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§É tenth month since father was dead’, the idiom requring the genitive of an event after which time is calculated deserves to be noted. Thus ‘‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø’ it isthe fifth day since I arrived here.

(5) Construe :‚Äî‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§°‡§®‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§π‡§æ ‡§π‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡§ø‡§É ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ø‡§É‡•§

By me a cavityful of libation (-water) [‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡§ø‡§É] has to be given to i. e. in honour of my father (‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å). But be-

fore that I must effect or bring about (‡§µ‡§ø+‡§ß‡§æ) a change in the condition (‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç) of women on the side of the enemy (‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Å). It would have for its cause grief [on account of the loss of their husband] (‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç). In the altered condition, the gem (-studded) circlets: (or bangles) would be broken on account of the beating of the bosom by the ladies ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§°‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡•§ Therein, the upper germent (‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï) would slip, from its position ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç! In it there would be the distressed (‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§§) cry ‘alas’ ‘alas’ I and therefore it would be piteous (‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§£) or pathetic‚Äô ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç. (6) Construe:‚Äî‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§•‡§æ ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡•Ä‡§ú‡§®‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ü‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§É‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§µ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§ú‡§®‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§µ‡§æ‡•§

There are two courses one out of which Malayketu says he must adopt: (a) to hold high (‡§â‡§¶‡•ç+‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç) the yoke of my father i, e. to shoulder his responsibility, worthy of a person who is not a coward (‡§® ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡§É‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç) and court death in a battle (‡§Ü‡§ú‡•å ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç and thus go along the path of my stree (‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§•‡§æ=‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§•‡§æ or (b) tears (‡§¨‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç) have to be taken away (‡§Ü+‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‚Äìgerund ‡§Ü‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø) from the eyes of my mothers and to be taken over (‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡§É) to those of the women-folk of the enemy. In simpler words

Malayaketu means to say that he ought either to fight to the last on the battle-field even if it means his death, or coming out victorious, ought to kill the enemies thus throwing their women-folk into the worst calamity viz. widowhood. As a result of this latter, the women on the enemy’s side would be bemoaning the loss of their husbands andthus be full of tears‚Äîthis being exactly what had formerly happened to his mothers.

‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§ï did not die on the battle-field but in the arms of the poison-maiden. ‡§Ü‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§•‡§æ ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç cannot be construwd.Either we take ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§É=‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç i.e. of the ancestors or we construe ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§•‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®as following in the footsteps of the father i.e going to the yonder world But in going to the yonder world, Malayaketu chooses to fight to the last on the battle-field (‡§Ü‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§®) ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§É‡§™‡§•‡§æ ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç in plain words is ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç and ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ü‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§É ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§µ‡§ß‡•Å‡§ú‡§®‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§®‡•á‡§Ø is in other words ’the enemy ought to be killed and his wo neufolk caused to be plunged into sorrow.’ The verse may therefore be regarded as au tustance of ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞. Its metre is ‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ. (‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ is grammatically wrong for ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® as ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç+‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç takes the ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§™‡§¶, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ has once, so far, used a wrong form for the exigency of the metre. An explanation of the use of the ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§™‡§¶ is sought to be given thus: the fruit of Malay iketu’s shouldering the responsibility of his father was to be of benefit to ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§ïand not to Malayaketu himself. Thus the ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§™‡§¶ is correctly used.)

    1. 2 ‡§Ö‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®a going i.e.visit which is not guessed or conjectured i.e. expected (beforehand): a surprise visit. ‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡•á‡§® enough of the trouble, away with the trouble. The prince gives the reason why other kings should not follow him: he wants to give delight to the minister by paying him a surprise visit. If all of them ware to accompany him, a surprise visit would not be possible.

(7) Construe:‚Äî‡§ï‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ñ‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§≠‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∂‡•à‡§É [‡§â‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É]‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡•Å‡§ü‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§µ ‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§É, ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§§‡§ú‡§µ‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§ï‡§ò‡§£‡•ç‡§ü‡•à‡§É‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∞‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É, [‡§π‡•à] ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ, ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡§ú‡§≤‡§ß‡§Ø ‡§á‡§µ ‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ ‡§® ‡§â‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§

(The Chamberlain informs the Prince that as soon as the kings were informed of the wish of Malayaketu, they obeyed the same. All of them have already returned.) Some have curbed their horses possessed of shoulder-regions having prominence (‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§ß‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§É ‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§â‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§É), shoulder-regions which are excessively (‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•) contracted (‡§≠‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞) on account of the very sharp (‡§ñ‡§∞‡§§‡§∞) bridle-bite being pulled up (‡§Ü‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§£) The horses (out of impatience quite natural to them) are as though breaking into pieces space (‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•ç) in front of them by their hoofs (‡§ñ‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡•Å‡§ü lit, folded or fold-like hoofs). This is a common sight for such as have an opportunity to see horses of excellent breed from close quarters. When curbed by the pulling in of the reins, the horses kick space impatiently. Visakhadatta jancies that they break as it were space in front of them into so many parts. Other kings have returned (‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É) with their leading (‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø) elephants (‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó), the bells [round their necks] silent (‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§ï) as their speed has been put an end to (‡§µ‡§ø‚Äì‡§π‡§§. The elephants are allowed to walk very slowly. The Chamberlain concludes from this that the protectors of the earth do not transgress (‡§® ‡§â‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø) your (‡§§‡•á) boundary i.e.they do not transgress the limit you have fixed for them In this respect they are comparable to the oceans (‡§ú‡§≤‡§ß‡§Ø‡§É lit, reservoirs of water) who do not go beyond the limit fixed by the king for them. (This latter is obviously a piece of the customary flattery of a royal servant as all who know the story of Canute’s reproof of his courtiers are aware. Oceans are governed more by nature’s, than by any king’s laws. In 1-3 there is a statement of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑or particular cases of some kings and in line 4 there is a general statement (‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø) which supports them. Of all kings it can be said they do not transgress the limit fixed by you Thus there is ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ in the verse. ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ is physical (the ‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ) in the case of the ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®, but metaphorical in that of the kings. Thus there is ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ contained in the verse The graphic description of the horses and the elephants in 1-3 makes it an Instance of ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞. The figure of speech in the verge as ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ (‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ú‡§≤‡§ß‡§Ø ‡§á‡§µ). The metre in which it is couohed is ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ.

4, 7, 1-3 The Chamberlain and the retinue return leaving BhƒÅgurƒÅyana alone to accompany Malayaketu as per the latter’s command. 4‚Äì8, Bhadrabha»õa etc. have made a representation to the prince that they have resorted to the prince not through ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏, but through ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∞‡§∏‡•á‡§®, ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å’s General; that they were full of disaffection (‡§Ö‡§™‚Äì‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É) for ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ as the latter had gone into the clutches of the wicked minister (CƒÅ·πáakya) and [above all] as the prince was richly endowed with (‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó) qualities (‡§ó‡•Å‡§£) of one who deserves to be approached as a resort (‡§Ü‡§≠‡§ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï). Performing such rites as the ‚Äò‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®’ (‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§∞‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•á‡§§) is no easy taskCƒÅnakya is fully aware of this and would therefore think twice before declaring another vow for the fulfilment of which he will have to practise the same ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ again. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§É is asignificant ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£ making the verse an instance of ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞. ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§π‡§§‡•á=‡§® ‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§π‡§§‡•á (present in the sense of future) contains ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§® ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞in it. ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ñ‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø=‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç……..‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø Lines 3 and 4, therefore illustrate the ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞. The Prince proceeds to inquire whether the minister has any relief from the headache he was suffering from 9-10 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏’s reply is worthy of a sincere minister, who has resorted to ‘*Prince’*Malayaketu as an ally So long as the Prince has not become the sovereign ruler (‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú, how could there be any relief? ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ the title ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§ not looked down upon i.e. not stamped out Evidently ‘so long as the title ‘adhiraja’ has not stamped out the title ‘KumƒÅra’ is a ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ fashion of saying ‘so long as the Prince has not risen to the eminence of the sovereign ruler’ 11 ‡§â‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§, under taken, is the same as ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ (also ‡§â‡§∞‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§), [‡§ä‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ is a misprint] ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å says now that this object is undertaken by ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏, it would not be difficult to secure it. this calamity pertaining to the minister is [practically] no calamity. 20 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ explains that of other kings this may some times be true But of ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§, the calamity in the form of estrangement from the minister is a great calamity.

21-23 ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å explains his point: The subjects (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§É) of ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ were drsaffected [only] on account of ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø’s faults, But now that ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø has been removed, the subjects already full of affection for ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§.would be even more so. 24-29 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ points out: there are two types of subjects (1) those who rose in revolt against the Nandas with Candragupta and (2) those full of affection for the Nanda family. Of the former. only. ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø’s faults were the cause of disaffection, and just hrs faults were the cause of disaffection But of those full of affection for the Nanda family, this is not true They had got themselves (offended ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É) agitated by disaffection (‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó) and anger (‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑) as (‡§á‡§§‡§ø) Candragupta had destroved the family that had become [his] parent [family]‚Äîor that had become their parent [family]. They are at present following just Candragupta, failing to secure any resort for themselves. But now that they have a king of your eminence with such power as would enable him to uproot the rival party i. e Candragupta, they would quickly abandon Candragupta and resort just to you. This is no mere theoretical argument. ‘We’ says ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏.‚Äòare ourselvas a convincing (‡§®‡§ø) example ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç)of this [development sure to take place]’ 30-31 ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å wants to make sure that the calamity that has befallen Candragupta is really great He inquires whether there is any other calamity. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏answers ’this is the most important one ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å has his doubts. He therefore inquires‚Äîwould ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§not find it possible to entrust the heavy responsibility (‡§ß‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç) of administration to some other minister [now that ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø is dismissed from office] or to shoulder it himself, and thus counteract the calamity?35-37 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ replies ‘‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§, depending for his success [or achievement] on the minister as he has been so far, is one who has not seen any dealings pertaining to administration himself‚Äîthat he is on a par with a man whose eyes have no power of seeing and that thus he would not be able to counteract the calamity.

(13) Construe:‚Äî‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•á ‡§ö ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•á [‡§∏‡§§‡§ø] ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§â‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•á; ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§π‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§è‡§ï‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡§ø!

Frankly this verse is a textual difficulty in the play not solved so far. It is evident that the verse has no vital relation to the argument preceding it. There is no word or phrase (‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§π‡§ø, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§É, ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö etc.) connecting it with the prose passage which it follows. The difficulty remains unsolved because it is not possible to decide whose Jeet (‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•å) are refere red to in line 2‚Äîwhether they are the feet of the minister and the king, or they are those of Sovereignty herself. In the translation (p.132) given in this edition, the idea understocd to have been intended by the poet is: when the minister and the King are each very much exalted, Sovereignty plants her feet firmly [one each] on their shoulders. [But standing so high up is an acrobatic feet which Sovereignty cannot keep on performing indefinitely long]. As is natural to a woman, she finds it impossible to maintain the difficult position (lit weight ‡§≠‡§∞) or sustain the strain and abandons one of them. [‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø & ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ are both exalted. This verse is properly connected with the prose passage which it comes immediately after A King who leaves to the minister (‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£) all administrative responsibility, when dragged away (‡§Ö‡§™‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü.) from him, is not able to live even for a moment, like an infant sucking the mother (lit breast ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§® ‡§ß‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Ç‡§ß‡§Ø) when weaned, not being able to survive even a moment. The king has his intellect all too dull‚Äînot at all rendered sharp‚Äîas he has seen no worldly dealings at all. The infant too is in the same state. (22) Construe : ‚Äî‡§è‡§§‡•á ‡§â‡§™‡§µ‡§®‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§É ‡§â‡§¶‡§Ø‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§É ‡§â‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•Å ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç [‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•å] ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ø [‡§∏‡§§‡§ø] ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ; ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§

Here the trees (‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡§É) in the garden (‡§â‡§™‡§µ‡§®) with their reddish tinge (‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó) manifested [as the red glow of the morning sun is spread over the trees] (punningly with their

affection (‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó) for the sun manifested) went far in front (‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç) of the sun (‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•Å) as he rose up from the mountain of, rise, and went very quickly (‡§Ü‡§∂‡•Å ‡§è‡§µ) by the shadows of their leaves, ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äì‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç. The plural …‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•à‡§É brings out that there are many ‡§™‡§£‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ω. Early in the morning, as soon as the sun rose, the trees cast long stretching shadows of their leaves [going westward]. This is like servants running ahead of the master to help him or escort him. But now that the sun has his orb (‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ) throw (‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§) on the edge (or region] (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§) of the other mountain i.e. the mountain of setting, the trees have returned. The shadows of the trees in the evening fall not sun-ward, but in such a way as to make the fancy possible that they are going away (‡§®‡§ø+‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç lit, returning) from the sun. The behaviour of the trees in the morning where the sun has risen. (is prosperous) and later in the evening when his orb has fallen on the edge of the mountain of setting, is regarded by ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏as typical of a majority (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§É) of servants For, these latter, mostly give up their master, even while serving him (‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§É), when the master has fallen from his prosperity (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§É ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç or ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§É). The verse contains in it the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® (line 4) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø (lines 1‚Äì3) ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§® - type of ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏. There is ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ also present as ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó (1) red tinge and (2) affection, occurs in line 1.

There is no special occasion for ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ to express the thought about servants contained in the verse. But the observation is true to facts, guardedly made as it is by the poet (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§É). Occasionally it is possible to come across grateful servants who stick to their worthy master through thick and thin. But the bulk of selfish people keep company with the master only so long as he is prospering As soon as the master falls on evil days, the servants desert him. [Though ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ is innocent of any desire to be prophetic, the words prove true of ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å and his supporter in act VI (vide VI 2. 30-34,) though for the desertion of the former by the latter, the former is to thank his own ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ or thoughtlessness. It would appear to be better not to understand any premonition here, as the cases of the sun (‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•Å)

and ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å are not on all fours with each other. For, there is no ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æof the sun referred to in 4,22].

The act is appropriately called ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó as ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ gird up his loins on learning that there was a rift between‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ and advises ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å to start on thb military expedition with Kusumapura as its objective. 42, The Praves’aka comes to a close. A ‘pravesaka’ is an ‚Äòinterlude‚Äô occuring between two acts, where subordinate characters take part in the conversation. For other details regarding a ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ï, a‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ may be referred to. Thus a ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ï, like a ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠, is indicative of what has happened already in the course of the plot of the play and what is going shortly to happen. It is thus a connecting link with brevity emphasized. In as brief a space as possible as much more should be conveyed as possible. Both‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ and ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ïare thus measures resorted to for the purpose of economy by the dramatist. Vi·π£kambha may be either ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß or ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ if a‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ character figures [or‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ characters figure] in it or if ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ and ‡§®‡•Ä‡§ö characters figure in it, respectively. A ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ï has no‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ character figuring in it and its language as a rule is Prak·πõt (Read‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ï‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ã ‡§®‡•Ä‡§ö‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡•• ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§•’s ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£ VI, 55-57). (4) Construe:‚Äî‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•á ‡§≤‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§É, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§ò‡§®‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ò‡§®‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø, ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§É, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•É‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡•§

BhagurƒÅya·πáa asks why should a man, dependent on another (‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É), after having sold his person (‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø) to one possessed of wealth ‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§§‡§ø), out of greed for wealth that lasts only for a short while (‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§ø‡§ï), and executing the master’s orders [with implicit obedience), consider afterhaving once accepted the position (‡§Ö‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§æ lit, now). ‚Äò[this is] wholesome (‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ø, [and this] unwholesome (‡§Ö‡§π‡§ø‡§§? Already the servant has gone past all consideration (‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É), left out inadvertently in the translation at p. 144) He has turned his face away from his noble family (‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤=‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§É) i e, its noble traditions, from sense oshame, from his own reputation or fair name and from [Justifiable] pride ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®). The moment the position of a servant was accepted for the sake of lucre, the man bad adieu to all decency, all thought of the distinction between good and bad.

The verse is appropriately put into the mouth of BhƒÅgurƒÅya·πáa in whose mind there is a regular conflict that is going on. BhƒÅgurƒÅya·πáa now feels drawn to Malayaketu,

if for no other reason, for the latter’s implicit faith in him.To deceive‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å would be the most unkindest cut of all. But then‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£is not free to consider what is proper or improper. The verse by itself is an instance of ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ, for, when‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£ wanted to speak of himself individually, he has, referred to a whole class of persons viz, servants who have sold themselves to their master. The verse is couched in the ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä metre.

(5) Construe:‚Äî [‡§è‡§∑] ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡•É‡§¢‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡§£‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç [‡§è‡§∑] ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ß‡§É ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç? ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§É ‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§

‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å’s mind has as it were mounted on the potter’s (‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø) wheel and is for long revolving [‚Äìnot being able to decide] whether ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ on account devotion [made quite) firm (‡§¶‡•É‡§¢) by his love of the Nanda family would enter into an alliance (‡§∏‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á) i.e., make peace with Candragupta (‡§Æ‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø), a scron (lit, one who depends on i e., here belongs to) of the Nanda family (‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø lit, linefrom ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å+‡§á to go after) and one who has achieved what is worth achieving (‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•Ä) by the repudiation**(‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§ = ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ this being an instance of ‡§®‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É) or removal of CƒÅnakya ‚Äî or whether he would consider firmness of devotion i.e. adherence to the political party once chosen to be more important and be true to his word? ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ(word)‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡§É keeping one’s word. The mind is going swiftly from one alternative to another and presumably in a like manner to a third and fourth (vide‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç) [though allof them are not stated in so many words] and‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å fanciesthat it has been put as it were on the potter’s wheel. (9) Construe:‚Äî ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ü‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É‡•§

In the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§, ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï makes a salutation to devotion to the master which makes them see only the excellences (lit, brings them to the excellences) and ignore (lit, cause to turn their face away from) faults. Siddhartharka too, like‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£, is essentially a human being with the sense of decency still alive. He is aware that he is now going to betray minister RƒÅk·π£asa, who had given him shelter on being told that having offended CƒÅnakya he could not return to ‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ [‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£ as well as ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï, paid agents of ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø, were not altogether blind to moral consideration. Their fault was, as they themselves were conscious that they had sold themselves to their employer. If they were equal to the task of considering the whole moral question, perhaps they would not have stated anything like V, 4 and V.9. At any rate the idea that the ethics of the Mudr√°rƒÅksasa are the ethics of scheming politicians with no scope for or trace of the common man’s views is a position that is untenable. (10) Construe:‚Äî‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ò‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§É ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø, ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø; ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø [‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø] ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§® ‡§á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§

The verse teems with technical terms used by the followers of the ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø and ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï systems while setting forth the ‚Äòsyllogism‚Äô. A king (‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø) is compared with a person who is arguing (‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä) and the instrument (‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®) i. e. the ‚Äòmiddleterm‚Äù that would help the aor the debator and the army that will help the king secure his object, are described with words having a double meaning in lines 1 and 2 And the ‚Äòmiddle term‚Äô that would lead the debator to defeat in arguing (‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π), as also the army that will lead the king to defeat on the battle-field are described, again with double meaning words, in times 3 and 4. The whole exposition of ‚Äòsyllogism‚Äô as it is set forth in works on logic in Sanskrit cannot and need not be given here. But it would be found helpful to the understanding of the verse to grasp the details that follow:

(1) ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§ (2) ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ (3) ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§É ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•á‡•§ (4) ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§ (5) ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç [or (3) ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡•á‡•§] is a typical instance of syllogism as given in Sanskritworks. is not enough in ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®. The first two lines of the vere would then mean: The middle term which is definitely (‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§) known to be connected with the major term (smoke known definitely to be connected with fire, there being no doubt about the matter), which is well formed (‡§ò‡§ü‡§ø‡§§) thanks to the rule of invariable concomittance in presence (‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§É, which has a stand on, which dwells in, a similar instance ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑(‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•á where both smoke and fire are present), which is absent from (‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§) a dissimilar instance (‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§π‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‚Äîin a tank full of water there being neither fire nor smoke), that [middle term] leads to the establishment of the desired conclusion viz, ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§

Of the army (‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®), the first two lines can thus be understood The army (‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®) which is definite about its objective, well formed i.e. strengthened or reinforced (‡§ò‡§ü‡§ø‡§§) by unity (‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‚Äîone following another i.e all being agreed), which stands close to the one of its own side (or party) (‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç), turning away from the one who is hostile [or beloning to the oppposed group], (‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§É ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äî that army leads [the king] to victory (‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø).

The 3rd and 4th lines understood of the middle term would mean; the middle term which is itself yet to be obtained(‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç) or established [in regard to its capacity to prove the major term of the minor term], which is equally present in both i.e.‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ and ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ and which [further] is opposed to the minor term i,e. proves exactly the opposite of ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø of the minor term, by the acceptance of that middle term there would take place the defect (‡§®‡§ø‚Äì‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π) of the debator.

Pertaining to the army, the 3rd and the 4th lines

would mean : the army (‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®) which itself is yet to be proved efficient (‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç, which is similarly disposed (‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø) to both a friend as well as a foe, which is opposed to the side or cause it represents (‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß)‚Äìby the acceptance of such an army, there wodld be she seizure, the‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π i.e. defeat of the master i.e. the king [at the hands of his enemy].

(11) Construe:‚Äî ‡§ñ‡§∂‡§Æ‡§ó‡§ß‡§ó‡§£‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡•à‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç; ‡§∏‡§Ø‡§µ‡§®‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§É; ‡§ö‡•Ä‡§®‡§π‡•Ç‡§£‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ï‡§®‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å; ‡§ï‡•å‡§≤‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§•‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§£‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§

The Khas’a and Magadha hosts with their armies arranged are to be at the fore-front, with leading them; tribes from Kandahar along with the Ionian chiefs are to make an effort to march in the middle; the S’aka kings strengthened by the Chainese and the white Huns are to bring the rear, while is to be surrounded [for safety obviously] by the five kings Kaul≈´ta (Citravarma) etc. on the way.‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ does not care much for chronology here and jumbles together several tribes though it is doubtful whether all of them were there in the days of Candragupta (Maurya). The Khas’as are assigned to the north-eastern part of Bengal. ‘Magara’, rather than ‘Magadha’, suggested by Mr. Telang would mean the forefathers of the Gurkhas of Nepal Chinese, Ionians and white Huns came into India‚Äîthough not all of them at the same time. The metre of the verse is ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ. 2-12 The female door-keeper of‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å appears and conveys his word to ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏. The latter recails that ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å had sent him ornaments and causes one of those purchased by S’aka·π≠adƒÅsa to be brought to him. On the servant’s doing so, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ puts the ornament on and starts with a view to going to that part of the camp where could be seen. Little does he know what havoc the ornament he has put on is going to play in the near future.

(24) Construe:‚Äî ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø? ‡§∏‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡§æ ‡§® ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç? ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç [‡§™‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç] ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø? ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•å ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§§‡§ø [‡§∏‡§§‡§ø] ‡§á‡§Ø [‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å] ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ; ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ñ‡§°‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡§ñ‡§É ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§¨‡§≤‡•á ‡§™‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø? ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ö ‡§® ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç; ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏ ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ò‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç, ‡§∞‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§

There are three alternatives that suggest themselves to‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏. (1) Shall I repair to a penance ‚Äì forest? But this would hardly give any peace to my mind-would fail to give peace to my mind with the [feeling of] enmity [influencing it strongly (2) Shall I follow my master, departed to the other world? But doing this while yet the enemy lives without doing anything to kill the enemy would be worthy of (‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‚Äì‡§§‡§æ) women! A man ought to avenge himself on his enemy by fighting. Suicide is not the proper path for him to follow. (3) Shall I with my sword as my companion fall on the enemy

force? This too would not be proper. One against many would decide the question again in favour of the enemy. The mind, if it be not ungrateful and in a hurry (‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç) to secure the release of CandanadƒÅsa, would obstruct me, impede me, if I would think of resorting to the 3rd alternative. For, more important than fighting the enemy’s army, as saving the life of my dearest friend CandanadƒÅsa, who has done all he could for me.

The metre of the verse is‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É=‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É The fifth act is called K≈´·π≠alekha or the ‚Äòartful (‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü) letter as the letter in the hand of S’akatadƒÅsa plays so important a part in and occupies so much of the space of the act. The‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§§‡•ç‡§µ of the letter lies in ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏’s not being in a position to give any satisfactory explanation of the letter.

To turn to a resume of the act:

ACT VI

6,0,1 Siddharthaka is decked with ornaments and full of joy when he enters. The ornaments are those he has received, as can be inferred (vide 5,2,17), as a gift from Candragupta to whom‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï conveyed the glad news of their victory. Naturally is‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï full of joy.

(1) Construe:‚Äî‡§ú‡§≤‡§¶‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§É ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§É ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§®‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§§‡§™‡§∞‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§

Victorious is Ke≈õava i.e. the Lord in his Krsna incarnation who destroyed (lit, destroys) ‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä the deman Ke≈õin, deputed by Kamsa with a view to doing harm to Kr·π£·πáa [The demon came in the form of a horse. Krsna thrust his arm right into the mouth of the horse and rent him asunder]. Krsna’s complexion is dark‚Äìblue like that of a cloud, (‡§ú‡§≤‡§¶ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§É). (2) Construe:‚Äî‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•á ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§

Curious as it may appear, prosperous circumstances (‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§É) give pain to men. This happens in the absence of [lit. separation from] their friends who have secured a place in their heart, who are veritable moons (‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§à‡§∂‡§æ‡§É ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É, ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç) in extreme trouble (‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç+‡§§‡§™‡•á) i.e. who are a great cooling agency in times of trouble [‡§§‡§æ‡§™ heat badly requires‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞the cooling agency] and who, on occasions (‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§µ‡§Ç=‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å) of festivity in the house, enjoy pleasures (with zest) (‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§É) Instead of saying, ‘I am finding my prosperity to be the cause of pain or unhappiness, because my friend SiddhƒÅrthaka is away’, the speaker has stated a general proposition (‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®). (3) Construe:‚Äî‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•á‡§£ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§ú‡§≤‡§ú‡§≤‡§¶‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§®‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§ï‡§∂‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§É ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§ú‡§Ø‡§®‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§É‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§

(4) Construe:‚Äî‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§¶‡•É‡§¢‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§ø‡§ò‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§É ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§

Victorious is the rope in the form of CƒÅ·πáakya’s policy (‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡§è‡§µ ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§É), firm or strong (‡§¶‡•É‡§¢‡§æ) [such as would not give way], thanks to the putting together or stringing together (‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç+‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó) of the six ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ω (‡§∏‡§ß‡§ø, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π, ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®, ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§®, ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§ß‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ and ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø vide I, 5) explained in the ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ [‚Äîa rope too becomes strong when many threads (‡§ó‡•Å‡§£) s are woven into one], with the grip [lit. mouth, opening] of the noose fashioned. (‡§ò‡§ü‡§ø‡§§) with a series (‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§ø) of politecal expedients [such as ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ, ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®, ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§° and ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶] [‚Äî the grip of the noose used for hanging persons also has to be fashioned out with a number of devices which the expert alone knows], the rope only too ready (‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ) for binding down (‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç+‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®) the enemy-folk. There is ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï in the verse (‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§è‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§É). But as ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£, ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø are used with a double entendre there is‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ too contained in the verse. The metre of the verse is ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ.

8, 4, 5 ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§∏ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§∞‡•á‡§£…… (and not ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§∞‡•á‡§£ which is a misprint). The man says he has reached the place where he was to see minister ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏, as the latter was sure, to be there according to the spy (‡§â‡§¶‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§∞)’s report. 6-7 As expected by the man, ‚Äòminister‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ is comming in this very direction with his head wrapped(‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§É), evidently with a view to not being recognised. The man decides to hide behind the trees in the old garden and watch where takes a seat. The device of concealing oneself behind a tree and asertaining what is going on is quite common in Sanskrit works. Cf ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≤ Act I, where ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§ conceals himself behind the trees and listens to the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§æ‡§™ of the three friends ‡§Ö‡§®‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§µ‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ and ‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡§æ, 9 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ enters, sword in hand. Hs is full of tears to recall to his mind how sovereignty has played the Nanda family foul.

(5) Construe: ‚Äî‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ü‡§æ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ, ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§É ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§è‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§É, ‡§Ö‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§´‡§≤‡•à‡§É ‡§Ü‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§É ‡§â‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§•‡§µ‡§æ [‡§§‡•á] ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å [‡§§‡•à‡§É] ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•à‡§É ‡§á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§

Sovereignty [personified], like a wanton woman (‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡§≤‡§æ), a harlo, moving from family to family, nervous on account of her resort (i.e. support or supporter) having been cut off, has walked over into another family [Instead of remaining with the Nandas she has taken to the son of MurƒÅ]. The subjects [punningly, the progeny of the wanton woman] following bliadly those who walk ahead of them (‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É) having abandoned [all precious] affection [for the father] have followed just her [i.e. the wanton woman]. The reliable persons too have cast off the yoke of the mission (‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø), as they failed to get any fruit of their valour ‡§® ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§§‡•à‡§É) Or [why blame them?] What can they do?They remain like (so many) limbs (‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø) devoid of the best (‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ) limb i.e. the head [altogether helpless]. Sovereignty is compresed to a harlot (line 1) and the reliable, persons to limbs without the head to guide them, as the king is dead and gone‚Äîhas been annihilated with the whole of his family. (10) Construe:‚Äî ‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§É, ‡§®‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡•à‡§É‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§∂‡§®‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç , ‡§∏‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡§è‡§∑‡§É

‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É [‡§∏‡§®‡•ç] ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§

(11) Construe :‚Äî ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•å‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ã‡§É ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç [‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç], ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§á‡§µ ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§É ‡§´‡§≤‡•à‡§É ‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§É [‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É] ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡§É ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§á‡§µ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§É ‡§§‡•É‡§£‡•à‡§É ‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡•§

He further refers to the lake there in the garden which has, all gone dry - like the heart of a saint on the destruction of his friends. [Obviously this is the state of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏’s own mind on the destruction of the five kings ‡§ï‡•å‡§≤‡•Ç‡§§ etc. at the command of ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å). The trees in the garden are devoid of fruit thus resembling the political measures (lit, policies ‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É) that prove of ho avail on an association with Fate which is unfavourable (lit, without quality). This is one of the best Verses 10 this, Act, remarkable for the beauty of the soliloquy of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏(verses 5-15). This whole passage has a lyrical charm all its own and develops the sentiment of pathos (‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§£ ‡§∞‡§∏). There is ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ too in the verse as ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç and ‡§´‡§≤ are used each in two senses. The figure of speech in the verse is ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ. The moaning on the part of pigeons on the branches is regarded as the wailing of the

branches that have been wounded. (13) Construe:‚Äî ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§â‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ü‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§É, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§É \[‡§è‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§É\] ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§â‡§™‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§

(15) Construe ‚Äî ‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§É \[‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø\], ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ \[‡§§‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç\] ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§É ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§É \[‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡§ø\] ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡•§

The trees themselves are only too eager to go to the cemetary, drying up within their body, having the excessive grief in the form of the wounds made by the insects, gloomy on account of the absence of lustre [and also shade], plunged in difficulty.
