(1) Construe :‚Äî ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§• ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§∞‡§§‡•§

‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§•is a mispript.

If you wish to save your life, property or wealth (a), family and wife, then avoid so as to keep far (‡§∏‡•Å) far away (‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§£) [all that is] unwholesome to the king. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç lit, un-even i.e. fraught with difficulty qualifies ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø (as anything unwholesome is sure to involve the person responsible for it on difficulty).

(2) Construe :‚Äî ‡§Ö‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§

If what is unwholesome [medically] is taken, there takes place i.e. follows either a disease or death of a man. If what is un wholesome to the king is practised or done (a) the entire family perishes. Between the former and the latter, there is thus a world of difference [the obvious‚Äù suggestion being that people should avoid both, but especially the latter]. Verses 1 and 2 are both couched in the ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ metre.

(6) Construe:‚Äî ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§É? ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§Ö‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§æ? ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡§ü‡§É ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§É ‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§É?‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§É‡§≠‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§É‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§É ‡§ö ‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§É‡•§

CƒÅnakya regards the capture of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ a singular achievement of some of the most difficult tasks that could have been set to any body. He, therefore, very eagerly wants to know (‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø-‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø) who has achieved the impossible (! Who has tied up (blazing) fire (‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§É ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§É‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É), tawny on account of the mass (‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§™) of his flames that rise high (‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó), in the hem (‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É) of his garment? (2) Who has brought about absence of movement ‡§Ö‡§ó‡§§‡§ø-‡§§‡§æ‡§Éof i.e confined to a spot the ever-moving (‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§É) wind that knows no rest) by means of [ropes used as] noose (‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•à‡§É)? Who has put into the cage the lion with his mane (‡§®‡§ü‡§æ) made fragrant (‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§), by the ichor of elephants [whose temples the lion broke]? ‡§® ‡§è‡§ï = ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï Here ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï = ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø and ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§™ = ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™ = ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä) ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ü‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§É, (4) By whom has the dreadful (‡§≠‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§É) ocean (‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§É), with many

(‡§®‡•à‡§ï) crocodiles ‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞ and sharks (‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞) been crossed? ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§is here establishing a poetic connection between [A] capturing the brave and intelligent former prime-minister of the Nandas (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§-‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø) on the one brand and [B] (1) catching fire in the hem of one’s garment, (2) rendering wind motion less by having him caught by a noose, (3) putting a lion that destroys, elephants in large numbers in a cage and (4) crossing by means of just one’s pair of arms (‡§¶‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç Instrumental dual of ‡§¶‡•ã‡§Éarm) the dread ocean, thus keeping oneself exposed all the time to the danger of being drowned or made short work of by the terrible aquatic creatures, on the other. But this connection culminates in bringing ont the similarity (‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ï) between [A] and [B] 1), (A) and (B) 2), (A) and (B) (3) and (A) and (B) (4).  ( 9 ) Coustrue :‚Äî ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É, ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§É , ‡§∏‡§É ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡§É ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§≠‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É, ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§É ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É ‡§ö, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡§É ‡§ö,‡§Ö‡§∏‡•å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§É \[‡§π‡•á\] ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ã‡§É\[‡§Æ‡•á\] ‡§®‡§Ø‡§É‡•§

(1) The servants‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§ü\[‡§°‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ‡§§, ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§\] etc. (2) that letterof that type i.e forged (3) the Jaina saint as he feigned to be (‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤), your friend (viz Jivasiddhi), (4) that man in dis, tress in the old garden (on the skirts of Kusumapura\], (5) that trouble (‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂) to which the President (of the merchant Guild, CandanadƒÅsa) was put‚Äîall this was my policy, desirous that I was of bringing about, O brave (one), a union (‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó) between you and Vrsala (i.e. ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§) The stage direct- 101 ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç shows that ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø is abashed when referring, though not directly quite (as the word or has not been used by him), to himself. 7, 9,1 CƒÅnakya sees Candragupta coming where they (Rak·π£asa and CƒÅ·πáakya) were. So he tells ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ ‚Äòhere ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§≤ comes to see you.  (10) Construe :‚Äî ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø \[‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø\] ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ ‡§á‡§µ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ã‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ \[‡§Æ‡§Æ\] ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§§‡•Ç‡§£‡•Ä‡§∂‡§Ø‡§®‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡•§

My arrows have come into contact with (‡§Ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø) i.e. received their irontips (‡§´‡§≤) all right; but as they have not been appointed to duty i.e. are not used, they have. reached a state where they have lost their countenance or brightness (‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç). By paranomasia ‡§´‡§≤ means fruit.

This the arrows have achieved but they have not worked for the same [Ca·πáƒÅkaya achieved the victory to which they could hardly lay any claim]. They thus had remained away from the target, never having been so much as taken out of the quiver, fixed on the string and discharged. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§® is thus ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø (target) ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®, paranomestically. On the part of the arrows there is a firm stand (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ) [they have taken] on their vow (‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§) of remaining (lit. lying) in their quiver (‡§§‡•Ç‡§£‡•Ä), with their faces-iron-tipped end (‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø)s [as apart froms the other to which is attached a feather] turned downwards i.e. into the quiver, as though through their personal grief (that they had no opportunity in achieving this precious victory) Paranomastically i.e. with a ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ã‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Çwould mean (of arrows) ‚Äòwith their faces downcast‚Äô. The arrows are regarded as very sensitive persons. The fruit (‡§´‡§≤) is there, but they were not appointed to any task (‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó). They thus lost all brightness of countenance (‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§) have theirfaces hung low and they prefer to lie down motionless in their own places (rather than mix freely with others in the society). Thus there is ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑ contained inthe verse ‚Äò‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ã‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äô contains ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ in it. If the 2nd line is read ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç there would be ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞in lines 1 and 2 meaning ‚Äòhaving secured the fruit of my arrows that have gone to the enemy-side‚Äô. Now one who wins fruit or is successful does not go over to the enemy’s side. The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß is to be explained away thus: ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø = having had iron tips (at one end) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äì ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®‡§æi.e. ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç those that have feathers of birds attached to the other end. The verse with ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç’ as the reading can be regarded as an instance of ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞.. Read ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡•à‡§É ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§ The common adjectives ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ã‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ ‡§ó‡§§ make it possible to ascribe the behaviour of sensitive people to the arrows, The metre in which the verse is couched is ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä with the scheme ‡§∏, ‡§∏, ‡§ú, ‡§ó,‡§ó(lines 1,3) and ‡§∏,‡§≠,‡§∞,‡§Ø(lines 2,4) ‚Äò‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ‡•á ‡§∏‡§∏‡§ú‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§≠‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ changes his line of thinking as shown by ‡§Ö‡§•‡§µ‡§æ‚Äî

 ( 11 ) Construe :‚Äî ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§§‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§É ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø ‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡•§

He over whose administration ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á = ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á, ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á Jit, science of administration, here it is the practice that it is intended), his preceptors, watchful (‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ç‡§ï) regarding the mission or duty to be carried out (‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø), are awake-he, even though asleep,‚Äî even with his bow unstrung i.e. never used or ever idle (‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡§É ‚Äî the refernce being to the fact that only when in use the string ‚Äî‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‚Äî is tied to the other end also of the bow, otherwise romaining tied to one end) is able to conquer definitely (‡§è‡§µ) what is worth conquering on the surface of the earth. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ú‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡§æ is the effect achieved even In the absence of the cause ‡§∏‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ Though the bow is not strung, there is conquering of all worth conquering. There is thus ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ too. Read “‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ß‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§´‡§≤‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ’ ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ü in X. The metre of the verse is the same as that of the preceding (7, 10).

7. 11, 1 Candragupta draws near CƒÅnakya and salutes him‚Äî2-3 ‚ÄòNo blessing need be pronounced now, all desires having been fulfilled‚Äô, says CƒÅnakya, ‚Äòfor minister bas arrived. So salute the minister-in-chief ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‚Äô.

4 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ observes in the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§ ‚ÄòHere this one has [already] established the relaionship [-between ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§andmyselfasthe ‚Äòking and his prime-minister]‡•§ 5 ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Ωalutes ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ saying ‚ÄòNoble one,‚Äô Candragupta salutes [vou]‚Äô ‚Äî ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ sees‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ and remembers he is the one who had shown promise even when he was a boy.

 (12) Construe :‚Äî ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§É ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§•‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§µ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§

Even when a boy, Candragupta had his great rise in this world shown possible. (‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§â‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø), like an elephant rising to the position of being the lord of the herd (‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§•‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç), Candragupta has risen to sovereignty (‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø). The figure of speech in the verse is ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ. The metre used for the verse is ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç. Aloud ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ wishes victory to ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§. The latter says:

( 13 ) Construe:- ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•å ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á[‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á] ‡§ö ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á[‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø] ‡§ö ‡§∑‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø [‡§∏‡§§‡§ø] ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

When the preceptor, noble (CƒÅnakya) and the noble one i.e., yourself, are vigilant about the consideration of the six expedients (‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∑‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç), it may be thought about as to what on the surface of this earth it is that I have not won. By implication, Candragupta wants to be understood to say ‚ÄòI have won everything.‚Äô Securing such eminent men as CƒÅnakya and Candragupta as ministers is the same thing as winning everything in the world. The metre of the verse is ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç.

  7, 13, 1-5 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏'s first re-action to ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•å ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø is to think that ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§, ‡§ï‡•å‡§ü‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø's pupil that he is, is treating him as a servant (‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∂‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§®)But soon he realizes that it is the fine training, discipline, modesty (‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ø) that has made ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ politely refer to ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ as ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•áand that ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ genuinely was offering ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏ prime-ministership. Jealousy made him have a perverted view of the matter (‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø). He observes that it is in the fitness of things looked at from all view-pornts (‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§•‡§æ) that ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø was victorious or successful.

 (14) Construe:‚Äî ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§°‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ \[‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø\]; ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§è‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É \[‡§∏‡§®‡•ç\] ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤‡§ú‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§§‡§§‡§ø‡•§

Of a guide (‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§æ), on having secured a worthy person (‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø) as the ambitious king (‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Å) lit desirous of winning ‚Äî ‚Äòsovereignty‚Äô to be supplied), a firm establishment on position of one possessed of success is definitely secured,though the guide (i.e the minister who gives counsel) be dull-witted (‡§ú‡§°‡§É‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§É ‡§ú‡§°‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø). Having come across an unworthy (young ruler) however, a minister, even though his policy be free from fault (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§É‡§®‡§Ø‡§É‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø), falls in the manner (or fashion) of a tree growing on the bank of a river, with its resort scattered all about ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§É ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§É ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É. Like the pious wish ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§É ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç (in 1) and ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•Å (in1, 2) in the ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä at the commencement, here in the at the the end, there is a wish that is expressed: Let the king, with his relatives and servants rich in possession of wealth, AvantivarmƒÅ(by name), protect the earth for long. He is one whose pair of arms Earth is resorting to now, being harrased as she is by the Mlecchas. The tip of the tusk of this very (king‚Äî who is according to ‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É,) self‚Äî born one, who formerly assumed (lit

resorted to ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø] the boar ‚Äî form [‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç‚Äì‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‚Äì ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç] suited to the task (‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø lit. process) of protection, Earth had restored to in days of yore, when she was submerged in the watery deluge (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø). ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ is ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§É, who as the ‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‚Äîincarnation of Vis·πáu, raised the earth from the bottom of the ocean bearing it on the snout, formerly; that same ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§É to-day has become ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É i.e appeared as the king. Let him, therefore. continue to protect the earth for a long period of time.

 Evidently the dramatist is showing his gratitude to AvantivarmƒÅ, the saviour of the people. It would not be wrong to infer that the dramatist is voicing the esteem in which AvantivarmƒÅ was held by a large bulk of people in those days (sixth century A.D). \[For the bearing that the verse has on the date of the author, as also for the variant readings for ‚Äò‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‚Äô read Introduction Topic: 1 pp 1=6\].

In lines 1-2‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø (‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§) has swallowed ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§). The figure of speech in the verse, therefore, is ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø. The metre in which the verse is couched is ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ.

To turn to aresume of the last act: As the curtain is raised, there appears the CƒÅniƒÅla i.e. executionerVajralomƒÅ on the stage. He warns all those who want to save their life, their prosperity, and family to avoid anything unwholesome to the king. If they have any doubts regarding the hatter, they are only to look at Candanadasa who is being

To the query made by some persons whether there be any means by which CandanadƒÅsa can be freed, the hangman’s answer is there is one remedy viz. surrendering the memers of the family of RƒÅksasa, If CandanadƒÅsa refuses to surrender those that have thrown themselves on him for protection, he is on his way to the yonder world and no amount of thinking about means of saving CandanadƒÅsa’slife on the part of his sympathisers is likely to be of any use

CandanadƒÅsa consoles himself with the thought that the cruel make no distinction between the innocent and the offending. This is amply borne out by the insistence of hunters on killing the poor deer that leave flesh to itself and maintain themselves on blades of grass. CandanadƒÅsa looks around and is pained to see that his dear friend VisnudƒÅsa is not so much as giving a word is reply. Or, are not those who would be within sight of the condemned, when the latter is to be hanged, difficult to come across ? There are some dear friends of his whose only counteraction is the tears trickling down their cheeks and who with faces woe-begone, are returning with great difficulty with their bodies though continuing to follow CandanadƒÅsa with their eyes heavy with tears CandanadƒÅsa asks his wife to return with their son, on being asked to do so by the hangman Bilvapatra, as they have already reached the place of execution. CandanadƒÅsa's wife who is all tears pleads that her lord has started for another world and not another country. CandanadƒÅsa explains to her that his death is n–æ consequence of his fault as it is being brought about on account of bis having helped his fried and that she need not, therefore, be dejected. The lady says, ‚Äòif this be so, this is no time for the members of
